llm_translation: "The one who strikes shall surely be put to death," I have only with the death written about him. From where do we know that if you are able to kill him with the death written about him, you are permitted to kill him with any death that you are able to kill him with? The Talmud teaches: "He shall surely be put to death," in any manner.

hebrew_text: ״הַכֵּה תַכֶּה״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא בְּהַכָּאָה הַכְּתוּבָה בָּהֶן, מִנַּיִן שֶׁאִם אִי אַתָּה יָכוֹל לַהֲמִיתָן בְּהַכָּאָה הַכְּתוּבָה בָּהֶן שֶׁאַתָּה רַשַּׁאי לְהַכּוֹתָן בְּכׇל הַכָּאָה שֶׁאַתָּה יָכוֹל? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״הַכֵּה תַכֶּה״, מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: “You shall strike [ hakeh takeh ] I have only with death written with regard to them, From where that if you are unable to execute them with death written with regard to them, it is permitted for you to execute them with any death which you are able to execute them? The verse states: “ Hakeh takeh ,” in any case.
llm_translation: "The one who strikes shall be struck." I have only with regard to the striking written in them, from where do we know that if you are able to kill them with the striking written in them, that you are permitted to strike them with any striking that you are able? The Talmud teaches: "The one who strikes shall be struck," in any case.

hebrew_text: ״הָשֵׁב תָּשִׁיב״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא שֶׁמִּשְׁכְּנוֹ בִּרְשׁוּת בֵּית דִּין. מִשְׁכְּנוֹ שֶׁלֹּא בִּרְשׁוּת בֵּית דִּין, מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״הָשֵׁב תָּשִׁיב״, מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: “You shall restore [ hashev tashiv ] I have only took collateral with the sanction of the court. From where took collateral without the sanction of the court? The verse states: “ Hashev tashiv ,” in any case.
llm_translation: "Return you shall surely return," I have only that he dwells in the jurisdiction of the court. If he dwells not in the jurisdiction of the court, from where? The Talmud teaches: "Return you shall surely return," from any place.

hebrew_text: ״חָבֹל תַּחְבֹּל״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא שֶׁמִּשְׁכְּנוֹ בִּרְשׁוּת. מִשְׁכְּנוֹ שֶׁלֹּא בִּרְשׁוּת, מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״חָבֹל תַּחְבֹּל״, מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: take as collateral [ ḥavol taḥbol ] I have only took collateral with the sanction of the court. From where took collateral without the sanction of the court? The verse states: “ Ḥavol taḥbol ,” in any case.
llm_translation: "Chavol tachvol," I have only that it dwells in a domain. If its dwelling is not in a domain, from where? The Talmud teaches: "Chavol tachvol," from any place.

hebrew_text: וְהָנֵי תְּרֵי קְרָאֵי לְמָה לִי? חַד לִכְסוּת יוֹם, וְחַד לִכְסוּת לַיְלָה.
human_translation: And these two verses, why do I One to a garment day, and one to a garment night
llm_translation: These two verses, why do I need them? One for the covering of the day, and one for the covering of the night.

hebrew_text: ״פָּתֹחַ תִּפְתַּח״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא לַעֲנִיֵּי עִירֶךָ. לַעֲנִיֵּי עִיר אַחֶרֶת, מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״פָּתֹחַ תִּפְתַּח״, מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: You shall open [ patoaḥ tiftaḥ ] I have only to the poor of your city. From where to the poor of another city The verse states: “ Patoaḥ tiftaḥ ,” in any case.
llm_translation: "Open, you shall open," I have only for the poor of your city. For the poor of another city, from where? The Talmud teaches: "Open, you shall open," from any place.

hebrew_text: ״נָתֹן תִּתֵּן״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא מַתָּנָה מְרוּבָּה. מַתָּנָה מוּעֶטֶת, מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״נָתֹן תִּתֵּן״, מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: You shall give [ naton titten ] I have only a large gift. From where a small gift The verse states: “ Naton titten ,” in any case,
llm_translation: "Give, you shall give," I have nothing except a large gift. A small gift, from where? The Talmud teaches: "Give, you shall give," from any place.

hebrew_text: ״הַעֲנֵיק תַּעֲנִיק״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא שֶׁנִּתְבָּרֵךְ הַבַּיִת בִּגְלָלוֹ מַעֲנִיקִין. לֹא נִתְבָּרֵךְ הַבַּיִת בִּגְלָלוֹ, מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״הַעֲנֵיק תַּעֲנִיק״, מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: “You shall furnish [ ha’aneik ta’anik ] I have only when the house is blessed because of him, one furnishes From where the house is not blessed because of him? The verse states: “ Ha’aneik ta’anik ,” in any case.
llm_translation: "Ha'anek ta'anik," I have only that the house is blessed because of him who bestows. The house is not blessed because of him, from where? The Torah teaches "Ha'anek ta'anik," in any case.

hebrew_text: וּלְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה, דְּאָמַר: נִתְבָּרֵךְ הַבַּיִת בִּגְלָלוֹ – מַעֲנִיקִין לוֹ, לֹא נִתְבָּרֵךְ הַבַּיִת בִּגְלָלוֹ – אֵין מַעֲנִיקִין, ״תַּעֲנִיק״ לְמָה לִי? דִּבְּרָה תוֹרָה כִּלְשׁוֹן בְּנֵי אָדָם.
human_translation: And according to Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, who says: the house is blessed because of him, one furnishes him the house is not blessed because of him, not furnish why do I ta’anik ”? The Torah speaks in the language of people.
llm_translation: To Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah, who said: "If the house is blessed because of him - they give to him, if the house is not blessed because of him - they do not give." "Why should I give?" The Torah spoke in the language of people.

hebrew_text: ״הַעֲבֵט תַּעֲבִיטֶנּוּ״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא שֶׁאֵין לוֹ וְאֵינוֹ רוֹצֶה לְהִתְפַּרְנֵס, אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא: תֵּן לוֹ דֶּרֶךְ הַלְוָאָה. יֵשׁ לוֹ וְאֵינוֹ רוֹצֶה לְהִתְפַּרְנֵס, מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״תַּעֲבִיטֶנּוּ״, מִכׇּל מָקוֹם.
human_translation: you shall lend [ ha’avet ta’avitennu ] I have only where one does not have and does not want to be supported the Merciful One states: Provide him by means of a loan. he has and he does not want to support himself from where The verse states: “ Ta’avitennu ,” in any case.
llm_translation: "The garment you shall surely return," I have nothing except that he has no desire to support himself, the Merciful One said: Give him a loan. He has the means but does not wish to support himself, from where? The Scripture teaches: "You shall surely return it," in any case.

hebrew_text: וּלְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן דְּאָמַר: יֵשׁ לוֹ וְאֵינוֹ רוֹצֶה לְהִתְפַּרְנֵס אֵין נִזְקָקִין לוֹ, ״תַּעֲבִיטֶנּוּ״ לְמָה לִי? דִּבְּרָה תוֹרָה כִּלְשׁוֹן בְּנֵי אָדָם.
human_translation: And according to Rabbi Shimon, who says he has and does not want to support himself one is not obligated to attend to his why do I ta’avitennu ”? The Torah speaks in the language of people
llm_translation: And for Rabbi Shimon who said: If one has the ability to earn a livelihood but does not wish to, we are not obligated to support him, "Why should I bear him?" The Torah spoke in the language of people.

hebrew_text: הָיָה בָּטֵל מִן הַסֶּלַע, לֹא יֹאמַר לוֹ ״תֵּן לִי סֶלַע״, אֶלָּא נוֹתֵן לוֹ שְׂכָרוֹ כְּפוֹעֵל (בָּטֵל). תְּנַן: נוֹתֵן לוֹ שְׂכָרוֹ כְּפוֹעֵל בָּטֵל.
human_translation: was idle from a sela , he shall not say to Give me a sela Rather, gives him his wage as a laborer. we learned gives him his wage as an idle laborer.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: If one was idle from the rock, he should not say to him "Give me the rock," rather he should give him his wage as a worker (idle). We learned: he should give him his wage as a worker (idle). English translation:

hebrew_text: מַאי כְּפוֹעֵל בָּטֵל? אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: כְּפוֹעֵל בָּטֵל שֶׁל אוֹתָהּ מְלָאכָה, דִּבְטַל מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: What As an idle laborer? Abaye said: as a laborer idle from that labor from which he is idle.
llm_translation: What is considered like the worker is idle? Abaye said: Like the worker is idle in that work, for he has ceased from it.

hebrew_text: אִם יֵשׁ שָׁם בֵּית דִּין – מַתְנֶה בִּפְנֵיהֶם. אִיסּוּר וְרַב סָפְרָא עֲבֻיד עִיסְקָא בַּהֲדֵי הֲדָדֵי. אֲזַל רַב סָפְרָא פְּלַג לֵיהּ בְּלָא דַּעְתֵּיהּ דְּאִיסּוּר בְּאַפֵּי בֵּי תְרֵי. אֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבָּה בַּר רַב הוּנָא, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: זִיל אַיְיתִי תְּלָתָא דִּפְלַגְתְּ קַמַּיְיהוּ, אִי נָמֵי
human_translation: If there are there a court, may stipulate before Issur and Rav Safra formed a joint venture with each other. Rav Safra went and dissolved without Issur’s knowledge in the presence of two came before Rabba bar Rav Huna said to him: Go bring me three before whom you dissolved Alternatively,
llm_translation: If there is a court there - appoint in front of them. Issur and Rav Safra were doing business together. Rav Safra went and divided it without his knowledge, that Issur was at the entrance of the house. He came before Rabba bar Rav Huna, he said to him: Go bring the three that you divided before them, if not.

hebrew_text: תְּרֵי מִגּוֹ תְּלָתָא, וְאִי נָמֵי תְּרֵי סָהֲדִי דִּפְלַגְתְּ בְּאַפֵּי בֵּי תְלָתָא.
human_translation: two of three Or alternatively, two witnesses that you dissolved before of three.
llm_translation: Two from three, and if you say two witnesses who contradict each other in the presence of three.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מְנָא לָךְ הָא? אֲמַר לֵיהּ, דִּתְנַן: אִם יֵשׁ שָׁם בֵּית דִּין – מַתְנֶה בִּפְנֵיהֶם, אֵין שָׁם בֵּית דִּין – בִּפְנֵי מִי יַתְנֶה? שֶׁלּוֹ קוֹדֵם.
human_translation: said to From where do you this said to him: as we learned If there are there a court, may stipulate before if there is no court there, before whom can he stipulate his take precedence,
llm_translation: He said to him: From where do you know this? He said to him, as we learned: If there is a court there - appoint in front of them, if there is no court there - in front of whom should one appoint? His takes precedence.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מִי דָּמֵי?! הָתָם דְּמַפֵּיק מָמוֹנָא מֵהַאי וּמוֹתֵיב לְהַאי בָּעֵינַן בֵּית דִּין, אֲבָל הָכָא דִּידִיה שְׁקַלִי גִּילּוּי מִילְּתָא בְּעָלְמָא הוּא בִּתְרֵי סַגִּי לֵיהּ. תִּדַּע, דִּתְנַן: אַלְמָנָה מוֹכֶרֶת שֶׁלֹּא בִּפְנֵי בֵּית דִּין!
human_translation: said to Is comparable There, where he is removing property from this and giving to that we require a court. But here, he is taking his own mere disclosure the matter two are sufficient for him Know as we learned a widow sells not before a court.
llm_translation: He said to him: Who is similar?! There, where he takes money from this one and gives it to that one, we require a court, but here, where he himself takes a matter into his own hands, it is a general declaration in the world, it is within his rights. Know that we learned: A widow may sell without the presence of a court!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: וְלָאו מִי אִתְּמַר עֲלַהּ ״אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף בַּר מִנְיוֹמֵי אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: אַלְמָנָה אֵינָהּ צְרִיכָה בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל מוּמְחִין, אֲבָל צְרִיכָה בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל הֶדְיוֹטוֹת״?
human_translation: Abaye said to him: But wasn’t it stated with regard to Rav Yosef bar Minyumi says Rav Naḥman says: a widow need not a court of experts, but is required a court of laymen.
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye: And wasn't it stated regarding this, "Rav Yosef son of Minyomei said in the name of Rav Nachman: A widow does not require a court of blemished priests, but she does require a court of laymen"?

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ מְצָאָהּ בָּרֶפֶת – אֵין חַיָּיב בָּהּ. בִּרְשׁוּת הָרַבִּים – חַיָּיב בָּהּ. וְאִם הָיְתָה בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת – לֹא יִטַּמֵּא לָהּ. אִם אָמַר לוֹ אָבִיו ״הִיטַּמֵּא״, אוֹ שֶׁאָמַר לוֹ ״אַל תַּחְזִיר״ – לֹא יִשְׁמַע לוֹ.
human_translation: one found in a stable not obligated it in a public area, obligated it. And if was in a graveyard he may not become impure to it. If his father said to him: Become impure; or where said to him: Do not return he may not listen to
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: If she found it in a public domain - she is not obligated regarding it. If it was in a public domain - she is obligated regarding it. And if it was in a cemetery - she should not become impure for it. If his father said to him, "Become impure," or if he said to him, "Do not return it" - he should not listen to him.

hebrew_text: פָּרַק וְטָעַן, פָּרַק וְטָעַן, אֲפִילּוּ אַרְבָּעָה וַחֲמִישָׁה פְּעָמִים – חַיָּיב, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״עָזֹב תַּעֲזֹב״.
human_translation: one unloaded and loaded unloaded and loaded even four or five times, obligated as it is stated: you shall release it [ azov ta’azov ]
llm_translation: Chapter: He unloaded and reloaded, he unloaded and reloaded, even four or five times - he is liable, as it is stated, "You shall surely unload" (Deuteronomy 22:3).

hebrew_text: הָלַךְ וְיָשַׁב לוֹ, וְאָמַר: ״הוֹאִיל וְעָלֶיךָ מִצְוָה, אִם רְצוֹנְךָ לִפְרוֹק – פְּרוֹק״ – פָּטוּר, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״עִמּוֹ״. אִם הָיָה זָקֵן אוֹ חוֹלֶה – חַיָּיב.
human_translation: went, and sat, and said Since a mitzva upon you if it is your wish to unload unload exempt, as it is stated: with him,” If he was old or infirm, obligated
llm_translation: He went and sat down, and said: "Since a commandment is upon you, if you wish to fulfill it - fulfill it" - exempt, as it is stated: "with him." If he was old or sick - obligated.

hebrew_text: מִצְוָה מִן הַתּוֹרָה לִפְרוֹק אֲבָל לֹא לִטְעוֹן. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: אַף לִטְעוֹן.
human_translation: a mitzva by Torah law to unload but no to load Rabbi Shimon says: even to load
llm_translation: Mitzvah from the Torah to separate but not to join. Rabbi Shimon says: Even to join.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי אוֹמֵר: אִם הָיָה עָלָיו יָתֵר עַל מַשָּׂאוֹ – אֵין זָקוּק לוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״תַּחַת מַשָּׂאוֹ״, מַשּׂאוֹי שֶׁיָּכוֹל לַעֲמוֹד בּוֹ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: If there was upon greater than burden, one need not attend to it, as it is stated: “Under its burden,” a burden that can bear.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei HaGalili says: If there was excess upon his load - it is not necessary for him, as it is stated "under his load," a load that he can stand with.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רָבָא: רֶפֶת שֶׁאָמְרוּ אֵינָהּ מַתְעָה וְאֵינָהּ מְשַׁמֶּרֶת. אֵינָהּ מַתְעָה, מִדְּקָתָנֵי ״אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב בָּהּ״. וְאֵינָהּ מְשַׁמֶּרֶת, מִדְּאִיצְטְרִיךְ לְמִיתְנֵי ״אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב בָּהּ״.
human_translation: Rava said: stable that mentioned neither encourages to stray nor secures does not encourage to stray from that teaches: He is not obligated in its it does not secure from was necessary to teach: He is not obligated in its
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara said Rava: Repet that they said is not mistaken and is not guarding. Is not mistaken, from the teaching of "he is not liable for it." And is not guarding, from the fact that it requires the teaching of "he is not liable for it."

hebrew_text: דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ מְשַׁמֶּרֶת, הַשְׁתָּא מַשְׁכַּח לָהּ אַבָּרַאי מְעַיֵּיל לַהּ לְגַוַּאי, מַשְׁכַּח לַהּ מִגַּוַּאי מִבַּעְיָא? אֶלָּא שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: אֵינָהּ מְשַׁמֶּרֶת, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: As, if it enters your mind secures Now found outside he brings it inside found inside necessary Rather, learn from it not secure learn from it
llm_translation: If your mind is preoccupied, at this moment you forget it; if a person brings it to your attention, you remember it. If you remember it from being brought to your attention, do you remember it from your own mind? Rather, conclude from this: she does not remember it, conclude from this.

hebrew_text: מְצָאָהּ בָּרֶפֶת אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב. אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: וְהוּא שֶׁעוֹמֶדֶת תּוֹךְ לַתְּחוּם. מִכְּלָל, דְּבִרְשׁוּת הָרַבִּים וַאֲפִילּוּ בְּתוֹךְ הַתְּחוּם – נָמֵי חַיָּיב.
human_translation: one found in a stable he is not obligated Rabbi Yitzḥak says: And that where is standing within the limits. by inference that found in a public area and even within the limits, also obligated
llm_translation: Found in the public domain is not liable. Rabbi Yitzchak said: That is when it is standing within the boundary. By inference, in a public domain, even within the boundary - yes, liable.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּמַתְנֵי לַהּ אַסֵּיפָא: בִּרְשׁוּת הָרַבִּים חַיָּיב בָּהּ. אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: וְהוּא שֶׁעוֹמֶדֶת חוּץ לַתְּחוּם. מִכְּלַל, דְּבָרֶפֶת אֲפִילּוּ עוֹמֶדֶת חוּץ לַתְּחוּם – נָמֵי אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב בָּהּ.
human_translation: There are those who teach with regard to the latter clause in a public area, obligated it. Rabbi Yitzḥak says: And that where is standing beyond the limits. by inference that found in the stable, even is standing beyond the limits, he is also not obligated in its
llm_translation: There is one who teaches it as follows: In a public domain, one is liable for it. Rabbi Yitzchak said: And this is when it is standing outside the boundary. By inference, in the case of a breach, even if it is standing outside the boundary - yes, one is not liable for it.

hebrew_text: בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת לֹא יִטַּמֵּא לָהּ. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מִנַּיִן שֶׁאִם אָמַר לוֹ אָבִיו ״הִיטַּמֵּא״, אוֹ שֶׁאָמַר לוֹ ״אַל תַּחְזִיר״ שֶׁלֹּא יִשְׁמַע לוֹ? שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אִישׁ אִמּוֹ וְאָבִיו תִּירָאוּ וְאֶת שַׁבְּתוֹתַי תִּשְׁמֹרוּ אֲנִי ה׳״, כּוּלְּכֶם חַיָּיבִין בִּכְבוֹדִי.
human_translation: And if was in a graveyard he may not become impure to it. the Sages taught: From where that if father said to him: Become impure, or that said to him: Do not return he should not listen to him? as it is stated: “Every man shall fear his mother and his father, and you shall observe My Shabbatot ; I am the Lord” You are all, obligated in My honor.
llm_translation: In the cemetery, she shall not become impure. The Rabbis taught: From where do we know that if her father said to her, "Become impure," or if he said to her, "Do not return," that she should not listen to him? As it is stated: "Every one of you shall revere his mother and his father, and you shall keep My Sabbaths; I am the Lord," all of you are obligated in My honor.

hebrew_text: טַעְמָא דִּכְתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״אֶת שַׁבְּתוֹתַי תִּשְׁמֹרוּ״ הָא לָאו הָכִי הֲוָה אָמֵינָא (צָיְיתָא) [נֵיצִית] לֵיהּ? וְאַמַּאי? הַאי עֲשֵׂה, וְהַאי לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה וַעֲשֵׂה – וְלָא אָתֵי עֲשֵׂה וְדָחֵי אֶת לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה וַעֲשֵׂה!
human_translation: The reason because the Merciful One writes: “You shall observe My Shabbatot ; but it were not so, I would say must obey him. But why? This a positive mitzva, and that a prohibition: and a positive mitzva: and a positive mitzva does not come and override a prohibition and a positive mitzva.
llm_translation: Reason for which wrote the Merciful One "My Sabbaths you shall keep" this not this was I saying (you have left) you have abandoned to him? And why? This is a positive commandment, and this is a negative commandment and a positive commandment – and the positive commandment does not come and push away the negative commandment and the positive commandment!

hebrew_text: אִיצְטְרִיךְ. סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא: הוֹאִיל וְהוּקַּשׁ כִּיבּוּד אָב וָאֵם לִכְבוֹדוֹ שֶׁל מָקוֹם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר כָּאן ״כַּבֵּד אֶת אָבִיךָ וְאֶת אִמֶּךָ״, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן ״כַּבֵּד אֶת ה׳ מֵהוֹנֶךָ״, הִלְכָּךְ לֵצִיית לֵיהּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּלָא לִשְׁמַע לֵיהּ.
human_translation: was necessary, enter your mind to say: Since honoring one’s father and mother is equated to the honor of the Omnipresent, as it is stated here: “Honor your father and your mother” and it is stated elsewhere: “Honor the Lord with your wealth” therefore, obey his teaches us that not to listen to him.
llm_translation: It is necessary. The reason of your opinion I say: Since the honor of the father and mother is equated to the honor of the Omnipresent, as it is stated here "Honor your father and your mother," and it is stated elsewhere "Honor the Lord from your wealth," therefore, to obey Him, it is heard for us that one should not listen to him.

hebrew_text: מִצְוָה מִן הַתּוֹרָה לִפְרוֹק אֲבָל לֹא לִטְעוֹן. מַאי אֲבָל לֹא לִטְעוֹן? אִילֵימָא אֲבָל לֹא לִטְעוֹן כְּלָל, מַאי שְׁנָא פְּרִיקָה, דִּכְתִיב ״עָזֹב תַּעֲזֹב עִמּוֹ״, טְעִינָה נָמֵי הָכְתִיב ״הָקֵם תָּקִים עִמּוֹ״!
human_translation: a mitzva by Torah law to unload but no to load What But no to load If we say But no to load at all; what is different unloading, with regard to which it is written: “You shall release it with him” loading as well, isn’t it written: “You shall lift them with him”
llm_translation: Commandment from the Torah to separate but not to join. What is meant by "but not to join"? If you say "but not to join" in general, what is different about separation, as it is written, "you shall surely let him go free," and also about joining, as it is written, "you shall surely uphold him"?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: מִצְוָה מִן הַתּוֹרָה לִפְרוֹק בְּחִנָּם, וְלֹא לִטְעוֹן בְּחִנָּם אֶלָּא בְּשָׂכָר. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: אַף לִטְעוֹן בְּחִנָּם. תְּנֵינָא לְהָא דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: פְּרִיקָה בְּחִנָּם, טְעִינָה בְּשָׂכָר. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: זוֹ וָזוֹ בְּחִנָּם.
human_translation: Rather, a mitzva by Torah law to unload for free, but no to load for free; rather, with remuneration. Rabbi Shimon says: also to load for free. We learn that which the Sages taught Unloading for free, loading with remuneration. Rabbi Shimon said: this and that for free.
llm_translation: Rather: commandment from the Torah to unload for free, and not to load for free but for payment. Rabbi Shimon says: even to load for free. We learned in a Mishnah that the Rabbis taught: unloading for free, loading for payment. Rabbi Shimon says: both this and that for free.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמַיְיהוּ דְּרַבָּנַן? דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ כְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן, לִכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא טְעִינָה וְלָא בָּעֵי פְּרִיקָה. וַאֲנָא אָמֵינָא: וּמָה טְעִינָה דְּלֵית בַּהּ צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים וְלֵיכָּא חֶסְרוֹן כִּיס – חַיָּיב, פְּרִיקָה דְּאִית בָּהּ צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים וְחֶסְרוֹן כִּיס, לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?! אֶלָּא לְמַאי הִלְכְתָא כַּתְבֵיהּ רַחֲמָנָא? לוֹמַר לָךְ: פְּרִיקָה בְּחִנָּם, טְעִינָה בְּשָׂכָר.
human_translation: What is the reason of the Rabbis that if it enters your mind in accordance with Rabbi Shimon, let the Merciful One write loading, and need not unloading, and I would say: Just as loading, where there is no suffering of animals and there is no monetary loss obligated unloading, where there is suffering of animals and there is monetary loss not all the more so Rather, with regard to what halakha the Merciful One write to tell you: unloading for free, but loading with remuneration.
llm_translation: What is the reason of the Rabbis? For if your opinion is like that of Rabbi Shimon, the Merciful One should have written "loading" and not "unloading." But I say: And what is loading that does not involve distress to living creatures and does not cause financial loss - one is liable. Unloading, which involves distress to living creatures and financial loss, how much more so?! Rather, why did the Merciful One write its law as unloading? To tell you: Unloading is gratuitous, loading is for payment.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן מַאי טַעְמָא? מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא מְסַיְּימִי קְרָאֵי.
human_translation: And Rabbi Shimon, what is the reason because the verses are not defined,
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon, what is the reason? Because he does not conclude the verses.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן אַמַּאי לָא מְסַיְּימִי קְרָאֵי? הָכָא כְּתִיב ״רוֹבֵץ תַּחַת מַשָּׂאוֹ״, הָתָם כְּתִיב ״נוֹפְלִין בַּדֶּרֶךְ״, דִּרְמוּ אִינְהוּ וּטְעוּנַיְיהוּ בְּאוֹרְחָא מַשְׁמַע. וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן: ״נוֹפְלִין בַּדֶּרֶךְ״ אִינְהוּ וּטְעוּנַיְיהוּ עִלָּוַיְיהוּ מַשְׁמַע.
human_translation: And the Rabbis Why the verses are not defined? Here it is written: “Collapsed under its burden” there it is written: “Fallen down by the way” indicating and their burdens are on the way And Rabbi Shimon “fallen down by the way” indicating with their burdens upon them,
llm_translation: The sages said: Why do they not conclude the verses? Here it is written, "He crouches, he lies down like a lion," there it is written, "They have fallen by the wayside," for they are lying and their burdens are heard on the road. And Rabbi Shimon said: "They have fallen by the wayside," they and their burdens on them are heard above.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא:
human_translation: Rava says:
llm_translation: Rava said:

hebrew_text: מִדִּבְרֵי שְׁנֵיהֶם נִלְמַד צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא. וַאֲפִילּוּ רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן לָא קָאָמַר, אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא מְסַיְּימִי קְרָאֵי. אֲבָל מְסַיְּימִי קְרָאֵי דָּרְשִׁינַן קַל וָחוֹמֶר, מִשּׁוּם מַאי? לָאו מִשּׁוּם צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דָּרְשִׁינַן?
human_translation: From the statements of both of learned suffering to animals by Torah law. As even Rabbi Shimon says only because the verses are not defined; but verses defined, we learned a fortiori Due to what What, is it not due to suffering of animals, we learned
llm_translation: From the words of both of them, we learn the pain of living creatures from the Torah. And even Rabbi Shimon did not say this, but because we do not conclude with verses. But when we conclude with verses, we interpret them with a fortiori argument, why? Is it not because we do not interpret for the pain of living creatures?

hebrew_text: דִּלְמָא מִשּׁוּם דְּאִיכָּא חֶסְרוֹן כִּיס. וְהָכִי קָאָמַר: וּמָה טְעִינָה דְּלֵית בַּהּ חֶסְרוֹן כִּיס – חַיָּיב, פְּרִיקָה דְּאִית בַּהּ חֶסְרוֹן כִּיס, לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?!
human_translation: Perhaps due to that there is monetary loss and this is what are saying: If loading, where there is no monetary loss, obligated unloading, where there is monetary loss, not all the more so
llm_translation: Perhaps because there is a lack of a purse. And thus he said: And what about a load that does not have a lack of a purse - is liable, a detachment that has a lack of a purse, all the more so?!

hebrew_text: וּטְעִינָה אֵין בָּהּ חֶסְרוֹן כִּיס? מִי לָא עָסְקִינַן דְּאַדְּהָכִי וְהָכִי בָּטֵיל מִשּׁוּקֵיהּ, אִי נָמֵי אָתוּ גַּנָּבֵי וְשָׁקְלִי כֹּל מָה דְּאִיכָּא בַּהֲדֵיהּ?
human_translation: But is there no monetary loss in loading? Are we not dealing where in the meanwhile, prevented from his marketplace alternatively, thieves come and take all that is there with him?
llm_translation: And a load, there is no deficiency in it? Who are we dealing with that thus and thus it is nullified from its market value, or perhaps thieves came and took everything that was in it?

hebrew_text: תֵּדַע דְּצַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, דְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי אוֹמֵר: אִם הָיָה עָלָיו יָתֵר [עַל] מַשָּׂאוֹ – אֵין זָקוּק לוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״תַּחַת מַשָּׂאוֹ״, מַשּׂאוֹי שֶׁיָּכוֹל לַעֲמוֹד בּוֹ. לָאו מִכְּלָל דְּתַנָּא קַמָּא סָבַר זָקוּק לוֹ? מַאי טַעְמָא? לָאו מִשּׁוּם דְּצַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא?
human_translation: Know that suffering to animals by Torah law, as it is taught the latter clause Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: If there was upon greater than burden, one need not attend to it, as it is stated: “Under its burden” a burden that can bear; not by inference that the first tanna holds he must attend to it What is the reason not due to that suffering to animals by Torah law?
llm_translation: You shall know the distress of living creatures from the Torah, as it is taught in the conclusion: Rabbi Yosei the Galilean says: If there was an excess burden upon him - he is not required, as it is said "under his burden," a burden that he can bear. Is it not from the fact that the first Tanna holds that he is required? What is the reason? Is it not because of the distress of living creatures from the Torah?

hebrew_text: דִּלְמָא ״בְּתַחַת מַשָּׂאוֹ״ פְּלִיגִי, דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי סָבַר: דָּרְשִׁינַן ״תַּחַת מַשָּׂאוֹ״, מַשּׂאוֹי שֶׁיָּכוֹל לַעֲמוֹד בּוֹ, וְרַבָּנַן סָבְרִי: לָא דָּרְשִׁינַן ״תַּחַת מַשָּׂאוֹ״.
human_translation: Perhaps “under its burden” disagree, as Rabbi Yosei holds that we interpret “under its burden” A burden that can bear. And the Rabbis hold we do not interpret “under its burden”
llm_translation: Perhaps "under his burden" they dispute, for Rabbi Yosei holds: we interpret "under his burden" as a burden that one can stand under, and the Rabbis hold: we do not interpret "under his burden."

hebrew_text: תֵּדַע דְּצַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים לָאו דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, דְּקָתָנֵי רֵישָׁא: הָלַךְ וְיָשַׁב לוֹ וְאָמַר לוֹ הוֹאִיל וְעָלֶיךָ מִצְוָה לִפְרוֹק, פְּרוֹק פָּטוּר, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר עִמּוֹ. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, מָה לִי אִיתֵיהּ לְמָרֵיהּ בַּהֲדֵיהּ, וּמָה לִי כִּי לֵיתֵיהּ לְמָרֵיהּ בַּהֲדֵיהּ?
human_translation: Know that suffering to animals not by Torah law, as it is taught the former clause went, and sat, and said Since a mitzva upon you to unload unload exempt, as it is stated: with him” And if it enters your mind that suffering to animals by Torah law, what to me its owner is with and what to me its owner is not with
llm_translation: You should know that the pain of living creatures is not from the Torah, as it is taught in the beginning: "If one goes and sits down to eat and the owner says to him, 'Please, it is incumbent upon you to remove the burden,' if he removes it, he is exempt, as it is said, 'with him.' And if, God forbid, your mind is concerned about the pain of living creatures from the Torah, what is it to me if its owner is with it or not with it? What is it to me if its owner is with it or not with it?"

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, מִי סָבְרַתְּ פָּטוּר פָּטוּר לִגְמָרֵי? וְדִלְמָא פָּטוּר בְּחִנָּם, וְחַיָּיב בְּשָׂכָר. וְהָכִי קָאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא: כִּי אִיתֵיהּ לְמָרֵיהּ בַּהֲדֵיהּ – עֲבֵד גַּבֵּיהּ בְּחִנָּם, וְכִי לֵיתֵיהּ לְמָרֵיהּ בַּהֲדֵיהּ – עֲבֵד גַּבֵּיהּ בְּשָׂכָר, וּלְעוֹלָם צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא.
human_translation: Actually, suffering to animals by Torah law. do you maintain exempt completely exempt? Perhaps exempt for free, but obligated for remuneration; and this the Merciful One said: its owner is with perform with him for free; and its owner is not with perform for him for remuneration. And actually, suffering to animals by Torah law.
llm_translation: Forever distress of owners of animals from the Torah, who thinks exempt exempt completely? And perhaps exempt for free, and obligated for payment. And thus says the Merciful One: If his master is with him – he works for him for free, and if his master is not with him – he works for him for payment, and forever distress of owners of animals from the Torah.

hebrew_text: (סִימַן בֶּהֱמַת, בֶּהֱמַת, אוֹהֵב, שׂוֹנֵא, רַבְצָן).
human_translation: a mnemonic Animal of; animal of; friend; enemy; collapser.
llm_translation: Chapter: Behemat (Livestock) Behemat, Behemat, Oheb, Soneh, Ravtsan.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ: בֶּהֱמַת גּוֹי מִטַּפֵּל בָּהּ כְּבֶהֱמַת יִשְׂרָאֵל. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא – מִשּׁוּם הָכִי מִטַּפֵּל בָּהּ כְּבֶהֱמַת יִשְׂרָאֵל, אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים לָאו דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, אַמַּאי מִטַּפֵּל בָּהּ כְּבֶהֱמַת יִשְׂרָאֵל? הָתָם מִשּׁוּם אֵיבָה.
human_translation: Let us say supports the animal of a gentile he tends to it as the animal of a Jew. Granted, if you say suffering to animals by Torah law, due to that he tends to it as the animal of a Jew. But if you say suffering to animals not by Torah law, why does he tend to it as the animal of a Jew? There due to enmity
llm_translation: Let us say it assists him: An animal of a gentile, when one is involved with it, is like an animal of an Israelite. If you say it is because of the pain of living creatures, which is from the Torah - therefore one is involved with it like an animal of an Israelite. But if you say the pain of living creatures is not from the Torah, why is one involved with it like an animal of an Israelite? There, it is because of enmity.

hebrew_text: הָכִי נָמֵי מִסְתַּבְּרָא, דְּקָתָנֵי: אִם הָיְתָה טְעוּנָה יֵין נֶסֶךְ – אֵין זָקוּק לָהּ. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא לָאו דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא – מִשּׁוּם הָכִי אֵין זָקוּק לָהּ, אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא – אַמַּאי אֵין זָקוּק לָהּ? הָכִי קָאָמַר: וּלְהַטְעִינָהּ יֵין נֶסֶךְ אֵין זָקוּק לָהּ.
human_translation: So too, it is reasonable as it is taught If was loaded wine a libation does not attend to it. Granted, if you say not by Torah law, due to that that he does not attend to it. But if you say by Torah law, why does he not attend to it; this is saying: And to load wine a libation he does not attend to it.
llm_translation: Thus it was stated: for it was taught: if it was intended for libation wine - it is not required for it. If you say it is not from the Torah - therefore it is not required for it, but if you say it is from the Torah - why is it not required for it? Thus he said: and to load it with libation wine is not required for it.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: בֶּהֱמַת גּוֹי וּמַשּׂאוֹי יִשְׂרָאֵל, ״וְחָדַלְתָּ״. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, אַמַּאי ״וְחָדַלְתָּ״? ״עָזֹב תַּעֲזֹב״ מִבְּעֵי לֵיהּ! לְעוֹלָם צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, הָתָם בִּטְעִינָה.
human_translation: Come hear the animal of a gentile the burden of a Jew, you shall forgo if you say suffering to animals by Torah law, why “You shall forgo”? should have “You shall release it Actually, suffering to animals by Torah law, there of loading,
llm_translation: Come and hear: Regarding the livestock of a gentile and its burden, "you shall surely release." And if you say that the pain of living creatures is from the Torah, why then "you shall surely release" is needed? It is necessary for abandonment! Indeed, the pain of living creatures is always from the Torah, there it is in the case of loading.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, אֵימָא סֵיפָא: בֶּהֱמַת יִשְׂרָאֵל וּמַשּׂאוֹי גּוֹי ״עָזֹב תַּעֲזֹב״. וְאִי בִּטְעִינָה, אַמַּאי ״עָזֹב תַּעֲזֹב״? מִשּׁוּם צַעֲרָא דְּיִשְׂרָאֵל.
human_translation: If so, say the latter clause the animal of a Jew the burden of a gentile, “You shall release it.” And if of loading, why “You shall release it”? because in that case, suffering of the Jew,
llm_translation: If so, say the latter part: regarding an Israelite's animal and a non-Jew's load, "You shall surely help." And if it is about loading, why "You shall surely help"? Because of the pain of an Israelite.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, אֲפִילּוּ רֵישָׁא נָמֵי! רֵישָׁא בְּחַמָּר גּוֹי סֵיפָא בְּחַמָּר יִשְׂרָאֵל. מַאי פָּסְקַתְּ? סְתָמָא דְּמִלְּתָא אִינִישׁ בָּתַר חֲמָרֵיהּ אָזֵיל.
human_translation: If so, even first clause. the first clause with regard to a gentile donkey driver, the latter clause with regard to a Jewish donkey driver what you definitive assertion typical of matters a person follows his donkey.
llm_translation: Thus, even the beginning is also so! The beginning with the donkey, the end with the donkey of Israel. What is the conclusion? A person usually follows his donkeys.

hebrew_text: וְהָא ״וְחָדַלְתָּ״ וְ״עָזֹב תַּעֲזֹב״ בִּפְרִיקָה הוּא דִּכְתִיבִי!
human_translation: But isn’t it with regard to unloading that “You shall forgo and: “You shall release it,” are written?
llm_translation: And this, "and you shall cease" and "you shall surely abandon" in the context of a divorce document, as it is written!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָא מַנִּי? רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי הִיא, דְּאָמַר: צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים לָאו דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא.
human_translation: he said to him: whose is this It is Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who says suffering to animals not by Torah law.
llm_translation: He said to him: Is this Mana? It is Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, who said: The suffering of living creatures is not from the Torah.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: אוֹהֵב לִפְרוֹק וְשׂוֹנֵא לִטְעוֹן – מִצְוָה בְּשׂוֹנֵא, כְּדֵי לָכוֹף אֶת יִצְרוֹ. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, הָא עֲדִיף לֵיהּ? אֲפִילּוּ הָכִי, כְּדֵי לָכוֹף אֶת יִצְרוֹ עָדִיף.
human_translation: Come hear a friend to unload and an enemy to load the mitzva to the enemy, in order to subjugate inclination. And if it enters your mind suffering to animals by Torah law, that is preferable for him. even so, in order to subjugate his inclination is preferable.
llm_translation: Come and hear: One who loves to uproot and hates to plant - it is a commandment to hate, in order to subdue his inclination. And if it enters your mind, the pain of living creatures from the Torah, is it not preferable? Even so, in order to subdue his inclination, it is preferable.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: שׂוֹנֵא שֶׁאָמְרוּ – שׂוֹנֵא יִשְׂרָאֵל וְלֹא שׂוֹנֵא אוּמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם. אִי אָמְרַתְּ צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, מָה לִי שׂוֹנֵא יִשְׂרָאֵל וּמָה לִי שׂוֹנֵא אוּמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם?
human_translation: Come hear The enemy which they stated a Jewish enemy and not a gentile enemy. If you say suffering to animals by Torah law, what to me a Jewish enemy and what to me a gentile enemy?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Come and hear: One who hates Israel, it is said, hates the Israelites but does not hate the nations of the world. If you say this refers to causing distress to living creatures, which is forbidden by Torah law, what difference does it make to me whether one hates the Israelites or hates the nations of the world?

hebrew_text: מִי סָבְרַתְּ אַשּׂוֹנֵא דִקְרָא קָאֵי? אַשּׂוֹנֵא דְמַתְנִיתִין קָאֵי.
human_translation: Do you maintain applies to the enemy in the verse: It applies to the enemy in the baraita
llm_translation: Who holds the view of the verse? The view of the Mishnah holds.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע:
human_translation: Come hear
llm_translation: Come and hear:

hebrew_text: ״רֹבֵץ״ וְלֹא רַבְצָן, ״רֹבֵץ״ וְלֹא עוֹמֵד. ״תַּחַת מַשָּׂאוֹ״ וְלֹא מְפוֹרָק. ״תַּחַת מַשָּׂאוֹ״, מַשּׂאוֹי שֶׁיָּכוֹל לַעֲמוֹד בּוֹ. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, מָה לִי רוֹבֵץ, וּמָה לִי רַבְצָן, וּמָה לִי עוֹמֵד!
human_translation: “collapsed,” but not collapser; “collapsed,” but not standing; “under its burden,” but not unloaded; “under its burden,” a burden that can bear. And if you say suffering to animals by Torah law, what to me collapsed; and what to me collapser; and what to me standing?
llm_translation: "Robetz" and not "Ravtsan," "Robetz" and not "Omed." "Tachat massa'o" and not "Meforak." "Tachat massa'o," a burden that one can stand on. And if you say the pain of living creatures is from the Torah, why do I need "Robetz," why do I need "Ravtsan," why do I need "Omed"!

hebrew_text: הָא מַנִּי? רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי הִיא, דְּאָמַר צַעַר בַּעֲלֵי חַיִּים דְּרַבָּנַן.
human_translation: whose is this It is Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who says suffering to animals is by rabbinic law,
llm_translation: The text reads: "Ha mani? Rabbi Yosei HaGalili hi, de'amar tza'ar ba'alei chayim d'rabbannan." Translation: "Who is the Tanna? It is Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, as he said the pain of living creatures is forbidden by the Rabbis."

hebrew_text: הָכִי נָמֵי מִסְתַּבְּרָא, דְּקָתָנֵי: ״תַּחַת מַשָּׂאוֹ״ – מַשּׂאוֹי שֶׁיָּכוֹל לַעֲמוֹד בּוֹ, מַאן שָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ דְּאִית לֵיהּ הַאי סְבָרָא – רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: So too, it is reasonable as it is taught “Under its burden” a burden that can bear. whom did you hear that he holds that reasoning? Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Learn from it
llm_translation: Thus it was stated: for it was taught: "under his burden" - his burden that he can bear, who heard this reasoning? - Rabbi Yosei the Galilean, learn from it.

hebrew_text: וּמִי מָצֵית מוֹקְמַתְּ לַהּ כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי? וְהָא קָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: ״תַּחַת מַשָּׂאוֹ״ – וְלֹא מְפוֹרָק. מַאי ״לֹא מְפוֹרָק״? אִילֵּימָא לֹא מְפוֹרָק כְּלָל, הָא כְּתִיב: ״הָקֵם תָּקִים עִמּוֹ״! אֶלָּא פְּשִׁיטָא: ״לֹא מְפוֹרָק״ בְּחִנָּם, אֶלָּא בְּשָׂכָר, מַאן שָׁמְעַתְּ לֵיהּ דְּאִית לֵיהּ הַאי סְבָרָא – רַבָּנַן! לְעוֹלָם רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הַגְּלִילִי הִיא, וּבִטְעִינָה סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבָּנַן.
human_translation: And can you establish in accordance with Rabbi Yosei HaGelili? But isn’t it taught the latter clause “Under its burden,” but not unloaded? What Not unloaded? If we say unloaded no at all, isn’t it written “You shall lift them with him” Rather, obvious unloaded, not for free; rather, for remuneration. whom did you hear that he holds that reasoning? the Rabbis. Actually, is Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, and in loading he holds in accordance with the Rabbis.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And who found a basis for her like Rabbi Yosei the Galilean? And this is what is taught in the latter part: "Under his burden" - and not separated. What is meant by "not separated"? If you say not separated at all, but it is written: "He shall surely make it good with him"! Rather, it is obvious: "Not separated" for free, but for payment. Who heard that he has this opinion? - The Rabbis! Indeed, Rabbi Yosei the Galilean is the one, and in loading, he holds the opinion of the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״כִּי תִרְאֶה״ – יָכוֹל אֲפִילּוּ מֵרָחוֹק, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כִּי תִפְגַּע״. אִי ״כִּי תִפְגַּע״, יָכוֹל פְּגִיעָה מַמָּשׁ? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״כִּי תִרְאֶה״. וְאֵיזוֹ הִיא רְאִיָּיה שֶׁיֵּשׁ בָּהּ פְּגִיעָה – שִׁיעֲרוּ חֲכָמִים אֶחָד מִשֶּׁבַע וּמֶחֱצָה בְּמִיל, וְזֶה הוּא רִיס.
human_translation: The Sages taught “If you see might even from a distance; the verse states: “If you encounter If “If you encounter,” might an actual encounter; the verse states: “If you see.” And what is seeing in which there is encounter? The Sages calculated one of seven and a half of a mil , and that is a ris .
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "When you see" - one might think even from a distance, therefore the verse states: "When you encounter." If "when you encounter," one might think it refers to actual physical contact, therefore the verse states: "When you see." And what is the type of seeing that involves contact? The Sages estimated one hairbreadth out of seven and a half in a mil, and this is the eyelash.

hebrew_text: תָּנָא: וּמִדַּדֶּה עִמּוֹ עַד פַּרְסָה. אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה: וְנוֹטֵל שָׂכָר.
human_translation: taught one walks with it up to one parasang [ parsa ] Rabba bar bar Ḥana says: And he takes remuneration
llm_translation: Mishna: And measure with him until the elbow. Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: And he takes payment.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֲבֵדָתוֹ וַאֲבֵדַת אָבִיו – אֲבֵדָתוֹ קוֹדֶמֶת. אֲבֵדָתוֹ וַאֲבֵדַת רַבּוֹ – שֶׁלּוֹ קוֹדֵם.
human_translation: his lost item and his father’s lost item, his lost item takes precedence. his lost item and his teacher’s lost item, his takes precedence.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "His lost object and the lost object of his father - his own lost object takes precedence. His lost object and the lost object of his teacher - his own takes precedence."

hebrew_text: אֲבֵדַת אָבִיו וַאֲבֵדַת רַבּוֹ – שֶׁל רַבּוֹ קוֹדֶמֶת, שֶׁאָבִיו הֱבִיאוֹ לָעוֹלָם הַזֶּה, וְרַבּוֹ שֶׁלִּמְּדוֹ חׇכְמָה מְבִיאוֹ לְחַיֵּי הָעוֹלָם הַבָּא. וְאִם אָבִיו חָכָם – שֶׁל אָבִיו קוֹדֶמֶת.
human_translation: his father’s lost item and his teacher’s lost item, his teacher’s takes precedence, as his father brought him into this world, and his teacher, who taught him wisdom brings him to life in the World-to-Come. And if his father is scholar, his father’s takes precedence.
llm_translation: The loss of his father and the loss of his teacher - the loss of his teacher takes precedence, because his father brought him into this world, and his teacher who taught him wisdom brings him to the life of the world to come. And if his father is wise - the loss of his father takes precedence.

hebrew_text: הָיָה אָבִיו וְרַבּוֹ נוֹשְׂאִין מַשּׂאוֹי – מַנִּיחַ אֶת שֶׁל רַבּוֹ, וְאַחַר כָּךְ מַנִּיחַ אֶת שֶׁל אָבִיו. הָיָה אָבִיו וְרַבּוֹ בְּבֵית הַשְּׁבִי – פּוֹדֶה אֶת רַבּוֹ, וְאַחַר כָּךְ פּוֹדֶה אֶת אָבִיו. וְאִם אָבִיו חָכָם – פּוֹדֶה אֶת אָבִיו, וְאַחַר כָּךְ פּוֹדֶה אֶת רַבּוֹ.
human_translation: his father and his teacher were carrying a burden places his teacher’s and thereafter places his father’s his father and his teacher were in captivity, redeems his teacher and thereafter redeems his father. And if his father is scholar, redeems his father and thereafter redeems his teacher.
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "If his father and his teacher are carrying a burden, he should first assist his teacher and then assist his father. If his father and his teacher are in captivity, he should first redeem his teacher and then redeem his father. And if his father is a scholar, he should first redeem his father and then redeem his teacher."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי? אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב, אָמַר קְרָא: ״אֶפֶס כִּי לֹא יִהְיֶה בְּךָ אֶבְיוֹן״, שֶׁלְּךָ קוֹדֵם לְשֶׁל כׇּל אָדָם.
human_translation: From where are these matters Rav Yehuda says Rav says the verse states: “Only so that there shall be no needy among you” your takes precedence of any person.
llm_translation: Gemara: What are these words teaching us? Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav, who said based on a verse: "For there will never cease to be poor in the land" - your poor take precedence over the poor of all people.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: כׇּל הַמְקַיֵּים בְּעַצְמוֹ כָּךְ, סוֹף בָּא לִידֵי כָּךְ.
human_translation: And Rav Yehuda says Rav says: anyone who fulfills this with regard to his ultimately comes to that
llm_translation: And Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: Anyone who establishes himself in such a way, in the end comes to this.

hebrew_text: הָיָה אָבִיו וְרַבּוֹ נוֹשְׂאִין מַשּׂאוֹי וְכוּ׳. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: רַבּוֹ שֶׁאָמְרוּ רַבּוֹ שֶׁלִּמְּדוֹ חׇכְמָה, וְלֹא רַבּוֹ שֶׁלִּמְּדוֹ מִקְרָא וּמִשְׁנָה, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: כֹּל שֶׁרוֹב חׇכְמָתוֹ הֵימֶנּוּ. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: אֲפִילּוּ לֹא הֵאִיר עֵינָיו אֶלָּא בְּמִשְׁנָה אַחַת, זֶה הוּא רַבּוֹ.
human_translation: his father and his teacher were carrying a burden, The Sages taught His teacher, whom stated his teacher who taught him wisdom, and not his teacher who taught him Bible or Mishna; the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: any from whom most of his knowledge, Rabbi Yosei says: Even if he enlightened him in only one mishna, that is his teacher.
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "His father and his teacher used to carry his burden, etc." The Sages taught: His teacher who taught him wisdom, but not his teacher who taught him Scripture and Mishnah, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: Anyone whose wisdom exceeds his piety. Rabbi Yosei says: Even if his eyes only shone upon one Mishnah, he is considered his teacher.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: כְּגוֹן רַב סְחוֹרָה, דְּאַסְבְּרַן זוּהֲמָא לִיסְטְרוֹן. שְׁמוּאֵל קְרַע מָאנֵיהּ עֲלֵיהּ הָהוּא מֵרַבָּנַן דְּאַסְבְּרֵיהּ ״אֶחָד יוֹרֵד לְאַמַּת הַשֶּׁחִי וְאֶחָד פּוֹתֵחַ כֵּיוָן״.
human_translation: Rava said: For example, Rav Seḥora as he explained to me zuhama listeron , Shmuel rent his garment over one of the Sages who explained to him One up to his armpit down And one which opened directly.
llm_translation: Rava said: For example, Rav Sechora, who considered gold as dust. Shmuel tore his cloak in front of that certain Sage who held the opinion, "One descends to the depth of the pit, and one opens the mouth."

hebrew_text: אָמַר עוּלָּא: תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים שֶׁבְּבָבֶל, עוֹמְדִין זֶה מִפְּנֵי זֶה, וְקוֹרְעִין זֶה עַל זֶה. וּלְעִנְיַן אֲבֵדָה בִּמְקוֹם אָבִיו, אֵינָן חוֹזְרִין אֶלָּא לְרַבּוֹ מוּבְהָק.
human_translation: Ulla says: The Torah scholars who are in Babylonia rise before one another and rend over one another’s But with regard to a lost item in where one’s father he returns only to his preeminent teacher
llm_translation: Ula said: The disciples of the sages in Babylonia stand facing one another and tear one another. And regarding a lost object found in the place of one's father, they only return it to their clearly recognized teacher.

hebrew_text: קָבָעֵי מִינֵּיהּ רַב חִסְדָּא מֵרַב הוּנָא: תַּלְמִיד וְצָרִיךְ לוֹ רַבּוֹ, מַאי? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: חִסְדָּא חִסְדָּא, לָא צְרִיכְנָא לָךְ, אַתְּ צְרִיכַתְּ לִי עַד אַרְבְּעִין שְׁנִין. אִיקְּפַדוּ אַהֲדָדֵי וְלָא עָיְילִי לְגַבֵּי הֲדָדֵי. יְתֵיב רַב חִיסְדָּא אַרְבְּעִין תַּעֲנִיָּתָא, מִשּׁוּם דַּחֲלַשׁ דַּעְתֵּיהּ דְּרַב הוּנָא. יָתֵיב רַב הוּנָא אַרְבְּעִין תַּעֲנִיָּתָא, מִשּׁוּם דְּחַשְׁדֵיהּ לְרַב חִסְדָּא.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda raised a dilemma before Rav Huna: a student, and his teacher needs him what said to him: Ḥisda, Ḥisda, I do not need you. you need me until forty years angry with each other and each did not enter to other. Rav Ḥisda observed forty fasts due to that Rav Huna was offended, Rav Huna observed forty fasts due to that he suspected Rav Ḥisda
llm_translation: The students of Rab Ḥisdah established from Rab Huna: A student and he needs his teacher, what? He said to him: "Ḥisdah, Ḥisdah, we do not need you, you need me for forty years." They were angry at each other but did not become angry in front of each other. Rab Ḥisdah fasted for forty days because he was concerned about the opinion of Rab Huna. Rab Huna also fasted for forty days because he suspected Rab Ḥisdah.

hebrew_text: אִיתְּמַר: רַב יִצְחָק בַּר יוֹסֵף אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה. רַב אַחָא בַּר רַב הוּנָא אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי.
human_translation: It was stated Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef Rabbi Yoḥanan says: halakha in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, Rav Aḥa bar Rav Huna Rav Sheshet says: halakha in accordance with Rabbi Yosei,
llm_translation: It was stated: Rav Yitzchak son of Yosef said Rabbi Yochanan: The halakha is like Rabbi Yehuda. Rav Acha son of Rav Huna said Rav Sheshet: The halakha is like Rabbi Yosei.

hebrew_text: וּמִי אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן הָכִי? וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הֲלָכָה כִּסְתַם מִשְׁנָה, וּתְנַן: רַבּוֹ שֶׁלִּמְּדוֹ חׇכְמָה. מַאי ״חׇכְמָה״? רוֹב חׇכְמָתוֹ.
human_translation: And did Rabbi Yoḥanan say that? But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: halakha in accordance with an unattributed mishna; and we learned His teacher, who taught him wisdom What wisdom the majority of his wisdom.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And who said it, Rabbi Yochanan like this? And Rabbi Yochanan said: The halacha is like the anonymous Mishnah, and we learned: his teacher who taught him wisdom. What is 'wisdom'? Most of his wisdom."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הָעוֹסְקִין בְּמִקְרָא – מִדָּה וְאֵינָהּ מִדָּה, בַּמִּשְׁנָה – מִדָּה וְנוֹטְלִין עָלֶיהָ שָׂכָר, בַּתַּלְמוּד – אֵין לָךְ מִדָּה גְּדוֹלָה מִזּוֹ, וּלְעוֹלָם הֱוֵי רָץ לַמִּשְׁנָה יוֹתֵר מִן הַתַּלְמוּד.
human_translation: The Sages taught who engage in Bible, a virtue but not virtue. in Mishna, a virtue and they receive reward for its in Talmud, you have no virtue greater than that. And always pursue of Mishna more than the Talmud.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: Those who engage in Scripture – it is a measure but not a full measure; in Mishnah – it is a measure and one receives reward for it; in Talmud – there is no greater measure than this, and one should always be more diligent in Mishnah than in Talmud.

hebrew_text: הָא גוּפַאּ קַשְׁיָא. אָמְרַתְּ בַּתַּלְמוּד אֵין לְךָ מִדָּה גְּדוֹלָה מִזּוֹ, וַהֲדַר אָמְרַתְּ: וּלְעוֹלָם הֱוֵי רָץ לַמִּשְׁנָה יוֹתֵר מִן הַתַּלְמוּד! אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן:
human_translation: This itself difficult, You said: in Talmud, you have no virtue greater than that. And then you said: And always pursue of Mishna more than the Talmud. Rabbi Yoḥanan says:
llm_translation: This is a difficult matter. You said in the study hall, "You have no greater quality than this," and then you said, "And always prioritize Mishnah over study!" Rabbi Yochanan said:

hebrew_text: בִּימֵי רַבִּי נִשְׁנֵית מִשְׁנָה זוֹ, שְׁבַקוּ כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא מַתְנִיתִין וַאֲזַלוּ בָּתַר תַּלְמוּדָא, הֲדַר דְּרַשׁ לְהוּ: וּלְעוֹלָם הֱוֵי רָץ לַמִּשְׁנָה יוֹתֵר מִן הַתַּלְמוּד.
human_translation: during the era of Rabbi this baraita was taught. everyone abandoned Mishna and pursued the Talmud. then taught And always pursue of Mishna more than the Talmud,
llm_translation: In the days of Rabbi, this Mishnah was repeated: All the people of the world abandoned Mishnaic teachings and went to engage in Talmudic study. He then expounded to them: "And always be more diligent in the study of Mishnah than in the study of Talmud."

hebrew_text: מַאי דְּרוּשׁ? כִּדְדָרֵישׁ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בְּרַבִּי אִלְעַאי, מַאי דִּכְתִיב: ״הַגֵּד לְעַמִּי פִּשְׁעָם וּלְבֵית יַעֲקֹב חַטֹּאתָם״?
human_translation: what homiletic interpretation is as Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Elai, interpreted homiletically: What which is written: declare to My people their transgression and to the house of Jacob their sins”
llm_translation: What is the meaning of the verse? As Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ilai, interpreted: What is the meaning of what is written: "Declare to My people their transgression, and to the house of Jacob their sin"?

hebrew_text: ״הַגֵּד לְעַמִּי פִּשְׁעָם״ – אֵלּוּ תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים, שֶׁשְּׁגָגוֹת נַעֲשׂוֹת לָהֶם כִּזְדוֹנוֹת. ״וּלְבֵית יַעֲקֹב חַטֹּאתָם״ – אֵלּוּ עַמֵּי הָאָרֶץ, שֶׁזְּדוֹנוֹת נַעֲשׂוֹת לָהֶם כִּשְׁגָגוֹת. וְהַיְינוּ דִּתְנַן, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: הֱוֵי זָהִיר בַּתַּלְמוּד, שֶׁשִּׁגְגַת תַּלְמוּד עוֹלָה זָדוֹן.
human_translation: “declare to My people their transgression,” these are the Torah scholars, whose unwitting become for them tantamount to intentional “And to the house of Jacob their sins,” these are the ignoramuses, whose intentional become for them tantamount to unwitting And that is we learned Rabbi Yehuda says: Be careful in the Talmud, as an unwitting Talmud is considered an intentional
llm_translation: "Declare to My people their transgression" - these are the Torah scholars, for whom inadvertent mistakes are considered intentional transgressions. "And to the house of Jacob their sins" - these are the common people, for whom intentional transgressions are considered inadvertent mistakes. And this is as we learned in a Mishnah: Rabbi Yehuda says: Be cautious in studying, for an inadvertent mistake in study is considered intentional transgression.

hebrew_text: דָּרֵשׁ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בְּרַבִּי אִלְעַאי: מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״שִׁמְעוּ דְּבַר ה׳ הַחֲרֵדִים אֶל דְּבָרוֹ״ – אֵלּוּ תַּלְמִידֵי חֲכָמִים, ״[אָמְרוּ] אֲחֵיכֶם״ – אֵלּוּ בַּעֲלֵי מִקְרָא, ״שֹׂנְאֵיכֶם״ – אֵלּוּ בַּעֲלֵי מִשְׁנָה, ״מְנַדֵּיכֶם״ – אֵלּוּ עַמֵּי הָאָרֶץ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Elai, interpreted homiletically. What which is written: “Hear the word of the Lord, you who tremble at His word,” these are Torah scholars; “your brothers…have said,” these are masters of the Bible, “that hate you,” these are masters of Mishna, “that ostracize you,” these are ignoramuses,
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ilai, expounded: What is the meaning of the verse, "Hear the word of the Lord, you who tremble at His word"? - These are the Torah scholars. "They said your brothers" - These are the experts in Scripture. "Those who hate you" - These are the experts in Mishnah. "Those who cast you out" - These are the ignorant masses.

hebrew_text: שֶׁמָּא תֹּאמַר פָּסַק סִבְרָם וּבָטַל סִיכּוּיָם? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְנִרְאֶה בְּשִׂמְחַתְכֶם״. שֶׁמָּא תֹּאמַר יִשְׂרָאֵל יֵבוֹשׁוּ? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהֵם יֵבֹשׁוּ״, אוּמּוֹת הָעוֹלָם יֵבוֹשׁוּ וְיִשְׂרָאֵל יִשְׂמָחוּ.
human_translation: Lest you say, their hope has ceased and their chances are eliminated, the verse states: “That we may gaze upon your joy.” Lest you say that the Jewish people will be ashamed, the verse states: “But they shall be ashamed,” gentiles will be ashamed, but the Jewish people will be joyous.
llm_translation: Perhaps you will say: They ceased from their actions and nullified their chances? The Scripture states: "And let it be seen in your joy." Perhaps you will say: Israel will be ashamed? The Scripture states: "And they shall be ashamed," while the nations of the world will be ashamed, and Israel will rejoice.

hebrew_text: הֲדַרַן עֲלָךְ אֵלּוּ מְצִיאוֹת
llm_translation: We will return to you, these findings.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַמַּפְקִיד אֵצֶל חֲבֵירוֹ בְּהֵמָה אוֹ כֵלִים, וְנִגְנְבוּ אוֹ שֶׁאָבְדוּ, שִׁילֵּם וְלֹא רָצָה לִישָּׁבַע, שֶׁהֲרֵי אָמְרוּ: ״שׁוֹמֵר חִנָּם נִשְׁבָּע וְיוֹצֵא״.
human_translation: one who deposits an animal or vessels with another, and they were stolen or they were lost, paid and did not wish to take an oath as said: An unpaid bailee takes an oath, and he is released
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who entrusts an animal or utensils to his fellow, and they were stolen or lost, he must pay but does not wish to take an oath, for it is said: "If a man gives his neighbor money or goods to keep for him and it is stolen out of the man's house, if the thief is found, he shall pay double."

hebrew_text: נִמְצָא הַגַּנָּב – מְשַׁלֵּם תַּשְׁלוּמֵי כֶפֶל. טָבַח וּמָכַר – מְשַׁלֵּם תַּשְׁלוּמֵי אַרְבָּעָה וַחֲמִשָּׁה. לְמִי מְשַׁלֵּם? לְמִי שֶׁהַפִּקָּדוֹן אֶצְלוֹ.
human_translation: the thief is found, pays double payment. slaughtered or sold he pays fourfold or fivefold payment. To whom does pay? to the one who the deposit in his
llm_translation: The thief - pays double restitution. One who slaughters and sells - pays four or fivefold restitution. To whom does he pay? To the one to whom the deposit was entrusted.

hebrew_text: נִשְׁבַּע וְלֹא רָצָה לְשַׁלֵּם, נִמְצָא הַגַּנָּב – מְשַׁלֵּם תַּשְׁלוּמֵי כֶפֶל. טָבַח וּמָכַר – מְשַׁלֵּם תַּשְׁלוּמֵי אַרְבָּעָה וַחֲמִשָּׁה, לְמִי מְשַׁלֵּם? לְבַעַל הַפִּקָּדוֹן.
human_translation: took an oath and did not wish to pay, the thief is found pay double payment, slaughtered or sold pay the fourfold or fivefold payment, to whom does pay? to the owner of the deposit,
llm_translation: Swore and did not want to pay, found the thief - pays double payment. Slaughtered and sold - pays four or five payments, to whom does he pay? To the Baal HaPikadon.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ לְמָה לֵיהּ לְמִתְנֵי בְּהֵמָה, וּלְמָה לֵיהּ לְמִתְנֵי כֵּלִים?
human_translation: Why does to teach an animal, and why does to teach vessels?
llm_translation: "Gema, why does it have the law of animal gifts, and why does it have the law of vessel gifts?"

hebrew_text: צְרִיכִי, דְּאִי תְּנָא בְּהֵמָה – הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: בְּהֵמָה הוּא דְּמַקְנֵי לֵיהּ כְּפֵילָא, מִשּׁוּם דִּנְפִישׁ טִירְחַהּ לְעַיּוֹלַהּ וּלְאַפּוֹקַהּ. אֲבָל כֵּלִים דְּלָא נְפִישׁ טִירְחַיְיהוּ, אֵימָא לָא מַקְנֵי לֵיהּ כְּפֵילָא.
human_translation: are necessary, as, if taught an animal, I would say: is an animal that transfer the double payment due to that the exertion to bring in and to take it out, is great. But vessels, where the exertion is not great, say that does not transfer double payment.
llm_translation: It is necessary, for if a Tanna taught regarding an animal - I would say: It is an animal that acquires through its doubling, because its exertion is significant for its benefit and for its loss. But vessels whose exertion is not significant for them, I would say do not acquire through their doubling.

hebrew_text: וְאִי תְּנָא כֵּלִים הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: כֵּלִים הוּא דְּקָמַקְנֵי לֵיהּ כְּפֵילָא – מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא נְפִישׁ כְּפֵלַיְיהוּ, אֲבָל בְּהֵמָה דְּכִי טָבַח וּמָכַר מְשַׁלֵּם תַּשְׁלוּמֵי אַרְבָּעָה וַחֲמִשָּׁה – אֵימָא לָא מַקְנֵי לֵיהּ כְּפֵילָא, צְרִיכָא.
human_translation: And had taught vessels, I would say: is vessels that the owner transfers the double payment due to that double payment, their is not substantial, But an animal, where if slaughtered or sold he pays the fourfold or fivefold payment, I say that does not transfer double payment necessary.
llm_translation: And if you will say, "utensils," I would say: utensils, for they acquire for it a double value - because their doubling is not apparent, but an animal, when one slaughters and sells, he pays four or five payments - I would say, he does not acquire for it a double value, it is necessary.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: וְהָא אֵין אָדָם מַקְנֶה דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא בָּא לָעוֹלָם! וַאֲפִילּוּ לְרַבִּי מֵאִיר דְּאָמַר אָדָם מַקְנֶה דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא בָּא לָעוֹלָם, הָנֵי מִילֵּי כְּגוֹן פֵּירוֹת דֶּקֶל דַּעֲבִידִי דְּאָתוּ,
human_translation: Rami bar Ḥama objects to But isn’t one cannot transfer ownership of an entity that has not come into the world? And even according to Rabbi Meir, who says a person transfer ownership of an entity that has not come into the world, that statement such as the fruits of a date palm, which are likely to come
llm_translation: The Gemara challenges him: Ramai bar Ḥama raises an objection to this: But is it not a principle that a person cannot acquire something that does not exist in the world? And even according to Rabbi Meir, who says that a person can acquire something that does not exist in the world, these matters, such as the fruits of a palm tree that are produced, do come into existence.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל הָכָא
human_translation: But here,
llm_translation: However, here

hebrew_text: מִי יֵימַר דְּמִגַּנְבָא, וְאִם תִּמְצֵי לוֹמַר דְּמִגַּנְבָא – מִי יֵימַר דְּמִשְׁתְּכַח גַּנָּב, וְאִי מִשְׁתְּכַח גַּנָּב – מִי יֵימַר דִּמְשַׁלֵּם, דִּלְמָא מוֹדֵי וּמִפְּטַר? אָמַר רָבָא: נַעֲשָׂה כְּאוֹמֵר לוֹ, לִכְשֶׁתִּגָּנֵב וְתִרְצֶה וּתְשַׁלְּמֵנִי הֲרֵי פָּרָתִי קְנוּיָה לְךָ מֵעַכְשָׁיו.
human_translation: who could say will be stolen? And if you say it be stolen, who could say the thief be found? And if the thief be found, who could say he pay Perhaps he will confess and will be exempted Rava said It is as though said to When it will be stolen, and you will wish and you will pay me my cow is hereby transferred to you from this time,
llm_translation: Who will say that he is a thief, and if you want to say that he is a thief - who will say that the thief is found, and if the thief is not found - who will say that he will pay, perhaps he will admit and be exempt? Rava said: It is done as he says to him, when you steal and want and pay me, behold my cow is acquired to you from now.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַבִּי זֵירָא: אִי הָכִי, אֲפִילּוּ גִּיזּוֹתֶיהָ וּוַלְדוֹתֶיהָ נָמֵי! אַלְּמָה תַּנְיָא חוּץ מִגִּיזּוֹתֶיהָ וּוַלְדוֹתֶיהָ? אֶלָּא אָמַר רַבִּי זֵירָא: נַעֲשָׂה כְּאוֹמֵר לוֹ, חוּץ מִגִּיזּוֹתֶיהָ וּוַלְדוֹתֶיהָ.
human_translation: Rabbi Zeira objects to this: If so, fleece and offspring of Why, is it taught except for its fleece and its offspring? Rather, Rabbi Zeira says it is as though said to except for its fleece and its offspring.
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: Rabbi Zeira objects to her: If so, even her hair and her children's hair are also excluded! Why does the Mishnah teach excluding her hair and her children's hair? Rather, Rabbi Zeira said: It should be done as he tells her, excluding her hair and her children's hair.

hebrew_text: וּמַאי פְּסָקַאּ? סְתָמָא דְּמִלְּתָא שְׁבָחָא דְּאָתֵא מֵעָלְמָא, עֲבִיד אִינִישׁ דְּמַקְנֵי. שְׁבָחָא דְּמִגּוּפַהּ, לָא עֲבִיד אִינִישׁ דְּמַקְנֵי.
human_translation: why without qualification? Typically, profit that comes from elsewhere, a person is apt to transfer profit that from the body a person is not apt to transfer
llm_translation: And what is the conclusion? Presumably, regarding a matter of praise that comes from the world, a person does it. Regarding self-praise, a person does not do it.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי, אָמַר רָבָא: נַעֲשָׂה כְּאוֹמֵר לוֹ, לִכְשֶׁתִּגָּנֵב וְתִרְצֶה וּתְשַׁלְּמֵנִי, סָמוּךְ לִגְנֵיבָתָהּ קְנוּיָה לָךְ. מַאי בֵּינַיְיהוּ?
human_translation: Some say Rava says It is as though said to When it will be stolen, and you will wish and you will pay me is transferred to you adjacent to, its theft. What is between
llm_translation: There is one who says, Rava said: It is done as he says to him, when you steal and want and pay me, close to her theft is acquired for you. What is the difference between them?

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ קוּשְׁיָא דְּרַבִּי זֵירָא. אִי נָמֵי דְּקָיְימָא בַּאֲגַם.
human_translation: There is between them the difficulty by Rabbi Zeira Alternatively, where standing in a marsh [ ba’agam ]
llm_translation: There is a difference between them, the difficulty of Rabbi Zeira. Either because it is established in the marsh.

hebrew_text: שִׁילֵּם וְלֹא רָצָה לִישָּׁבַע [וְכוּ׳]. אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: לֹא ״שִׁילֵּם״ – שִׁילֵּם מַמָּשׁ, אֶלָּא כֵּיוָן שֶׁאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי מְשַׁלֵּם״, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא שִׁילֵּם.
human_translation: paid and did not wish to take an oath, Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says Rabbi Yoḥanan says: paid, not actually paid. Rather, once said: I hereby pay, even if he did not pay,
llm_translation: He paid and did not want to swear etc.. Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: Not "he paid" - he actually paid, but since he said "I am willing to pay," even though he did not pay.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן: שִׁילֵּם וְלֹא רָצָה לִישָּׁבַע. שִׁילֵּם – אִין, לֹא שִׁילֵּם – לָא. אֵימָא סֵיפָא: נִשְׁבַּע וְלֹא רָצָה לְשַׁלֵּם. טַעְמָא דְּלֹא רָצָה, הָא רָצָה אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא שִׁילֵּם. אֶלָּא מֵהָא לֵיכָּא לְמִשְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: we learned paid and did not wish to take an oath, paid, yes, did not pay, not. Say the latter clause took an oath and did not wish to pay, The reason that did not wish But wished although he did not pay, Rather, no to be learned from this
llm_translation: We learned: He paid and did not want to swear. He paid - yes, he paid not - no. Say the latter case: He swore and did not want to pay. The reason he did not want, because he wanted even though he did not pay. Rather, from here we can infer.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּוָתֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הַשּׂוֹכֵר פָּרָה מֵחֲבֵירוֹ, וְנִגְנְבָה, וְאָמַר הַלָּה: ״הֲרֵינִי מְשַׁלֵּם וְאֵינִי נִשְׁבָּע״, וְאַחַר כָּךְ נִמְצָא הַגַּנָּב – מְשַׁלֵּם תַּשְׁלוּמֵי כֶפֶל לַשּׂוֹכֵר.
human_translation: is taught in accordance with of Rabbi Yoḥanan: one who rents a cow from another, and it was stolen, and the other said: I hereby pay and I will not take an oath, and the thief was located thereafter, pays double payment to the renter.
llm_translation: It was taught in the school of Rabbi Yochanan: One who rents a cow from his fellow, and it was stolen, and he said to him: "Here, I am paying and I am not taking an oath," and afterwards the thief was found - he pays double payment to the renter.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: שׁוֹמֵר חִנָּם, כֵּיוָן שֶׁאָמַר ״פָּשַׁעְתִּי״, מַקְנֵה לֵיהּ כְּפֵילָא. דְּאִי בָּעֵי פָּטַר נַפְשֵׁיהּ בִּגְנֵיבָה. שׁוֹמֵר שָׂכָר, כֵּיוָן שֶׁאָמַר ״נִגְנְבָה״, מַקְנֵה לֵיהּ כְּפֵילָא. דְּאִי בָּעֵי פָּטַר נַפְשֵׁיהּ בִּשְׁבוּרָה וּמֵתָה.
human_translation: Rav Pappa says: an unpaid bailee, once he stated: I was negligent, transfers the double payment to him, as, if wishes, exempt himself with theft. a paid bailee, once he stated: It was stolen, transfers the double payment to him, as, if wishes, exempt himself with maimed or died
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: One who guards an item for free, once he says "I have sinned," acquires it as a double payment for himself. For if he wants, he can exempt himself with the claim of theft. One who guards an item for payment, once he says "it was stolen," acquires it as a double payment for himself. For if he wants, he can exempt himself with the claim of breakage, and the owner dies.

hebrew_text: שׁוֹאֵל שֶׁאוֹמֵר ״הֲרֵינִי מְשַׁלֵּם״ – לָא מַקְנֵי לֵיהּ כְּפֵילָא, בְּמַאי הֲוָה לֵיהּ לְמִפְטַר נַפְשֵׁיהּ? בְּמֵתָה מֵחֲמַת מְלָאכָה, מֵתָה מֵחֲמַת מְלָאכָה לָא שְׁכִיחַ.
human_translation: a borrower who says: I hereby to pay, does not transfer the double payment to him. With what to exempt himself with died due to labor. died due to labor is uncommon,
llm_translation: One who says, "Behold, I will pay" - does not acquire it as a double payment, with what was he to exempt his soul? If he died due to work, if he died due to work it is not common.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי, אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: שׁוֹאֵל נָמֵי כֵּיוָן שֶׁאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי מְשַׁלֵּם״ – מַקְנֵי לֵיהּ כְּפֵילָא, דְּאִי בָּעֵי פָּטַר נַפְשֵׁיהּ בְּמֵתָה מֵחֲמַת מְלָאכָה. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב זְבִיד: הָכִי אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: שׁוֹאֵל עַד שֶׁיְּשַׁלֵּם. מַאי טַעְמָא? הוֹאִיל וְכׇל הֲנָאָה שֶׁלּוֹ, בְּדִיבּוּרָא לָא מַקְנֵי לֵיהּ כְּפֵילָא.
human_translation: Some say Rav Pappa said: a borrower, once he stated: I hereby to pay, transfers the double payment to him, as, if wishes, exempt himself with died due to labor. Rav Zevid said to him this Abaye said: A borrower only when he pays What is the reason Since all of the benefit to the owner does not transfer the double payment to due to statement
llm_translation: There are those who say, Rav Papa said: One may ask for interest, since he said, "Here I am, ready to pay" - he acquires it as a double loan, for if he wants, he can exempt himself with a death due to work. Rav Zebid said to him: Thus Abaye said: One may ask until he pays. What is the reason? Since all his benefit, he does not acquire with speech as a double loan.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַב זְבִיד: הַשּׁוֹאֵל פָּרָה מֵחֲבֵירוֹ וְנִגְנְבָה, וְקִידֵּם הַשּׁוֹאֵל וְשִׁילֵּם, וְאַחַר כָּךְ נִמְצָא הַגַּנָּב – מְשַׁלֵּם תַּשְׁלוּמֵי כֶפֶל לַשּׁוֹאֵל.
human_translation: is taught in accordance with of Rav Zevid: one who borrows a cow from another, and it was stolen, and the borrower went ahead and paid, and the thief was located thereafter, pays double payment to the borrower.
llm_translation: It was taught in the school of Rav Zevid: If one borrows a cow from his fellow and it is stolen, and the borrower had already paid back the lender, and afterwards the thief is found - the thief must pay double restitution to the borrower.

hebrew_text: לְלִישָּׁנָא קַמָּא דְּרַב פָּפָּא – וַדַּאי לָא הָוְיָא תְּיוּבְתָּא. לְלִישָּׁנָא בָּתְרָא לֵימָא תֶּיהְוֵי תְּיוּבְתֵּיהּ?
human_translation: According to the first version of Rav Pappa, certainly is not a conclusive refutation [ teyuvta ] According to the latter version shall we say would be a conclusive refutation
llm_translation: Firstly, the translation of the text you provided is as follows: "Talmudic text: Regarding the first teaching of Rav Papa - and surely it was not a satisfactory answer. Regarding the second teaching, should it be considered a satisfactory answer?"

hebrew_text: אָמַר לְךָ רַב פָּפָּא: מִי אַלִּימָא מִמַּתְנִיתִין? דְּקָתָנֵי ״שִׁילֵּם״, וְאוֹקֵימְנָא, בְּאָמַר הָכָא נָמֵי בְּאָמַר.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said to you: Is stronger than the mishna, which teaches paid and we established to states Here, too, to states
llm_translation: He said to you, Rav Papa: Who said it from the Mishnah? As it teaches "he shall pay," and I establish it, as it says here also as it says.

hebrew_text: מִי דָּמֵי? הָתָם לָא קָתָנֵי ״קִידֵּם״, הָכָא קָתָנֵי ״קִידֵּם״! מַאי ״קִידֵּם״? קִידֵּם וְאָמַר.
human_translation: Are comparable? There, is not taught went ahead Here, is taught went ahead What went ahead? he went ahead and stated
llm_translation: Who is similar? There it does not teach "preceded," here it teaches "preceded"! What is "preceded"? He preceded and said.

hebrew_text: הָא מִדְּקָתָנֵי גַּבֵּי שׂוֹכֵר ״וְאָמַר״, וְגַבֵּי שׁוֹאֵל ״קִידֵּם״ – שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ דַּוְקָא קָתָנֵי! מִידֵּי גַּבֵּי הֲדָדֵי תַּנְיָא?
human_translation: But from that teaches with regard to a renter And he said and with regard to a borrower Went ahead, conclude from it that is teaching specifically Are taught together
llm_translation: The one who taught regarding a renter "and he said," and regarding a borrower "before" - learn from it that specifically it teaches! From the hands of Hadadei, is there a teaching?

hebrew_text: שַׁיְילִינְהוּ לְתַנָּאֵי דְּבֵי רַבִּי חִיָּיא וּדְבֵי רַבִּי אוֹשַׁעְיָא, וְאָמְרִי: גַּבֵּי הֲדָדֵי תַּנְיָין.
human_translation: asked the tanna’im of the school of Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Oshaya, And they said were taught together
llm_translation: They asked the scholars of the school of Rabbi Ḥiyya and the school of Rabbi Oshaya, and they said: "Regarding the Hadadeans, teachings."

hebrew_text: פְּשִׁיטָא: אָמַר ״אֵינִי מְשַׁלֵּם״ וְחָזַר וְאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי מְשַׁלֵּם״, – הָא קָאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי מְשַׁלֵּם״. אֶלָּא אָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי מְשַׁלֵּם״
human_translation: obvious said: I will not pay, and then said: I hereby pay didn’t say: I hereby choose to pay? But said: I hereby pay,
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: "Peshita: he said, 'I will not pay,' and then he retracted and said, 'Here I am paying' - this is what he said, 'Here I am paying.' Rather, he said, 'Here I am paying.'"

hebrew_text: וְחָזַר וְאָמַר ״אֵינִי מְשַׁלֵּם״, מַאי? מִי אָמְרִינַן מִהְדָּר קָא הָדַר בֵּיהּ, אוֹ דִלְמָא בְּמִלְּתֵיהּ קָאֵי וְדַחוֹיֵי הוּא דְּקָא מְדַחֵי לֵיהּ?
human_translation: and then said: I will not pay, what Do we say he is retracting Or, perhaps he stands his statement and is postponing
llm_translation: And he went back and said, "I do not pay," what? Who said that he is returning to it, or perhaps he is standing on his words and rejecting the one who is rejecting him?

hebrew_text: אָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי מְשַׁלֵּם״ וָמֵת, וְאָמְרוּ בָּנָיו ״אֵין אָנוּ מְשַׁלְּמִין״, מַאי? מִי אָמְרִינַן מִהְדָּר קָא הָדְרִי בְּהוּ, אוֹ דִלְמָא בְּמִלְּתָא דַאֲבוּהוֹן קָיְימִי, וְדַחוֹיֵי הוּא דְּקָא מְדַחוּ לֵיהּ?
human_translation: said: I hereby pay, and died and his sons said: We are not paying, what Do we say they are retracting or perhaps they stand their father’s statement and are postponing
llm_translation: He said, "I will pay," and he died, and his sons said, "We are not paying." What? Do we say that he is retracting with them, or perhaps the matter of his father's vow is standing, and he is pushing away the one who is pushing him away?

hebrew_text: שִׁלְּמוּ בָּנִים, מַאי? מָצֵי אָמַר לְהוּ: כִּי אַקְנַאי כְּפֵילָא – לַאֲבוּכוֹן דַּעֲבַד לִי נְיָיח נַפְשַׁאי, לְדִידְכוּ לָא, אוֹ דִלְמָא לָא שְׁנָא.
human_translation: the sons paid, what Can say to them: When I transferred the double payment, to your father, who pleased me, to you, not Or perhaps is no different,
llm_translation: They said, "What is the meaning of 'Shillemu Banim'?" He replied to them: "For I am zealous like a leopard - for the honor of my Creator, who created me, my soul is at ease, but not for your sake, or perhaps not at all."

hebrew_text: שִׁילֵּם לְבָנִים, מַאי? מָצוּ אָמְרִי לֵיהּ: כִּי אַקְנִי לָךְ אֲבוּנָא כְּפֵילָא – דַּעֲבַדְתְּ לֵיהּ נְיָיח נַפְשֵׁיהּ, אֲבָל אֲנַן לְדִידַן לָא, אוֹ דִלְמָא לָא שְׁנָא. שִׁלְּמוּ בָּנִים לְבָנִים, מַאי?
human_translation: paid to sons, what Can say to When our father transferred the double payment to you, you pleased him, but we not us? Or perhaps it is no different, sons paid the sons what
llm_translation: He shall pay with stones, what is it? They found and said to him: "For I will buy for you a stone twofold" - you have made it rest, but we do not, or perhaps it is not different. They shall pay sons with sons, what is it?

hebrew_text: שִׁילֵּם מֶחֱצָה, מַאי? שָׁאַל שְׁתֵּי פָּרוֹת וְשִׁילֵּם אַחַת מֵהֶן, מַאי? שָׁאַל מִן הַשּׁוּתָּפִין וְשִׁילֵּם לְאֶחָד מֵהֶן, מַאי? שׁוּתָּפִין שֶׁשָּׁאֲלוּ וְשִׁילֵּם אֶחָד מֵהֶן, מַאי? שָׁאַל מִן הָאִשָּׁה וְשִׁילֵּם לְבַעְלָהּ, מַאי? אִשָּׁה שֶׁשָּׁאֲלָה וְשִׁילֵּם בַּעֲלָהּ, מַאי? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: paid half what one borrowed two cows, he paid of one of them, what borrowed from partners, and he paid one of them, what partners who borrowed and one of them paid, what one borrowed from a woman and paid her husband, what a woman who borrowed and her husband paid, what shall stand [ teiku ]
llm_translation: He paid half, what is it? He asked for two cows and paid one of them, what is it? He asked from the partners and paid to one of them, what is it? Partners who asked and he paid one of them, what is it? He asked from the woman and paid to her husband, what is it? A woman who asked and her husband paid, what is it? The matter remains unresolved.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: מַשְׁבִּיעִין אוֹתוֹ שְׁבוּעָה שֶׁאֵינָהּ בִּרְשׁוּתוֹ. מַאי טַעְמָא? חָיְישִׁינַן שֶׁמָּא עֵינָיו נָתַן בָּהּ.
human_translation: Rav Huna says: administers an oath to him that is not in his possession. What is the reason We are concerned perhaps he coveted
llm_translation: Rav Huna said: We administer an oath to him for a week that is not in his possession. What is the reason? We are concerned that perhaps he placed his eyes upon it.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: הַמַּלְוֶה אֶת חֲבֵירוֹ עַל הַמַּשְׁכּוֹן, וְאָבַד הַמַּשְׁכּוֹן, וְאָמַר לוֹ: סֶלַע הִלְוִיתִיךָ עָלָיו, שֶׁקֶל הָיָה שָׁוֶה. וְהַלָּה אוֹמֵר: לֹא כִּי, אֶלָּא סֶלַע הִלְוִיתַנִי עָלָיו, סֶלַע הָיָה שָׁוֶה – פָּטוּר.
human_translation: raises an objection one who lends to another on collateral, and the collateral was lost, and says to I loaned you a sela on was worth a shekel, And the other says That is not Rather, you loaned me a sela on was worth a sela ; exempt
llm_translation: Challenger: One who lends to his fellow with a mortgage, and the mortgage is lost, and he says to him: "I have lent you a rock upon it, it was worth a shekel." And the defender says: "No, rather, I lent you a rock upon it, it was worth a shekel" - he is exempt.

hebrew_text: סֶלַע הִלְוִיתִיךָ עָלָיו, שֶׁקֶל הָיָה שָׁוֶה, וְהַלָּה אוֹמֵר: לֹא כִי, אֶלָּא סֶלַע הִלְוִיתַנִי עָלָיו, שְׁלֹשָׁה דִּינָרִים הָיָה שָׁוֶה – חַיָּיב.
human_translation: I loaned you a sela on and it was worth a shekel. And the other says: That is not rather, you loaned me a sela on and was worth three dinars, obligated
llm_translation: The rock I lent you upon it, a shekel was worth, and Halah says: Not so, but the rock I lent upon it, three dinars was worth - liable.

hebrew_text: סֶלַע הִלְוִיתַנִי עָלָיו, שְׁנַיִם הָיָה שָׁוֶה, וְהַלָּה אוֹמֵר: לֹא כִּי, אֶלָּא סֶלַע הִלְוִיתִיךָ עָלָיו, סֶלַע הָיָה שָׁוֶה – פָּטוּר.
human_translation: You loaned me a sela on was worth two And the other said: That is not rather, I loaned you a sela on was worth a sela . exempt.
llm_translation: The rock I lent you, two were equal, and Halah says: Not so, but the rock I lent you, two were equal - exempt.

hebrew_text: סֶלַע הִלְוִיתַנִי עָלָיו, שְׁנַיִם הָיָה שָׁוֶה, וְהַלָּה אוֹמֵר: לֹא כִּי, אֶלָּא סֶלַע הִלְוִיתִיךָ עָלָיו, חֲמִשָּׁה דִּינָרִים הָיָה שָׁוֶה – חַיָּיב.
human_translation: You loaned me a sela on was worth two And the other said: That is not rather, I loaned you a sela on was worth five dinars. obligated
llm_translation: Text: "Sela hilvitani alav, shnayim hayah shaveh, vehalah omer: lo ki, ela sela hilvitikha alav, chamesha dinarim hayah shaveh - chayav." Translation: "A borrowed rock upon it, two was equal, and the Halacha says: not so, rather a borrowed rock of yours upon it, five dinars was equal - liable."

hebrew_text: מִי נִשְׁבָּע? מִי שֶׁהַפִּקָּדוֹן אֶצְלוֹ. שֶׁמָּא יִשָּׁבַע זֶה וְיוֹצִיא הַלָּה אֶת הַפִּקָּדוֹן.
human_translation: Who takes oath? The one whose the deposit was lest this take an oath and the other produce the deposit
llm_translation: Who takes an oath? One who has the deposit with him. Perhaps this one will take an oath and cause the depositor to lose his deposit.

hebrew_text: אַהֵיָיא? אִילֵּימָא אַסֵּיפָא, וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ דִּשְׁבוּעָה גַּבֵּי מַלְוֶה הִיא, דְּהָא קָא מוֹדֵי מִקְצָת הַטַּעֲנָה! אֶלָּא אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: אַרֵישָׁא.
human_translation: To which If we say to the latter clause Derive oath upon the creditor that he admits to part of the claim, Rather, Shmuel says: to the first clause
llm_translation: Ahayya? Ileima asseifa, vetifok leih dishvua gabei malveh hi, deha kameidei miktsat hataanah! Ella amar Shmuel: areisha.

hebrew_text: מַאי אַרֵישָׁא? אַסֵּיפָא דְּרֵישָׁא, סֶלַע הִלְוִיתִיךָ עָלָיו שֶׁקֶל הָיָה שָׁוֶה, וְהַלָּהּ אוֹמֵר: לֹא כִּי, אֶלָּא סֶלַע הִלְוִיתַנִי עָלָיו, שְׁלֹשָׁה דִּינָרִין הָיָה שָׁוֶה – חַיָּיב. דִּשְׁבוּעָה גַּבֵּי לֹוֶה הוּא, וַאֲמוּר רַבָּנַן: לִשְׁתְּבַע מַלְוֶה, שֶׁמָּא יִשָּׁבַע זֶה וְיוֹצִיא הַלָּה אֶת הַפִּקָּדוֹן.
human_translation: What to the first clause to the latter of the first clause: I loaned you a sela on and it was worth a shekel. And the other says: That is not rather, you loaned me a sela on and was worth three dinars. obligated the oath is that of the borrower, But the Sages said: Let the creditor take oath lest this take an oath and the other produce the deposit.
llm_translation: What is the first case? The conclusion of the first case, "I borrowed a rock from you that was worth a shekel, and the borrower says: 'No, rather, I borrowed a rock from you that was worth three dinars' – he is liable.
