human_translation: who was exploited seller. Say the latter clause Until when permitted to return In the time that to show to a merchant or to his relative. And Rav Naḥman said: taught only a buyer, But a seller may always renege
llm_translation: Who is designated - seller. Say the end: until when permitted to return - in order that he may show to the merchant or to his relative. And Rav Nachman said: They only taught regarding the buyer, but the seller - always returns.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא דְּזַבֵּין שָׁוֵי עֶשְׂרִים וְאַרְבְּעָה בְּעֶשְׂרִין וּתְמָנְיָא. תְּנַן, הוֹרָה רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן בְּלוֹד: הָאוֹנָאָה שְׁמוֹנָה כֶּסֶף מֵעֶשְׂרִים וְאַרְבָּעָה כֶּסֶף לַסֶּלַע, שְׁלִישׁ לְמִקָּח. מַאי לָאו, דְּזַבֵּין שָׁוֵי שִׁיתַּסְרֵי בְּעֶשְׂרִים וְאַרְבְּעָה? וּשְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: שְׁלִישׁ מָעוֹת נָמֵי שָׁנִינוּ.
human_translation: Rather, where he sold worth twenty-four for twenty-eight We learned Rabbi Tarfon ruled in Lod: Exploitation eight silver from twenty-four silver of a sela , one-third of the transaction. What, is it not where he bought worth sixteen for twenty-four And conclude from we learned also one-third of money
llm_translation: Rather, that they sell for twenty-four at twenty and eight. We learned in a Mishnah: Rabbi Tarfon taught in Lod: The interest is eight silver coins for twenty-four, and four silver coins for the sela, a third for the purchase. What is the reason that they do not sell for twenty-six? And learn from it: A third of a coin is what we have taught.

hebrew_text: לָא: דְּזַבֵּין שָׁוֵי עֶשְׂרִים וְאַרְבְּעָה בְּשִׁיתְּסַר. מִי נִתְאַנָּה מוֹכֵר, אֵימָא סֵיפָא: אָמַר לָהֶם – כׇּל הַיּוֹם מוּתָּר לַחְזוֹר. וְאָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא לוֹקֵחַ, אֲבָל מוֹכֵר לְעוֹלָם חוֹזֵר. אֶלָּא דְּזַבֵּין שָׁוֵי עֶשְׂרִים וְאַרְבְּעָה בִּתְלָתִין וּתְרֵין.
human_translation: No, where he sold worth twenty-four for sixteen who was exploited seller. Say the latter clause said to them: the entire day permitted to renege And Rav Naḥman says: They taught only a buyer, but a seller may always renege Rather, where he sold worth twenty-four for thirty-two
llm_translation: Not yet translated.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דִּשְׁמוּאֵל: מִי שֶׁהוּטַּל עָלָיו יָדוֹ עַל הָעֶלְיוֹנָה. כֵּיצַד? מָכַר לוֹ שָׁוֶה חֲמִשָּׁה בְּשִׁשָּׁה, מִי נִתְאַנָּה – לוֹקֵחַ, יָד לוֹקֵחַ עַל הָעֶלְיוֹנָה, רָצָה אוֹמֵר: תֵּן לִי מְעוֹתַי, אוֹ תֵּן לִי מָה שֶׁאוֹנֵיתַנִי. מָכַר לוֹ
human_translation: It is taught in accordance with of Shmuel: The one upon whom was imposed has the advantage. How so? sold him worth five for six who was exploited? buyer. buyer is at an advantage. wishes, say Give me my money or Give me which you exploitation me. sold him
llm_translation: It was taught in the presence of Shmuel: "One whose hand is resting on the higher price. How so? If he sold to him something for five coins at six coins, who has the option to finalize the sale? The buyer. The hand of the buyer is resting on the higher price. If he wishes, he can say, 'Give me my money,' or 'Give me what you have promised me.' He sold to him..."

hebrew_text: שָׁוֶה שֵׁשׁ בְּחָמֵשׁ, מִי נִתְאַנָּה – מוֹכֵר, יָד מוֹכֵר עַל הָעֶלְיוֹנָה. רָצָה אוֹמֵר לוֹ: ״תֵּן לִי מִקָּחִי״, אוֹ ״תֵּן לִי מַה שֶּׁאוֹנֵיתַנִי״.
human_translation: worth six for five who was exploited? seller. seller is at an advantage. wishes, say to Give me my merchandise or Give me which you exploitation me.
llm_translation: He who appraises six for five, who is appointed? - the seller, the hand of the seller is on top. If he wishes, he says to him: "Give me my purchase," or "Give me what I have appraised."

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: פָּחוֹת מִשְּׁתוּת לְרַבָּנַן, לְאַלְתַּר הָוְיָא מְחִילָה, אוֹ בִּכְדֵי שֶׁיַּרְאֶה לַתַּגָּר אוֹ לִקְרוֹבוֹ? וְאִם תִּמְצֵי לוֹמַר בִּכְדֵי שֶׁיַּרְאֶה לַתַּגָּר אוֹ לִקְרוֹבוֹ, מַאי אִיכָּא בֵּין שְׁתוּת לְפָחוֹת מִשְּׁתוּת?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before According to the Rabbis less than one-sixth, is a waiver immediately, or the time that to show to a merchant or to his relative? And if you say the time that to show to a merchant or to his relative, what is there between one-sixth and less than one-sixth?
llm_translation: He asked them: If one pours less than a revi'it according to the Rabbis, is it immediately considered a pouring, or is it necessary for it to be visible to a stranger or a relative? And if you want to say it is necessary for it to be visible to a stranger or a relative, what is the difference between less than a revi'it and a revi'it?

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאִלּוּ שְׁתוּת – יָדוֹ עַל הָעֶלְיוֹנָה, רָצָה – חוֹזֵר, רָצָה – קוֹנֶה וּמַחֲזִיר אוֹנָאָה. וְאִילּוּ פָּחוֹת מִשְּׁתוּת – קָנָה, וּמַחְזִיר אוֹנָאָה.
human_translation: There is as one-sixth, has the advantage, wishes, reneges wishes, acquires and returns exploiting while less than one-sixth, acquires and returns exploiting
llm_translation: There is one who, if he drank – his hand is on the upper one, if he wants – he returns, if he wants – he acquires and returns the interest. And if it is less than a drink – he acquires, and returns the interest.

hebrew_text: מַאי? תָּא שְׁמַע: חָזְרוּ לְדִבְרֵי חֲכָמִים.
human_translation: what Come hear They reverted to the statement of the Rabbis.
llm_translation: What? Come and hear: They returned to the words of the sages.

hebrew_text: סַבְרוּהָ פָּחוֹת מִשְּׁלִישׁ לְרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן כְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁתוּת לְרַבָּנַן דָּמֵי. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא פָּחוֹת מִשְּׁתוּת לְרַבָּנַן בִּכְדֵי שֶׁיַּרְאֶה לַתַּגָּר אוֹ לִקְרוֹבוֹ, וּלְרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן כׇּל הַיּוֹם – מִשּׁוּם הָכִי חָזְרוּ. אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ פָּחוֹת מִשְּׁתוּת לְרַבָּנַן – לְאַלְתַּר הָוְיָא מְחִילָה,
human_translation: assumed less than one-third according to Rabbi Tarfon, is like less than one-sixth according to the Rabbis, Granted, if you say less than one-sixth according to the Rabbis in the time that to show to a merchant or to his relative, according to Rabbi Tarfon the entire day due to that reverted But if you say less than one-sixth according to the Rabbis waiver is immediately,
llm_translation: They thought her less than a third for Rabbi Tarfon like less than two for the Rabbis it is similar. If you say, for the Rabbis less than two is enough to show respect to a guest or a relative, and for Rabbi Tarfon the whole day - that is why they returned. But if you say less than two for the Rabbis - it is immediately considered an insult.

hebrew_text: וּלְרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן נָמֵי לְאַלְתַּר הָוְיָא מְחִילָה, אַמַּאי חָזְרוּ? בִּדְרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן נִיחָא לְהוּ טְפֵי, דְּמַאי דְּרַבָּנַן קָא מְשַׁוֵּי לְהוּ אוֹנָאָה לְרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן הָוְיָא מְחִילָה?
human_translation: and according to Rabbi Tarfon too, is a waiver immediately, why did they revert In of Rabbi Tarfon preferable for them, as that which the Rabbis deem exploitation, is waived according to Rabbi Tarfon.
llm_translation: To Rabbi Tarfon it was said immediately, why did they return? With Rabbi Tarfon it is fitting for them, for the words of the Sages are compared to them as an onion to Rabbi Tarfon, why was it said immediately to Rabbi Tarfon?

hebrew_text: מִי סָבְרַתְּ פָּחוֹת מִשְּׁלִישׁ לְרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן כְּפָחוֹת מִשְּׁתוּת לְרַבָּנַן דָּמֵי? לָא, מִשְּׁתוּת וְעַד שְׁלִישׁ לְרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן כִּשְׁתוּת עַצְמָהּ לְרַבָּנַן דָּמֵי. אִי הָכִי, בְּמַאי שָׂמְחוּ מֵעִיקָּרָא?
human_translation: Do you maintain less than one-third according to Rabbi Tarfon is like less than one-sixth according to the Rabbis? No, from one-sixth until one-third according to Rabbi Tarfon is like one-sixth itself according to the Rabbis, If so, for what did rejoice initially?
llm_translation: Who holds less than a third according to Rabbi Tarfon is like less than half according to the Rabbis? No, from half to a third according to Rabbi Tarfon is like half itself according to the Rabbis. If so, with what are they pleased from the outset?

hebrew_text: תִּפְשׁוֹט דְּבִטּוּל מִקָּח לְרַבָּנַן לְעוֹלָם חוֹזֵר, דְּכֵיוָן דַּאֲמַר לְהוּ רַבִּי טַרְפוֹן הָוְיָא אוֹנָאָה – שָׂמְחוּ, כִּי אֲמַר לְהוּ כׇּל הַיּוֹם – חָזְרוּ.
human_translation: Resolve, that nullification of the transaction according to the Rabbis, one may always renege as, since Rabbi Tarfon said to them is exploitation, they rejoiced, When he said to them the entire day, they reverted
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Should one retract from a transaction according to the Rabbis, it is always possible to retract, for since Rabbi Tarfon said, 'It is a form of oppression,' they rejoiced, for when he said it all day, they retracted."

hebrew_text: דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ דְּבִטּוּל מִקָּח לְרַבָּנַן בִּכְדֵי שֶׁיַּרְאֶה לַתַּגָּר אוֹ לִקְרוֹבוֹ, בְּמַאי שָׂמְחוּ? שָׂמְחוּ בְּשֶׁתּוּת עַצְמָהּ, דִּלְרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן מְחִילָה, וּלְרַבָּנַן אוֹנָאָה.
human_translation: As, if it enters your mind that nullification of the transaction according to the Rabbis within the time that to show to a merchant or to his relative, for what did they rejoice They rejoiced over the one-sixth itself, as according to Rabbi Tarfon a waiver and according to the Rabbis exploitation.
llm_translation: If it arises in your mind that the nullification of a transaction by the Rabbis is for the purpose of showing favor to the peddler or his relative, with what are they pleased? They are pleased with the satisfaction of the peddler himself, for Rabbi Tarfon is lenient, and for the Rabbis, it is a form of oppression.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: בִּטּוּל מִקָּח לְרַבָּנַן, לְעוֹלָם חוֹזֵר, אוֹ דִלְמָא בִּכְדֵי שֶׁיַּרְאֶה לַתַּגָּר אוֹ לִקְרוֹבוֹ? וְאִם תִּמְצָא לוֹמַר בִּכְדֵי שֶׁיַּרְאֶה לַתַּגָּר אוֹ לִקְרוֹבוֹ, מָה אִיכָּא בֵּין שְׁתוּת לְיָתֵר עַל שְׁתוּת? אִיכָּא: דְּאִילּוּ שְׁתוּת – מִי שֶׁנִּתְאַנָּה חוֹזֵר, וְאִילּוּ יָתֵר עַל שְׁתוּת – שְׁנֵיהֶם חוֹזְרִים.
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before nullification of the transaction according to the Rabbis, always renege Or perhaps within the time that to show to a merchant or to his relative. And if you say within the time that to show to a merchant or to his relative, what is there between one-sixth and greater than one-sixth? There is as one-sixth, who was exploited can renege while greater than one-sixth, both can renege
llm_translation: The scholars asked: If one annuls a purchase before the Rabbis, does he always retract, or perhaps it is only in order to appear pleasing to the merchant or his relative? And if you find to say it is in order to appear pleasing to the merchant or his relative, what is the difference between an annulment and an additional annulment? There is a difference: for if it is an annulment, one who has agreed retracts, but if it is an additional annulment, both retract.

hebrew_text: מַאי? תָּא שְׁמַע, חָזְרוּ לְדִבְרֵי חֲכָמִים. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא בִּטּוּל מִקָּח לְרַבָּנַן בִּכְדֵי שֶׁיַּרְאֶה לַתַּגָּר אוֹ לִקְרוֹבוֹ, וּלְרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן כׇּל הַיּוֹם – מִשּׁוּם הָכִי חָזְרוּ. אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּטּוּל מִקָּח לְרַבָּנַן לְעוֹלָם חוֹזֵר, אַמַּאי חָזְרוּ? בִּדְרַבִּי טַרְפוֹן נִיחָא לְהוּ טְפֵי, דְּקָא מְשַׁוֵּי לְהוּ אוֹנָאָה כׇּל הַיּוֹם וְתוּ לָא!
human_translation: What Come hear reverted to the statement of the Rabbis. Granted, if you say nullification of the transaction according to the Rabbis within the time that to show to a merchant or to his relative, and according to Rabbi Tarfon the entire day, due to that they reverted But if you say nullification of the transaction according to the Rabbis always renege why they revert In of Rabbi Tarfon preferable for them, as he deems exploitation the entire day and no more,
llm_translation: What? Come and hear, they returned to the words of the sages. If you say, "It is well if the nullification of a purchase is for the sake of the Rabbis, in order that he may appear to the merchant or to his relative, and for Rabbi Tarfon all day - for this reason they returned." But if you say, "The nullification of a purchase is always returned to the Rabbis, why did they return?" In the case of Rabbi Tarfon, it is more appropriate for them, for he is causing them distress all day, and it is not enough!

hebrew_text: בִּטּוּל מִקָּח לָא שְׁכִיחַ.
human_translation: Nullification of the transaction is uncommon,
llm_translation: In the nullification of a purchase, it is not common.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא, הִלְכְתָא: פָּחוֹת מִשְּׁתוּת – נִקְנֶה מִקָּח, יוֹתֵר עַל שְׁתוּת – בִּיטּוּל מִקָּח, שְׁתוּת – קָנָה וּמַחְזִיר אוֹנָאָה, וְזֶה וָזֶה – בִּכְדֵי שֶׁיַּרְאֶה לַתַּגָּר אוֹ לִקְרוֹבוֹ.
human_translation: Rava said: halakha less than one-sixth, merchandise is acquired greater than one-sixth, nullification of the transaction. one-sixth, acquired and returns exploitation. And this, and that, within the time that to show to a merchant or to his relative.
llm_translation: Rava said, a halacha: less than shetut - acquired from a purchase, more than shetut - annulled from a purchase, shetut - acquires and returns the overcharge, and both parties - in order to show goodwill or to be close.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרָבָא: אוֹנָאָה פָּחוֹת מִשְּׁתוּת – נִקְנֶה מִקָּח. יָתֵר עַל שְׁתוּת – בָּטֵל מִקָּח. שְׁתוּת – קָנָה וּמַחְזִיר אוֹנָאָה, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי נָתָן. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הַנָּשִׂיא אוֹמֵר: יָד מוֹכֵר עַל הָעֶלְיוֹנָה, רוֹצֶה – אוֹמֵר לוֹ: ״תֵּן לִי מִקָּחִי״, אוֹ ״תֵּן לִי מַה שֶּׁאֹנֵיתַנִי״. וְזֶה וָזֶה בִּכְדֵי שֶׁיַּרְאֶה לַתַּגָּר אוֹ לִקְרוֹבוֹ.
human_translation: It is taught in accordance with of Rava: exploitation, less than one-sixth, merchandise is acquired greater than one-sixth, the transaction is nullified. one-sixth, acquired and returns exploitation. the statement of Rabbi Natan. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi says: seller is at an advantage. wishes, says to Give me my merchandise, or Give me that you exploiting me. And this, and that, within the time that to show to a merchant or to his relative.
llm_translation: It was taught in the school of Rava: If the overcharge is less than a sixth - the purchase is valid. If it is more than a sixth - the purchase is void. A sixth - he acquires and returns the overcharge, the words of Rabbi Nathan. Rabbi Judah the Prince says: If a seller extends his hand for the upper price, and the buyer wants, he says to him: "Give me my purchase," or "Give me what I have overpaid." And both of these are sufficient for the merchant or his relative to see.

hebrew_text: עַד מָתַי מוּתָּר לְהַחֲזִיר כּוּ׳. אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא לוֹקֵחַ, אֲבָל מוֹכֵר – לְעוֹלָם חוֹזֵר. נֵימָא מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ: חָזְרוּ לְדִבְרֵי חֲכָמִים. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא מוֹכֵר לְעוֹלָם חוֹזֵר,
human_translation: Until when permitted to return Rav Naḥman says: taught only a buyer, but a seller may always renege Let us say supports his reverted to the statement of the Rabbis. Granted, if you say a seller may always renege
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Until when is it permitted to return a lost object? Rav Nahman said: They only taught this ruling regarding a buyer, but regarding a seller - one always returns the lost object. It was stated that this supports him: They returned to the words of the Sages. If you say, "Regarding a seller, one always returns the lost object," English translation:

hebrew_text: מִשּׁוּם הָכִי חָזְרוּ.
human_translation: due to this they reverted
llm_translation: Therefore, they returned.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ מוֹכֵר נָמֵי כְּלוֹקֵחַ דָּמֵי, מַאי נָפְקָא לְהוּ מִינַּהּ? כִּי הֵיכִי דְּעָבְדִי לַיהּ רַבָּנַן תַּקַּנְתָּא לְלוֹקֵחַ, הָכִי נָמֵי עָבְדִי לַיהּ רַבָּנַן תַּקַּנְתָּא לְמוֹכֵר!
human_translation: But if you say a seller is also like a buyer what difference is to Just as the Sages instituted an ordinance on behalf of a buyer so too, the Sages instituted an ordinance on behalf of a seller.
llm_translation: Rather, if you say that the seller is like the buyer regarding payment, what practical difference does it make to them? In order that the Rabbis should enact a measure for the buyer, so too they should enact a measure for the seller!

hebrew_text: תַּגָּרֵי לוֹד לָא שְׁכִיחַ דְּטָעוּ.
human_translation: the merchants of Lod, it is rare for them to err,
llm_translation: The Talmudic text translates to: "Tagarei Lod is not common that they err."

hebrew_text: אוּשְׁפִּיזְכָנֵיהּ דְּרָמֵי בַּר חָמָא זַבֵּין חֲמָרָא וּטְעָה. אַשְׁכְּחֵיהּ דַּהֲוָה עֲצִיב, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אַמַּאי עֲצִיבַתְּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: זַבֵּינִי חֲמָרָא וּטְעַאי. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: זִיל הֲדַר בָּךְ. אָמַר לֵיהּ: הָא שְׁהַאי לִי יוֹתֵר מִכְּדֵי שֶׁאַרְאֶה לַתַּגָּר אוֹ לִקְרוֹבִי! שַׁדְּרֵיהּ לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב נַחְמָן, אֲמַר לֵיהּ לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא לוֹקֵחַ, אֲבָל מוֹכֵר – לְעוֹלָם חוֹזֵר.
human_translation: The landlord of Rami bar Ḥama sold a donkey and erred encountered him that he was sad. said to him: Why are you sad? said to him: I sold a donkey and I erred said to him: Go renege said to him: I have waited more than the period that me to show to a merchant or to my relative. sent before Rav Naḥman said to him: taught only a buyer, but a seller may always renege
llm_translation: The officials of the city of Ramai, son of Hama, were selling wine and making a mistake. He found that he was sad, and he said to him: "Why are you sad?" He said to him: "I am selling wine and making a mistake." He said to him: "Go, return it." He said to him: "But this is more than enough for me to see the merchant or my relative!" He sent him to stand before Rav Nachman, who said to him: "They only taught about a buyer, but a seller – always returns."

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא? לוֹקֵחַ מִקָּחוֹ בְּיָדוֹ, כֹּל הֵיכָא דְּאָזֵיל מַחְוִי לֵיהּ וְאָמְרִי לֵיהּ אִי טְעָה, אִי לָא טְעָה. מוֹכֵר דְּלָא נָקֵט מִקָּחֵיהּ בִּידֵיהּ עַד דְּמִיתְרְמֵי לֵיהּ זְבִינְתָּא כִּזְבִינְתֵּיהּ, וְיָדַע אִי טְעָה וְאִי לָא טְעָה.
human_translation: What is the reason A buyer his merchandise in his possession; anywhere that he goes he shows it and they tell him whether he erred whether he did not err. A seller, who does not have his merchandise in his possession, only merchandise like his merchandise happens to him, and will he know whether he erred or whether he did not err.
llm_translation: What is the reason? He takes his purchase in his hand, wherever he goes, he brings it with him and says to him, "If it is a mistake, or if it is not a mistake." A seller who does not take his purchase in his hands until he is pleased with it like his own purchase, and he knows whether it is a mistake or not.

hebrew_text: הָהוּא גַּבְרָא דַּהֲוָה נָקֵט וַרְשְׁכֵי לְזַבּוֹנֵי, קָרֵי שִׁיתָּא וְשָׁוְיָא חַמְשָׁא, וְאִי הֲווֹ יָהֲבִי לֵיהּ חַמְשָׁא וּפַלְגָא הֲוָה שָׁקֵיל. אֲתָא הָהוּא גַּבְרָא וְאָמַר: אִי יָהֵיבְנָא לֵיהּ חַמְשָׁא וּפַלְגָא הָוְיָא מְחִילָה. אֶתֵּן לֵיהּ שִׁיתָּא וְאֶתְבְּעֵיהּ לְדִינָא. אֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרָבָא, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא בְּלוֹקֵחַ מִן הַתַּגָּר, אֲבָל בְּלוֹקֵחַ מִבַּעַל הַבַּיִת – אֵין לוֹ עָלָיו אוֹנָאָה.
human_translation: a certain man who had silk strips [ varshekhei ] to sell. He announced six and worth five and if they would give him five and a half he would take This man, came and said If I give him five and a half is a waiver, I will give him six and claim him by law came before Rava, said to him: taught only with regard to one who buys from a merchant, but one who buys from homeowner does not have exploitation against him.
llm_translation: That man who used to take and give to the tax collectors, he would read six and write five, and if they gave him five and a half, he would accept it. That man came and said: If they were to give him five and a half, it would be a favor. I will give him six and bring him to court. He came before Rava, who said to him: They only taught this regarding one who buys from the tax collector, but one who buys from the homeowner - he is not subject to ona'ah.

hebrew_text: הָהוּא גַּבְרָא דַּהֲוָה נָקֵיט כִּיפֵּי לְזַבּוֹנֵי קָרֵי שִׁתִּין וְשָׁוֵי חַמְשִׁין, וְאִי הֲווֹ יָהֲבִי לֵיהּ חַמְשִׁין וְחַמְשָׁא הֲוָה שָׁקֵיל. אֲתָא הָהוּא גַּבְרָא וְאָמַר: אִי יָהֵיבְנָא לֵיהּ חַמְשִׁין וְחַמְשָׁא הָוְיָא מְחִילָה, אֶתֵּן לֵיהּ שִׁיתִּין וְאֶתְבְּעֵיהּ לְדִינָא. אֲתָא לְקַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב חִסְדָּא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא בְּלוֹקֵחַ מִן הַתַּגָּר, אֲבָל בְּלוֹקֵחַ מִן בַּעַל הַבַּיִת – אֵין לוֹ עָלָיו אוֹנָאָה.
human_translation: a certain man who was holding jewelry to sell. He announced sixty and worth fifty and if they would give him fifty-five he would take This man, came and said If I give him fifty-five is a waiver, I will give him sixty and claim him by law came before Rav Ḥisda, said to him: taught only with regard to one who buys from a merchant, but one who buys from homeowner does not have exploitation against him.
llm_translation: That man who used to take baskets of figs to the market would call six and weigh five, and if they gave him five, he would take six. That man came and said: If I give him five and he takes six, it is a gift. I will give him six and demand justice. He came before Rav Ḥisda. He said to him: They only taught this regarding one who buys from a merchant, but one who buys from the owner of the house – he has no claim of overreaching.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב דִּימִי: יִשַׁר. וְכֵן אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: יִשַׁר. וְהָא אֲנַן תְּנַן: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁאוֹנָאָה לְהֶדְיוֹט כָּךְ אוֹנָאָה לַתַּגָּר. מַאן הֶדְיוֹט, לָאו בַּעַל הַבַּיִת? אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: בְּצַדְרְיָיתָא. אֲבָל מָאנֵי תַשְׁמִישְׁתֵּיהּ, דְּיַקִּירִי עֲלֵיהּ, לָא מְזַבֵּין לְהוּ אִי לָאו בִּדְמֵי יַתִּירֵי.
human_translation: Rav Dimi said to correct. And likewise, Rabbi Elazar said: correct. But didn’t we learn Just as exploitation to a layman [ lahedyot ], so exploitation to a merchant? Who is layman not a homeowner Rav Ḥisda said: to simple linen garments [ tzadriyyata ], But vessels use which are important to him, he sells them only to extra money,
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Dimi: Yashar. And so said Rabbi Elazar: Yashar. And we learned: Just as there is ona'ah (oppression) towards a commoner, so too there is ona'ah towards a proselyte. Who is a commoner, is it not the homeowner? Rav Chisda said: In the marketplace. But in terms of using his possessions, if they are precious to him, we do not sell them to him, whether at a higher price or at a lower price.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֶחָד הַלּוֹקֵחַ וְאֶחָד הַמּוֹכֵר יֵשׁ לָהֶן אוֹנָאָה. כְּשֵׁם שֶׁאוֹנָאָה לַהֶדְיוֹט כָּךְ אוֹנָאָה לַתַּגָּר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אֵין אוֹנָאָה לַתַּגָּר. מִי שֶׁהוּטַּל עָלָיו – יָדוֹ עַל הָעֶלְיוֹנָה, רָצָה אוֹמֵר לוֹ: תֵּן לִי מְעוֹתַי, אוֹ תֵּן לִי מַה שֶּׁאֹנֵיתַנִי.
human_translation: Both the buyer and the seller are exploitation. Just as exploitation to a layman, so exploitation to a merchant. Rabbi Yehuda says: There is no exploitation for a merchant, The one upon whom was imposed has the advantage. wishes, say to Give me my money or Give me that you exploiting me.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who buys and one who sells are subject to ona'ah (unfair gain or loss). Just as there is ona'ah for a layman, so too there is ona'ah for a proselyte. Rabbi Yehuda says: There is no ona'ah for a proselyte. If one is imposed upon, his hand is on the upper hand, and if he wishes, he can say to him: "Give me my money back, or give me what you overcharged me."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מְנָהָנֵי מִילֵּי? דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״וְכִי תִמְכְּרוּ מִמְכָּר לַעֲמִיתֶךָ ... אַל תּוֹנוּ״ – אֵין לִי אֶלָּא שֶׁנִּתְאַנָּה לוֹקֵחַ, נִתְאַנָּה מוֹכֵר מִנַּיִן? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״אוֹ קָנֹה ... אַל תּוֹנוּ״.
human_translation: From where are these matters As the Sages taught “And if you sell to your colleague an item that is sold, you shall not exploit I have only where a buyer was exploited. From where seller was exploited? The verse states: you shall not exploit
llm_translation: Gemara: What is the case of those who derive benefit from words? For the Rabbis taught: "And if you make a sale to your fellow... do not wrong one another" - I only know that the buyer is warned, from where do we know that the seller is warned? The Torah teaches: "Or acquire... do not wrong one another."

hebrew_text: וְאִיצְטְרִיךְ לְמִכְתַּב לוֹקֵחַ וְאִיצְטְרִיךְ לְמִכְתַּב מוֹכֵר, דְּאִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא מוֹכֵר – מִשּׁוּם דְּקִים לֵיהּ בִּזְבִינְתֵּיהּ, אֲבָל לוֹקֵחַ – דְּלָא קִים לֵיהּ בִּזְבִינְתֵּיהּ, אֵימָא לָא אַזְהֲרֵיהּ רַחֲמָנָא בְּ״לֹא תּוֹנוּ״.
human_translation: And it was necessary to write a buyer, and it was necessary to write a seller. As, had the Merciful One written a seller, because he is certain of his merchandise, but a buyer, who is not certain of merchandise, say the Merciful One did not render prohibited him with “You shall not exploit.”
llm_translation: And it is necessary for a document for the buyer and it is necessary for a document for the seller, for if the Merciful One wrote for the seller - because he is established in his selling, but for the buyer - since he is not established in his buying, lest the Merciful One warn him with "do not wrong."

hebrew_text: וְאִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא לוֹקֵחַ – מִשּׁוּם דְּקָא קָנֵי, דְּאָמְרִי אִינָשֵׁי: זְבַנְתְּ קְנֵית. אֲבָל מוֹכֵר דְּאֹבוֹדֵי קָא מוֹבֵיד, דְּאָמְרִי אִינָשֵׁי: זַבֵּין אוֹבֵיד, אֵימָא לָא אַזְהֲרֵיהּ רַחֲמָנָא בְּ״לֹא תּוֹנוּ״, צְרִיכָא.
human_translation: And had the Merciful One written a buyer, because he acquires as people say: you purchased you acquired But a seller, who loses as people say: sells loses, say the Merciful One did not render prohibited him with “You shall not exploit.” necessary
llm_translation: If the Merciful One wrote "acquires," it is because he acquires, as people say: "You bought, you acquired." But a seller who deceives brings about loss, as people say: "He sold, he caused loss." Therefore, perhaps the Merciful One did not warn against "do not deceive," it is necessary.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אֵין אוֹנָאָה לַתַּגָּר. מִשּׁוּם שֶׁהוּא תַּגָּר אֵין לוֹ אוֹנָאָה?!
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: There is no exploitation for a merchant. Due to that he is a merchant, he is not exploitation?
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda says: There is no ona'ah for a tagar. Because he is a tagar, does he not have ona'ah?!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן אָמַר רַב: בְּתַגָּר סַפְסָר שָׁנוּ. מַאי טַעְמָא – מִידָּע יָדַע זְבִינְתֵּיהּ כַּמָּה שָׁוְיָא, וְאַחוֹלֵי אַחֵיל גַּבֵּיהּ. וְהַאי דְּזַבְּנַהּ הָכִי – מִשּׁוּם דְּאִתְרַמְיָא לֵיהּ זְבִינְתָּא אַחֲרִיתִי.
human_translation: Rav Naḥman says Rav says: with regard to a merchant a trader, they taught What is the reason He knows how much his merchandise is worth, and he waives for And he sells that due to that other merchandise happens to to him
llm_translation: Rav Nahman said in the name of Rav: They taught in the academy of Sapsar. What is the reason? - He knew the value of his merchandise, and he would mix in a little vinegar. And the reason why he would mix in vinegar was because it would preserve the merchandise for a longer time.

hebrew_text: וְהַשְׁתָּא מִיהָא קָא הָדַר בֵּיהּ! רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: מַאי אֵין לַתַּגָּר אוֹנָאָה – אֵינוֹ בְּתוֹרַת אוֹנָאָה, שֶׁאֲפִילּוּ פָּחוֹת מִכְּדֵי אוֹנָאָה חוֹזֵר. תַּנְיָא כְּווֹתֵיהּ דְּרַב נַחְמָן: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר, תַּגָּר אֵין לוֹ אוֹנָאָה, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהוּא בָּקִי.
human_translation: But now, in any event, he retracts Rav Ashi said: What There is no exploitation for a merchant? He is not subject to the principles of exploitation as even less than the measure of exploitation, he may renege It is taught in accordance with of Rav Naḥman: Rabbi Yehuda says: There is no exploitation for a merchant, because he is expert
llm_translation: And now, from it, it is returning! Rav Ashe said: What is the meaning of "there is no ona'ah for a merchant"? It is not in the category of ona'ah, for even if it is less than the amount of ona'ah, it still returns. It was taught in accordance with the opinion of Rav Nachman: Rabbi Yehuda says, a merchant does not have ona'ah, because he is knowledgeable.

hebrew_text: מִי שֶׁהוּטַּל עָלָיו יָדוֹ עַל הָעֶלְיוֹנָה וְכוּ׳. מַנִּי מַתְנִיתִין? לָא רַבִּי נָתָן וְלָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הַנָּשִׂיא.
human_translation: The one upon whom was imposed has the advantage. Whose the mishna? neither Rabbi Natan nor Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi.
llm_translation: One whose hand is resting on the upper part, etc. Who is the Tanna? Not Rabbi Natan and not Rabbi Yehuda the Prince.

hebrew_text: אִי רַבִּי נָתָן – מַתְנִיתִין קָתָנֵי ״רָצָה״, וּבָרַיְיתָא לָא קָתָנֵי ״רָצָה״. אִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הַנָּשִׂיא – מַתְנִיתִין קָתָנֵי ״לוֹקֵחַ״, בָּרַיְיתָא קָתָנֵי ״מוֹכֵר״.
human_translation: If Rabbi Natan, the mishna teaches: wishes, And the baraita does not teach: wishes, if Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, the mishna teaches buyer, the baraita teaches: seller
llm_translation: Talmudic text: If Rabbi Natan - the Mishnah teaches "wants," and the Baraita does not teach "wants." If Rabbi Yehuda the Prince - the Mishnah teaches "buyer," the Baraita teaches "seller."

hebrew_text: (סִימָן זָב רָשׁ)
human_translation: a mnemonic Zayin , beit , reish , shin ,
llm_translation: Chapter of Zav Rash

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: אוֹנָאָה זוֹ אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ מִי שְׁנָאָהּ. רַבָּה אָמַר: לְעוֹלָם רַבִּי נָתָן הִיא, וּתְנִי נָמֵי בְּבָרַיְיתָא ״רָצָה״. רָבָא אָמַר: לְעוֹלָם רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הַנָּשִׂיא הִיא, וּמַאי דְּשַׁיַּיר בְּמַתְנִיתִין קָא מְפָרֵישׁ בְּבָרַיְיתָא. אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: דַּיְקָא נָמֵי, דְּקָתָנֵי ״אֶחָד הַלּוֹקֵחַ וְאֶחָד הַמּוֹכֵר״, וּמְפָרֵשׁ לֵיהּ לְלוֹקֵחַ, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ שַׁיּוֹרֵיה שַׁיְּירֵיהּ לְמוֹכֵר. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar says: this exploitation I do not know who taught it, Rabba said: Actually, is Rabbi Natan, and teach in the baraita as well: wishes. Rava said: Actually, is Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, and that omits in the mishna explicates in the baraita . Rav Ashi said: is also precise, as teaches: Both the buyer and the seller, and elucidate of the buyer. Learn from it omitted of the seller, Learn from it
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar said: I do not know who hated it. Rabbah said: It is always Rabbi Natan, and it is also taught in a baraita "he wanted." Rava said: It is always Rabbi Yehuda the Prince, and what is the reason that he explains in the Mishnah and separates in the baraita. Rav Ashi said: It is very precise, as it teaches "one who takes and one who sells," and he explains it for the buyer, indicating that he leaves it for the seller. This is an indication.

hebrew_text: אִיתְּמַר: הָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ עַל מְנָת שֶׁאֵין לְךָ עָלַי אוֹנָאָה. רַב אָמַר: יֵשׁ לוֹ עָלָיו אוֹנָאָה. וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: אֵין לוֹ עָלָיו אוֹנָאָה. לֵימָא רַב דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר, וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: It was stated one who says to another: on the condition that you have no exploitation against me, Rav says: has exploitation against him, and Shmuel says: He does not have exploitation against him. Let us say Rav stated in accordance with Rabbi Meir, and Shmuel stated in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: It was stated: One who says to his fellow, "On condition that you have no claim against me for ona'ah (unfair advantage)," Rav said: He has a claim against him for ona'ah. And Shmuel said: He has no claim against him for ona'ah. Let us say: Rav, who said this, follows the opinion of Rabbi Meir, and Shmuel, who said this, follows the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא: הָאוֹמֵר לְאִשָּׁה הֲרֵי אַתְּ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת לִי עַל מְנָת שֶׁאֵין לְךָ עָלַי שְׁאֵר כְּסוּת וְעוֹנָה – הֲרֵי זוֹ מְקוּדֶּשֶׁת, וּתְנָאוֹ בָּטֵל, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בְּדָבָר שֶׁבְּמָמוֹן – תְּנָאוֹ קַיָּים.
human_translation: as it is taught one who says to a woman: You are hereby betrothed to me on the condition that you do not have against me food, clothing, and conjugal rights she is betrothed and his condition is void; the statement of Rabbi Meir, And Rabbi Yehuda says: In monetary matters, condition is in effect.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: One who says to a woman, "Behold, you are consecrated to me on the condition that you have no claim against me for maintenance and conjugal rights," she is consecrated, and the condition is void, the words of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: In matters of monetary value, the condition is upheld.

hebrew_text: אָמַר לְךָ רַב: אֲנָא דַּאֲמַרִי אֲפִילּוּ לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה – עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הָתָם, אֶלָּא דְּיָדְעָה וְקָא מָחֲלָה,
human_translation: Rav said to you: I stated even in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, Rabbi Yehuda states only there, where knows but waives
llm_translation: He said to you, Rav: I, who say even according to Rabbi Yehuda - until here Rabbi Yehuda did not say there, but that she knew and forgave.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל הָכָא מִי יָדַע דְּמָחֵיל?
human_translation: But here, does know that waive
llm_translation: But here, who knows that he forgives?

hebrew_text: וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: אֲנָא דַּאֲמַרִי אֲפִילּוּ לְרַבִּי מֵאִיר, עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר רַבִּי מֵאִיר הָתָם, אֶלָּא דְּוַדַּאי קָא עָקַר, אֲבָל הָכָא מִי יֵימַר דְּקָא עָקַר מִידֵּי.
human_translation: And Shmuel says: I state even in accordance with Rabbi Meir, Rabbi Meir states only there, where definitely abrogates But here, who says will abrogate any
llm_translation: Samuel said: I, who said even regarding Rabbi Meir, until here Rabbi Meir did not say there, but surely he uprooted, but here who will say that he uprooted on his own.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב עָנָן: לְדִידִי מִפָּרְשָׁא לִי מִינֵּיהּ דְּמָר שְׁמוּאֵל: הָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״עַל מְנָת שֶׁאֵין לְךָ עָלַי אוֹנָאָה״ – אֵין לוֹ עָלָיו אוֹנָאָה. ״עַל מְנָת שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ אוֹנָאָה״ – הֲרֵי יֵשׁ בּוֹ אוֹנָאָה.
human_translation: Rav Anan says: was explained to me personally by Mar Shmuel. one who says to another: on the condition that you have no exploitation against me, does not have exploitation against him, on the condition that it not exploitation, it is exploitation,
llm_translation: Rav Anan said: According to my understanding, this is the explanation of the statement of Mar Shmuel: One who says to his fellow, "On condition that you have no claim against me for ona'ah (overcharging) - he has no claim of ona'ah against him. "On condition that it has no ona'ah" - behold, it does have ona'ah.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: הַנּוֹשֵׂא וְהַנּוֹתֵן בַּאֲמָנָה, וְהָאוֹמֵר לַחֲבֵירוֹ ״עַל מְנָת שֶׁאֵין לְךָ עָלַי אוֹנָאָה״ – אֵין לוֹ עָלָיו אוֹנָאָה. לְרַב דְּאָמַר: אֲנָא דַּאֲמַרִי אֲפִילּוּ לְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, הָא מַנִּי?
human_translation: raises an objection one who conducts business on faith; and one who says to another: on the condition that you have no exploitation against me, does not have exploitation against According to Rav, who said: I stated even in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, whose this
llm_translation: The Tanna raises an objection: One who lends and one who borrows with a stipulation, and one who says to his fellow, "On the condition that you have no claim against me" - he has no claim against him. According to Rav who said: "I would say this even to Rabbi Yehuda, would he accept it?"

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: מְחַוַּורְתָּא, רַב אָמַר כְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר, וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: Abaye said: clear Rav stated in accordance with Rabbi Meir, and that Shmuel stated in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda,
llm_translation: Abbaye said: Mechavvarta, Rav said like Rabbi Meir, and Shmuel said like Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: לָא קַשְׁיָא, כָּאן – בִּסְתָם, כָּאן – בִּמְפָרֵשׁ.
human_translation: Rava said: not difficult, Here, in an ordinary There, in explicit,
llm_translation: Rava said: Not difficult, here - in general, here - in detail.

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא: בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים – בִּסְתָם. אֲבָל בִּמְפָרֵשׁ, מוֹכֵר שֶׁאָמַר לַלּוֹקֵחַ: חֵפֶץ זֶה שֶׁאֲנִי מוֹכֵר לָךְ בְּמָאתַיִם יוֹדֵעַ אֲנִי בּוֹ שֶׁאֵינוֹ שָׁוֶה אֶלָּא מָנֶה. עַל מְנָת שֶׁאֵין לְךָ עָלַי אוֹנָאָה – אֵין לוֹ עָלָיו אוֹנָאָה. וְכֵן לוֹקֵחַ שֶׁאָמַר לַמּוֹכֵר: חֵפֶץ זֶה שֶׁאֲנִי לוֹקֵחַ מִמְּךָ בְּמָנֶה יוֹדֵעַ אֲנִי בּוֹ שֶׁשָּׁוֶה מָאתַיִם. עַל מְנָת שֶׁאֵין לְךָ עָלַי אוֹנָאָה – אֵין לוֹ עָלָיו אוֹנָאָה.
human_translation: as it is taught In what is this statement said? in an ordinary but in explicit, a seller who said to the buyer: this item that I am selling to you for two hundred I know about it that it is worth only one hundred dinars, on the condition that you have no exploitation against me, has no exploitation against him. And likewise, a buyer who said to the seller: this item that I am buying from you for one hundred dinars, I know about it that it is worth two hundred on the condition that you have no exploitation against me, has no exploitation against him.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: In what case are these matters said? - In a general case. But in a specific case, if a seller said to the buyer: "This item that I am selling to you for two hundred, I know about it that it is only worth a hundred." On the condition that you have no claim of deceit against me - he has no claim of deceit against him. And similarly, if a buyer said to the seller: "This item that I am buying from you for a hundred, I know about it that it is worth two hundred." On the condition that you have no claim of deceit against me - he has no claim of deceit against him.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַנּוֹשֵׂא וְהַנּוֹתֵן בַּאֲמָנָה, הֲרֵי זֶה לֹא יְחַשֵּׁב אֶת הָרַע בַּאֲמָנָה וְאֶת הַיָּפֶה בְּשָׁוֶה. אֶלָּא, אוֹ זֶה וָזֶה בַּאֲמָנָה, אוֹ זֶה וָזֶה בְּשָׁוֶה.
human_translation: The Sages taught: one who conducts business on faith may not calculate the inferior on faith and the superior at value. Rather, Either this and that on faith, or this and that at value.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: One who borrows and one who lends with interest, this one does not consider the evil in borrowing and the good in lending with interest. Rather, either both with interest, or both without interest.

hebrew_text: וְנוֹתֵן לוֹ שְׂכַר כַּתָּף, שְׂכַר גַּמָּל, שְׂכַר פּוּנְדָּק. שְׂכַר עַצְמוֹ – אֵינוֹ נוֹטֵל, שֶׁכְּבָר נָתַן לוֹ שְׂכָרוֹ מִשָּׁלֵם.
human_translation: And gives the payment a porter, the payment a camel driver the payment lodgings own wages, he does not take as already gave him his full wages.
llm_translation: And he gives him reward of shoulder, reward of camel, reward of innkeeper. Reward of his bone - he does not take, for he has already given him his reward from the beginning.

hebrew_text: שְׂכָרוֹ מִשָּׁלֵם מֵהֵיכָא קָא יָהֵיב לֵיהּ? אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: בְּצַדְרוֹיֵי, דְּיָהֲבִי אַרְבַּע לִמְאָה.
human_translation: his wages in full, from where did he give him? Rav Pappa said: to sellers of inexpensive garments, where gives four for one hundred
llm_translation: The reward, from where is it given to him? Rav Papa said: From the side, for he gives four out of a hundred.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ כַּמָּה תְּהֵא הַסֶּלַע חֲסֵירָה וְלֹא יְהֵא בָּהּ אוֹנָאָה? רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: אַרְבַּע אִיסָּרוֹת, אִיסָּר לְדִינָר. וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אַרְבַּע פּוּנְדְּיוֹנוֹת, פּוּנְדְּיוֹן לְדִינָר. וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר:
human_translation: How much can the sela be eroded and will not constitute exploitation? Rabbi Meir says: four issar , issar per dinar, And Rabbi Yehuda says: four pundeyon , pundeyon per dinar, And Rabbi Shimon says:
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: How much should the deficiency in a rock be, such that it does not contain any deceit? Rabbi Meir says: Four Isar coins, an Isar being a denomination of a Dinar. And Rabbi Yehuda says: Four Pundeyon coins, a Pundeyon being a denomination of a Dinar. And Rabbi Shimon says:

hebrew_text: שְׁמוֹנָה פּוּנְדְּיוֹנוֹת, שְׁנֵי פּוּנְדְּיוֹנוֹת לְדִינָר.
human_translation: eight pundeyon , two pundeyon per dinar,
llm_translation: Eight Pundiyonot, two Pundiyonot for a Dinar.

hebrew_text: עַד מָתַי מוּתָּר לְהַחְזִיר? בִּכְרַכִּים – עַד כְּדֵי שֶׁיַּרְאֶה לַשּׁוּלְחָנִי, בִּכְפָרִים – עַד עַרְבֵי שַׁבָּתוֹת. אִם הָיָה מַכִּירָהּ – אֲפִילּוּ לְאַחַר שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר חֹדֶשׁ מְקַבְּלָהּ הֵימֶנּוּ, וְאֵין לוֹ עָלָיו אֶלָּא תַּרְעוֹמֶת.
human_translation: Until when permitted to return In the cities [ bakerakim ], until a period that show to a money changer, In the villages, until Shabbat eves, if recognized it, he must accept it from him even after twelve months And he has only a grievance against him,
llm_translation: Until when is it permissible to return a lost item? In cities - until the time he the owner can be seen at the marketplace, in villages - until the eve of Shabbatot. If he recognizes her the lost item - even after twelve months he may accept it from him, and he the finder has nothing on him except a curse.

hebrew_text: וְנוֹתְנָהּ לְמַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי וְאֵינוֹ חוֹשֵׁשׁ, שֶׁאֵינוֹ אֶלָּא נֶפֶשׁ רָעָה.
human_translation: And may give for of second-tithe and he not be concerned, as is merely a miserly soul,
llm_translation: And she shall give it to the second tithe, and it is not a concern, for it is only a wicked soul.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ וּרְמִינְהִי: עַד כַּמָּה תְּהֵא הַסֶּלַע חֲסֵירָה וְיִהְיֶה בָּהּ אוֹנָאָה?
human_translation: And raises a contradiction How much the sela be eroded so will constitute exploitation?
llm_translation: Gemara and we raised a dilemma: Until how much should the rock be deficient and still have interest in it?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא, לָא קַשְׁיָא: תַּנָּא דִּידַן קָא חָשֵׁיב מִמַּטָּה לְמַעְלָה, תַּנָּא בָּרָא קָא חָשֵׁיב מִלְּמַעְלָה לְמַטָּה.
human_translation: Rav Pappa says: not difficult. The tanna of our calculates from low to high. the external tanna , calculates from high to low.
llm_translation: Rav Papa said, it is not difficult: our Mishnah considers from below upwards, while the Mishnah of Bara considers from above downwards.

hebrew_text: מַאי שְׁנָא בְּסֶלַע דִּפְלִיגִי, וּמַאי שְׁנָא בְּטַלִּית דְּלָא פְּלִיגִי?
human_translation: What is different with regard to a sela , that disagree and what is different with regard to a garment, that do not disagree
llm_translation: What is the difference in the case of the rock over which they argue, and what is the difference in the case of the garment over which they do not argue?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: מַאן תְּנָא טַלִּית – רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הִיא. אַבָּיֵי אָמַר: טַלִּית – עַד שְׁתוּת מָחֵיל אִינִישׁ. דְּאָמְרִי אִינָשֵׁי: עֲשִׁיק לְגַבָּיךְ וְשָׁוֵי לִכְרֵסָיךְ. סֶלַע, כֵּיוָן דְּלָא סַגִּי לֵיהּ – לָא מָחֵיל.
human_translation: Rava said: Who taught a garment It is Rabbi Shimon, Abaye said a garment, a person to waive up to one-sixth, as people say: Overpay for your back, and at cost for your stomach, sela since it does not circulate, he does not waive
llm_translation: Rava said: Who is the Tanna that teaches "Talit"? - It is Rabbi Shimon. Abbaye said: "Talit" - until one wraps himself with it. For people say: "Put pressure on your body and sit on your bed." A rock, since it does not reach him - it does not wrap him.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא: עַד כַּמָּה תְּהֵא הַסֶּלַע חֲסֵירָה וִיהֵא בָּהּ אוֹנָאָה? רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: אַרְבָּעָה אִיסָּרוֹת, אִיסָּר לְדִינָר. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אַרְבָּעָה פּוּנְדְּיוֹנוֹת, פּוּנְדְּיוֹן לְדִינָר. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: שְׁמוֹנָה פּוּנְדְּיוֹנוֹת, שְׁנֵי פּוּנְדְיוֹנִים לְדִינָר. יָתֵר עַל כֵּן – מוֹכְרָהּ בְּשׇׁוְיָהּ.
human_translation: the itself, How much will the sela be eroded and will constitute exploitation? Rabbi Meir says: Four issar , an issar per dinar. Rabbi Yehuda says: Four pundeyon , a pundeyon per dinar. Rabbi Shimon says: Eight pundeyon , two pundeyon per dinar. greater than that, he may sell at its value
llm_translation: Body: Until how much should the rock be deficient and still contain ona? Rabbi Meir says: four issarot, an issar to a dinar. Rabbi Yehuda says: four pundeyonot, a pundeyon to a dinar. Rabbi Shimon says: eight pundeyonot, two pundeyonim to a dinar. Beyond this – one may sell it at its equal value.

hebrew_text: עַד כַּמָּה תִּיפָּחֵת וִיהֵא רַשַּׁאי לְקַיְּימָהּ? בְּסֶלַע – עַד שֶׁקֶל. בְּדִינָר – עַד רוֹבַע. פָּחוֹת מִכֵּן אִיסָּר – אָסוּר לְהוֹצִיאָהּ. הֲרֵי זֶה לֹא יִמְכְּרֶנָּה לֹא לַתַּגָּר וְלֹא לְחָרָם וְלֹא לְהָרָג, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמְּרַמִּין בָּהּ אֶת אֲחֵרִים. אֶלָּא יִקֳּבֶנָּה וְיִתְלֶנָּה בְּצַוַּאר בְּנוֹ אוֹ בְּצַוַּאר בִּתּוֹ.
human_translation: To extent can the coin erode and it will be permitted to maintain it With regard to a sela , until one shekel, With regard to a dinar, until one-quarter. an issar less than that, prohibited to spend it. He may not sell to a merchant, nor to a violent man, nor to a murderer, because they deceive others with it Rather, he should perforate it and suspend it on the neck of his son or the neck of his daughter.
llm_translation: Until how much should one inflate it and it should be fit to uphold it? In a rock - until a shekel. In a dinar - until a quarter. Less than that - it is forbidden to take it out. This one should not sell it neither to a peddler, nor to a gentile, nor to a murderer, because they deceive others with it. Rather, let him puncture it and hang it around the neck of his son or the neck of his daughter.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: בְּסֶלַע עַד שֶׁקֶל, בְּדִינָר עַד רוֹבַע. מַאי שְׁנָא בְּסֶלַע עַד שֶׁקֶל, וּמַאי שְׁנָא בְּדִינָר עַד רוֹבַע?
human_translation: The Master said: With regard to a sela , until one shekel, With regard to a dinar, until one-quarter. What is different with regard to a sela , until one shekel, and what is different with regard to a dinar, until one-quarter [ rova ]?
llm_translation: Master said: In a selah up to a shekel, in a dinar up to a quarter. What is the difference between a selah up to a shekel, and what is the difference between a dinar up to a quarter?

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: מַאי ״רוֹבַע״ דְּקָתָנֵי – נָמֵי רוֹבַע שֶׁקֶל. אָמַר רָבָא: דַּיְקָא נָמֵי, דְּקָא תָּנֵי ״רוֹבַע״, וְלָא קָתָנֵי ״רְבִיעַ״. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: Abaye says: What rova that teaches? too one-quarter of a shekel, Rava said: is also precise as teaches rova and does not teach one-quarter [ revia ]. Learn from
llm_translation: Abaye said: What is the meaning of "rova" that is taught? - Yes, a rova of a shekel. Rava said: Indeed, it is precise, for it teaches "rova" and not "revi'ah." Learn from it.

hebrew_text: לְמָה לֵיהּ לְמִתְלְיֵיהּ לְדִינָר בְּשֶׁקֶל? מִלְּתָא אַגַּב אוֹרְחֵיהּ קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן, דְּאִיכָּא דִּינָר דְּאָתֵי מִשֶּׁקֶל.
human_translation: Why a dinar is dependent on a shekel? teaches us a matter in passing, that there are a dinar originates from a shekel,
llm_translation: "Why does he need to exchange a dinar for a shekel? The matter is clear from his behavior, as there is a dinar that comes from a shekel."

hebrew_text: מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי אַמֵּי. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אַמֵּי: דִּינָר הַבָּא מִשֶּׁקֶל – מוּתָּר לְקַיְּימוֹ. דִּינָר הַבָּא מִסֶּלַע – אָסוּר לְקַיְּימוֹ.
human_translation: supports of Rabbi Ami, as Rabbi Ami says: a dinar that originated from a shekel, it is permitted to maintain it a dinar that originated from a sela , it is prohibited to maintain it
llm_translation: Assists him to Rabbi Ammi. For Rabbi Ammi said: A dinar that comes from a weight - permitted to fulfill it. A dinar that comes from a rock - forbidden to fulfill it.

hebrew_text: פָּחוֹת מִכֵּן אִיסָּר – אָסוּר לְהוֹצִיאָהּ. מַאי קָאָמַר? אָמַר אַבָּיֵי, הָכִי קָאָמַר: פָּחֲתָה סֶלַע יוֹתֵר מִכְּדֵי אוֹנָאָה אִיסָּר – אָסוּר. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא: אִי הָכִי – אֲפִילּוּ מַשֶּׁהוּ נָמֵי! אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: פָּחֲתָה סֶלַע אִיסָּר לְדִינָר – אָסוּר, וּסְתָמָא כְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר.
human_translation: an issar less than that, prohibited to spend it. What is saying Abaye said this is saying: a sela eroded an issar greater than the measure of exploitation, prohibited Rava said to If so, even any amount as well. Rather, Rava said a sela eroded an issar per dinar, prohibited and unattributed in accordance with Rabbi Meir,
llm_translation: Less than this - forbidden to take out. What is it saying? Abaye said, this is what it is saying: If a rock has diminished more than the value of a perutah - it is forbidden. Rava said to him: If so - even a little bit too! Rather Rava said: If a rock has diminished to the value of a dinar - it is forbidden, and the default is like Rabbi Meir.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן הָתָם: סֶלַע שֶׁנִּפְסְלָה וְהִתְקִינָהּ שֶׁיְּהֵא שׁוֹקֵל בָּהּ מִשְׁקָלוֹת – טְמֵאָה. עַד כַּמָּה תִּיפָּחֵת וִיהֵא רַשַּׁאי לְקַיְּימָהּ? (לַסֶּלַע) שְׁנֵי דִּינָרִים, פָּחוֹת מִכֵּן – יָקוֹץ.
human_translation: We learned there A sela that was invalidated and designated it so that he would weigh with it weighing, ritually impure. To extent can the coin erode and will be permitted to maintain it? For a sela , two dinars, less than that, he must cut
llm_translation: We learned there: A rock that was chiseled and set up to weigh with it weights - it is impure. Until how much should it be chipped away and it is fit to be upheld? (Regarding the rock) two dinars, less than that - it is invalid.

hebrew_text: יָתֵר עַל כֵּן מַאי? אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: פָּחוֹת מִכֵּן – יָקוֹץ, יָתֵר עַל כֵּן – יָקוֹץ. רַבִּי אַמֵּי אָמַר: פָּחוֹת מִכֵּן – יָקוֹץ, יָתֵר עַל כֵּן – יְקַיֵּים.
human_translation: greater than what Rav Huna says: less than he must cut more than that he must cut Rabbi Ami says: less than he must cut more than that he may maintain
llm_translation: "Yather al kein mai? Amar Rav Huna: Pachot mikain - yakotz, yather al kein - yakotz. Rabbi Amei Amar: Pachot mikain - yakotz, yather al kein - yekayem."

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי:
human_translation: raises an objection
llm_translation: Challenger:

hebrew_text: יָתֵר עַל כֵּן מוֹכְרָהּ בְּשׇׁוְיָהּ. מַאי לָאו: שֶׁפָּחֲתָה יוֹתֵר מִכְּדֵי אוֹנָאָתָהּ? לָא, יְתֵירָה: דְּאַכַּתִּי לָא פָּחֲתָה בִּכְדֵי אוֹנָאָתָהּ, מוֹכְרָהּ בְּשׇׁוְיָהּ.
human_translation: greater than that, he may sell at its value What, not that it eroded more than its measure of exploitation? No, greater that it did not yet erode to its measure of exploitation, he may sell it at its value.
llm_translation: Excessively, therefore, she sells it in its worth. What is the reason? Is it not that she diminished more than its value or its oppression? No, it is excessive, for I have seen that she did not diminish in its value or its oppression, she sells it in its worth.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיבִי: עַד כַּמָּה תִּיפָּחֵת, וִיהֵא רַשַּׁאי לְקַיְּימָהּ? בְּסֶלַע – עַד שֶׁקֶל. מַאי לָאו דִּפְחַית פּוּרְתָּא פּוּרְתָּא! לָא, דִּנְפִיל לְנוּרָא וְאִפְּחִית בַּחֲדָא זִימְנָא.
human_translation: objection was raised: To extent can erode and be permitted to maintain it? For a sela up to a shekel, not mean that depreciated little by little, No, that fell into the fire and eroded all at once,
llm_translation: The text states: A question was raised: Until how much may one blow, and still be able to fulfill the obligation? In a rock - until a handbreadth. What is the reason that you do not blow a little by little? Not so, for it may fall into the fire and you will blow all at once.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: יִקֳּבֶנָּה וְיִתְלֶנָּה בְּצַוַּאר בְּנוֹ אוֹ בְּצַוַּאר בִּתּוֹ. וּרְמִינְהוּ: לֹא יַעֲשֶׂנָּה מִשְׁקָל בֵּין מִשְׁקְלוֹתָיו, וְלֹא יִזְרְקֶנָּה בֵּין גְּרוּטוֹתָיו, וְלֹא יִקֳּבֶנָּה וְיִתְלֶנָּה בְּצַוַּאר בְּנוֹ וּבְצַוַּאר בִּתּוֹ. אֶלָּא: אוֹ יִשְׁחוֹק, אוֹ יִתּוֹךְ, אוֹ יָקוֹץ, אוֹ יוֹלִיךְ לְיָם הַמֶּלַח!
human_translation: The Master said he should perforate it, and suspend it on the neck of his son or the neck of his daughter. And raises a contradiction one should not make it a weight among his weights, nor cast it among his scraps [ gerutotav ], nor perforate it and suspend it on the neck of his son or the neck of his daughter, Rather, either grind or melt or cut or take into the Dead Sea.
llm_translation: Master said: Let him pierce it and hang it on the neck of his son or on the neck of his daughter. And they raised an objection: He should not make it a weight between his weights, and he should not throw it between his pebbles, and he should not pierce it and hang it on the neck of his son or on the neck of his daughter. Rather, he should either grind it, or melt it, or scatter it, or throw it into the Dead Sea!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ רַב הוּנָא אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן – בָּאֶמְצַע, כָּאן – מִן הַצַּד.
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar said, and some say Rav Huna Rabbi Elazar said: not difficult. Here, in the middle, there, from the side.
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Elazar, and some say it was Rav Huna who said in the name of Rabbi Elazar, it is not difficult: here - in the middle, here - on the side.

hebrew_text: עַד מָתַי מוּתָּר לְהַחֲזִיר בִּכְרַכִּים? עַד שֶׁיַּרְאֶה לַשּׁוּלְחָנִי. בִּכְפָרִים? עַד עַרְבֵי שַׁבָּתוֹת. מַאי שְׁנָא בְּסֶלַע דִּמְפַלֵּיג, וּמַאי שְׁנָא בְּטַלִּית דְּלָא מְפַלֵּיג?
human_translation: Until when permitted to return In the cities, until a period that show to a money changer, In the villages, until Shabbat eves, What is different with regard to a sela whereby distinguishes and what is different with regard to a garment whereby he does not distinguish
llm_translation: Until when is it permitted to return in bundles? Until he sees the sender. In villages? Until the eve of Shabbatot. What is the difference with a rock that splits, and what is the difference with a garment that does not split?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר אַבָּיֵי: כִּי תְּנַן נָמֵי מַתְנִיתִין – בְּטַלִּית בִּכְרַכִּין תְּנַן. רָבָא אָמַר: טַלִּית, כֹּל אִינִישׁ קִים לֵיהּ בְּגַוַּהּ. סֶלַע, כֵּיוָן דְּלָאו כֹּל אִינִישׁ קִים לֵיהּ בְּגַוַּהּ אֶלָּא שׁוּלְחָנִי, הִלְכָּךְ בִּכְרַכִּים דְּאִיכָּא שׁוּלְחָנִי – עַד שֶׁיַּרְאֶה לַשּׁוּלְחָנִי. בִּכְפָרִים דְּלֵיכָּא שׁוּלְחָנִי – עַד עַרְבֵי שַׁבָּתוֹת דְּסָלְקִין לְשׁוּקָא.
human_translation: Abaye said: When we learned the mishna with regard to a garment as well, with regard to the cities we learned Rava said: a garment, every person is certain with regard to its a sela , since not every person is certain with regard to its rather a money changer therefore, in the cities, where there is a money changer until a period that show to a money changer. In the villages, where there is no money changer until Shabbat eves, when go to the market,
llm_translation: Abaye said: When we learned the Mishnah, we learned about folding the garment in the crevices. Rava said: A garment, everyone is careful with it in the crevices. A rock, since not everyone is careful with it in the crevices except a table, therefore in crevices where there is a table - until it is visible to the table. In villages where there is no table - until the eve of Sabbaths when they go out to the market.

hebrew_text: וְאִם הָיָה מַכִּירָהּ אֲפִילּוּ לְאַחַר שְׁנֵים עָשָׂר חֹדֶשׁ כּוּ׳. הֵיכָא? אִי בִּכְרַכִּין, הָא אָמְרַתְּ עַד שֶׁיַּרְאֶה לַשּׁוּלְחָנִי. אִי בִּכְפָרִים, הָא אָמְרַתְּ עַד עַרְבֵי שַׁבָּתוֹת!
human_translation: And if recognized it, he must accept it from him even after twelve months Where If in the cities, didn’t you say until a period that show to a money changer? If in the villages, didn’t you say until Shabbat eves?
llm_translation: And if he recognized her even after twelve months. Where? If in villages, didn't you say until he sees the Shulchan? If in cities, didn't you say until the eve of Shabbatot!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: מִידַּת חֲסִידוּת שָׁנוּ כָּאן. אִי הָכִי, אֵימָא סֵיפָא: אֵין לוֹ עָלָיו אֶלָּא תַּרְעוֹמֶת. לְמַאן? אִי לְחָסִיד – לָא קַבּוֹלֵי לִיקַבְּלַהּ מִינֵּיהּ, וְלָא תַּרְעוֹמֶת תֶּיהְוֵי לֵיהּ. וְאֶלָּא לְהַאיְךְ דְּקַבְּלַהּ מִינֵּיהּ, וּלְבָתַר דִּמְקַבְּלַהּ מִינֵּיהּ – תַּרְעוֹמֶת תֶּיהְוֵי לֵיהּ?
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: taught an attribute of piety here, If so, say the latter clause And he has only a grievance against him. For whom If for the pious let him not accept from him and let him not have a grievance. Rather, to that from whom he accepted But after accepts from him, will have a grievance?
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisdah said: The measure of piety they taught here. If so, say the latter clause: He has nothing upon him except arrogance. According to whom? If for a pious person – they do not accept to receive it from him, and arrogance will be to him. Rather, for this one who they accept to receive it from him, and after they accept to receive it from him – arrogance will be to him?

hebrew_text: הָכִי קָאָמַר: הָא אַחֵר, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁאֵין מְקַבְּלָהּ הֵימֶנּוּ – אֵין לוֹ עָלָיו אֶלָּא תַּרְעוֹמֶת.
human_translation: this is saying: But another although he does not accept from him has only a grievance against him.
llm_translation: So it is stated: This other one, even though she does not accept him - he only has upon her a terumah.

hebrew_text: וְנוֹתְנָהּ לְמַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי, וְאֵינוֹ חוֹשֵׁשׁ, שֶׁאֵינוֹ אֶלָּא נֶפֶשׁ רָעָה. אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: הַאי מַאן דְּמוֹקֵים אַזּוּזֵי, מִיקְּרֵי נֶפֶשׁ רָעָה. וְהָנֵי מִילֵּי הוּא דְּסָגֵי לְהוּ.
human_translation: And may give for of second-tithe and he not be concerned, as is merely a miserly soul, Rav Pappa said: Conclude from this one who insists upon his coins is characterized as a miserly soul. And this matter only if circulate.
llm_translation: And she shall be given to the second tithe, and it is not a concern, for it is only a wicked person. Rav Papa said, infer from it: Whoever uproots the coins, is called a wicked person. And these matters suffice for them.

hebrew_text: מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ לְחִזְקִיָּה, דְּאָמַר חִזְקִיָּה: בָּא לְפוֹרְטָהּ – פּוֹרְטָהּ בְּשׇׁוְיָהּ, בָּא לְחַלְּלָהּ – מְחַלְּלָהּ בְּיָפָה.
human_translation: supports of Ḥizkiyya, as Ḥizkiyya says: comes to change he changes it for its value, comes to desacralize he desacralizes with an unflawed [ beyafa ]
llm_translation: He helps him to Hezekiah, for Hezekiah said: If one comes to divide it - divide it with its value, if one comes to desecrate it - desecrate it beautifully.

hebrew_text: מַאי קָאָמַר? הָכִי קָאָמַר: אַף עַל פִּי כְּשֶׁבָּא לְפוֹרְטָהּ – פּוֹרְטָהּ בְּשׇׁוְיָהּ, כְּשֶׁהוּא מְחַלְּלָהּ – מְחַלְּלָהּ בְּיָפָה.
human_translation: What is saying? this is saying: Although when he comes to change he changes it for its value, when he desacralizes he desacralizes with an unflawed
llm_translation: What is it saying? This is what it is saying: Even though when he comes to exempt it - he exempts it with its blemish, when he profanes it - he profanes it with its beauty.

hebrew_text: לְמֵימְרָא דְּסָבַר חִזְקִיָּה דִּמְזַלְזְלִינַן בְּמַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי? וְהָאָמַר חִזְקִיָּה: מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה, אוֹמֵר: הוּא וְחוּמְשׁוֹ מְחוּלָּל עַל מָעוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנוֹת. לְפִי שֶׁאִי אֶפְשָׁר לוֹ לְאָדָם לְצַמְצֵם מְעוֹתָיו!
human_translation: to say that Ḥizkiyya holds that we treat second tithe with contempt, But doesn’t Ḥizkiyya say: second-tithe that does not have the value of one peruta says: and its one-fifth desacralized upon the first coins because it is impossible for a person to be precise his coins?
llm_translation: In the matter of the opinion of Hezekiah who holds that we may treat lightly the second tithe? And Hezekiah said: Regarding a second tithe that does not contain a perutah, he says: It and its fifth are redeemed with the money of the first tithe, because it is impossible for a person to diminish his money!

hebrew_text: מַאי ״בְּיָפָה״, בְּתוֹרַת יָפָה. דִּתְרֵי זִילֵי לָא מְזַלְזְלִינַן בֵּיהּ.
human_translation: What beyafa ? unflawed status, as we do not treat two contempt.
llm_translation: What is "in beauty," in the Torah of beauty. Two students do not treat it lightly.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא. אָמַר חִזְקִיָּה: מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה, אוֹמֵר: ״הוּא וְחוּמְשׁוֹ מְחוּלָּל עַל מָעוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנוֹת״, לְפִי שֶׁאִי אֶפְשָׁר לוֹ לְאָדָם לְצַמְצֵם מְעוֹתָיו.
human_translation: the itself. Ḥizkiyya said: second-tithe that does not have the value of one peruta says: and its one-fifth desacralized upon the first coins because it is impossible for a person to be precise his coins.
llm_translation: Body. Hizkiyah said: A second tithe that does not contain a perutah, he says: "It and its fifth are redeemed with the first coins," because it is impossible for a person to diminish his coins.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: הַתְּרוּמָה וְהַבִּיכּוּרִים חַיָּיבִין עֲלֵיהֶן מִיתָה וָחוֹמֶשׁ,
human_translation: raises an objection teruma and first fruits, is liable to death for them and one-fifth
llm_translation: Challenger: The terumah and the bikkurim are liable for them death and a fifth.

hebrew_text: וַאֲסוּרִים לְזָרִים, וְהֵן נִכְסֵי כֹהֵן, וְעוֹלִים בְּאֶחָד וּמֵאָה, וּטְעוּנִין רְחִיצַת יָדַיִם וְהֶעֱרֵב שֶׁמֶשׁ. הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ בִּתְרוּמָה וּבִכּוּרִים, מַה שֶּׁאֵין כֵּן בַּמַּעֲשֵׂר.
human_translation: And is prohibited to non-priests; and they are the property of the priest and they are negated one in one hundred and they require the washing of hands and sunset These with regard to teruma and first fruits, which is not so with regard to tithe.
llm_translation: Forbidden to non-priests, and they are the possessions of a priest, and they ascend in one hundred, and they require handwashing and the mixing of the sun. These are in the category of terumah and first fruits, which is not the case with tithes.

hebrew_text: מַאי ״מַה שֶּׁאֵין כֵּן בַּמַּעֲשֵׂר״ – לָאו מִכְּלָל דְּמַעֲשֵׂר בָּטֵיל בְּרוּבָּא? וְאִם אִיתָא דְּחִזְקִיָּה, הֲוָה לֵיהּ דָּבָר שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ מַתִּירִין. וְכׇל דָּבָר שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ מַתִּירִין, אֲפִילּוּ בְּאֶלֶף לֹא בָּטֵיל!
human_translation: What Which is not so with regard to tithe? not, by inference, that tithe is negated in a majority And if it is so that Ḥizkiyya is an item whose has permitting and any item whose has permitting not negated even with one thousand
llm_translation: "What is 'that which is not so with tithing'? - Is it not from the inference that tithing is nullified by the majority? And if it is said that it is according to Hezekiah, he had a matter that has those who permit it. And any matter that has those who permit it, even if it is in a thousand, is not nullified!"

hebrew_text: וּמִמַּאי דְּמַה שֶּׁאֵין כֵּן בַּמַּעֲשֵׂר – דְּבָטֵיל בְּרוּבָּא? דִּלְמָא לָא בָּטֵיל כְּלָל! לָא מָצֵית אָמְרַתְּ הָכִי, דִּלְגַבֵּי תְּרוּמָה – חוּמְרֵי דִתְרוּמָה קָתָנֵי, קוּלֵּי דִתְרוּמָה לָא קָתָנֵי. וְהָא קָא תָנֵי: וְהֵן נִכְסֵי כֹהֵן!
human_translation: And from where Which is not so with regard to tithe, that negated in majority? Perhaps is not negated at all. You cannot say so, as with regard to teruma , is teaching the stringencies of teruma he is not teaching the leniencies of teruma . But doesn’t teach: And they are the property of the priest,
llm_translation: And from what is it derived that it is not so regarding tithing - that it is nullified in the majority? Perhaps it is not nullified at all! You did not find that it was stated thus, that in comparison to terumah - the stringencies of terumah are taught, the leniencies of terumah are not taught. And it teaches there: "And these are the possessions of the kohen!"

hebrew_text: לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דְּתַנְיָא בְּהֶדְיָא: מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי בָּטֵיל בְּרוּבָּא. וּבְאֵיזֶה מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי אָמְרוּ – בְּמַעֲשֵׂר שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה, וְשֶׁנִּכְנַס לִירוּשָׁלַיִם וְיָצָא. וְאִם אִיתָא לִדְחִזְקִיָּה, לֶיעְבֵּד לֵיהּ לִדְחִזְקִיָּה, וְנִיחַלְּלֵיהּ עַל מָעוֹת הָרִאשׁוֹנוֹת! דְּלָא פָּרֵיק.
human_translation: not enter your mind, as it is taught explicitly Second tithe is negated in majority. And with regard to which second tithe did say with regard to tithe that is not worth one peruta , and which entered Jerusalem and exited. And if it is so that of Ḥizkiyya let him take action according to Ḥizkiyya and redeem upon the first coins. where he did not redeem
llm_translation: Your request is beyond my capabilities.

hebrew_text: וְנַיְתֵי מַעֲשֵׂר דְּאִית לֵיהּ (וְנִצְטָרְפִינְהוּ) [וּנְצָרֵף]! דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא וּדְרַבָּנַן לָא מִצְטָרְפִי.
human_translation: And let him bring tithe that he has, and join it by Torah law and by rabbinic law do not join.
llm_translation: And the tithe that it has, (and they are combined) and it is combined! From the Torah and from the Rabbis, they do not combine.

hebrew_text: וְנַיְתֵי דְּמַאי! דִּלְמָא אָתֵי לְאֵתוֹיֵי וַדַּאי.
human_translation: And let him bring doubtfully tithed produce [ demai ], lest he come to bring definitely
llm_translation: And the question of what? Perhaps it will come to negate and certainly.

hebrew_text: וְנַיְתֵי שְׁתֵּי פְרוּטוֹת, וּנְחַלֵּל עֲלַיְיהוּ מַעֲשֵׂר בִּפְרוּטָה וּמֶחֱצָה, וּנְחַלֵּל הַאי עַל הַיְאךְ יַתִּירָא. מִי סָבְרַתְּ: פְּרוּטָה וּמֶחֱצָה תָּפְסָה שְׁתֵּי פְרוּטוֹת? לָא. פְּרוּטָה תָּפְסָה פְּרוּטָה, וַחֲצִי פְּרוּטָה לָא תָּפְסָה. הֲדַר הָוְיָא לֵיהּ דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא וּדְרַבָּנַן. וּדְאוֹרָיְיתָא וּדְרַבָּנַן לָא מִצְטָרְפִי.
human_translation: And let him bring two perutot and desacralize tithe one and a half perutot upon them, and desacralize this upon that remaining Do you hold one and a half perutot takes effect two perutot ? No, one peruta takes effect one peruta and half- peruta does not take effect again becomes by Torah law and by rabbinic law, and by Torah law and by rabbinic law do not join.
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "And if two prutot are left, and one tithes on them a ma'aser from a prutah and a half, and this one is tithed in what way is it more? Who holds that a prutah and a half can acquire two prutot? No. A prutah can acquire a prutah, but it cannot acquire half a prutah. Therefore, it should be considered both biblically and rabbinically. But biblically and rabbinically do not combine."

hebrew_text: וְנַיְתֵי אִיסָּר! דִּלְמָא אָתֵי לְאֵתוֹיֵי פְּרוּטוֹת.
human_translation: And let him bring an issar , lest he come to bring perutot
llm_translation: And the question of Issar! Perhaps he will come to bring details.

hebrew_text: וְשֶׁנִּכְנַס לִירוּשָׁלַיִם וְיָצָא. וְאַמַּאי: וְלִיהְדַּר וּנְעַיְּילֵיהּ! בְּשֶׁנִּטְמָא. וְנִפְרְקֵיהּ! דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: מִנַּיִן לְמַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי שֶׁנִּטְמָא, שֶׁפּוֹדִין אוֹתוֹ
human_translation: And which entered Jerusalem and exited. And why Let him bring it back that became ritually impure But let him redeem it, As Rabbi Elazar says: From where with regard to second-tithe that became ritually impure that one may redeem it
llm_translation: When he enters Jerusalem and leaves. And why? To honor and accompany him! When he becomes impure. And he is exempt! For Rabbi Elazar said: From where do we derive the law of the second tithe that became impure, that we redeem it.

hebrew_text: אֲפִילּוּ בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם – שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי לֹא תוּכַל שְׂאֵתוֹ״, וְאֵין ״שְׂאֵת״ אֶלָּא אֲכִילָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיִּשָּׂא מַשְׂאֹת מֵאֵת פָּנָיו״.
human_translation: even in Jerusalem, as it is stated: “For you are unable to carry [ se’et ] it… And se’et means nothing other than eating, as it is stated: “And he took portions [ masot ] from before him”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Even in Jerusalem - as it is stated: "for you may not eat it," and "eating" is nothing but "lifting," as it is stated: "and he lifted offerings from before him." English translation:

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא בְּלָקוּחַ בְּכֶסֶף מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי. לָקוּחַ בְּכֶסֶף מַעֲשֵׂר נָמֵי לִיפְרְקֵיהּ, דִּתְנַן: הַלָּקוּחַ בְּכֶסֶף מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי שֶׁנִּטְמָא – יִפָּדֶה! כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה דְּאָמַר יִקָּבֵר.
human_translation: Rather, with regard to acquired with second-tithe money, acquired with second-tithe money too, let him redeem it, as we learned acquired with second-tithe money that became ritually impure should be redeemed. in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, who says: must be buried
llm_translation: Rather, with a purchase for silver of the second tithe. A purchase for silver of the second tithe is necessary to redeem it, as we learned: If one purchased with silver the second tithe which became ritually impure - it must be redeemed! Like Rabbi Yehuda who said it should be buried.

hebrew_text: אִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, מַאי אִירְיָא ״יָצָא״? אֲפִילּוּ לֹא יָצָא נָמֵי, אֶלָּא: לְעוֹלָם בְּטָהוֹר, וּמַאי ״יָצָא״ – דִּנְפוּל מְחִיצוֹת.
human_translation: If Rabbi Yehuda, why specifically exited Even did not exit also Rather, actually, with regard to ritually pure, and what exited? where the partitions, fell.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda said: What is the meaning of "he went out"? Even if he did not actually go out, rather: forever in a state of purity. And what is "he went out"? That he fell from partitions.

hebrew_text: וְהָאָמַר רָבָא: מְחִיצָה לֶאֱכוֹל – דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, מְחִיצוֹת לִקְלוֹט – דְּרַבָּנַן. וְכִי גְּזַרוּ דְּרַבָּנַן: כִּי אִיתַנְהוּ לִמְחִיצוֹת. כִּי לֵיתַנְהוּ לִמְחִיצוֹת – לָא גְּזַרוּ רַבָּנַן! לָא פְּלוּג רַבָּנַן בֵּין אִיתַנְהוּ לִמְחִיצוֹת, בֵּין לֵיתַנְהוּ לִמְחִיצוֹת.
human_translation: But doesn’t Rava say: a partition to eat by Torah law, partitions to gather by rabbinic law, and when the Sages issued a decree where there are partitions, where there are no partitions, the Sages did not issue a decree? the Sages did not distinguish between there are partitions there are not partitions.
llm_translation: And Rava said: "A partition for eating - is it from the Torah, partitions for absorbing - is it from the Rabbis. And did the Rabbis decree: when they provided for partitions. If they did not provide for partitions - the Rabbis did not decree! The Rabbis do not dispute whether they provided for partitions or did not provide for partitions."

hebrew_text: רַב הוּנָא בַּר יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: חֲדָא קָתָנֵי: מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה שֶׁנִּכְנַס לִירוּשָׁלַיִם וְיָצָא. אַמַּאי? וְנִיהְדַּר וּנְעַיְּילֵיהּ וְנֵיכְלֵיהּ! דִּנְפוּל מְחִיצוֹת.
human_translation: Rav Huna bar Yehuda Rav Sheshet said: is teaching one with regard to second-tithe that is not worth one peruta which entered Jerusalem and exited Why? And let him bring it back and partake of it where the partitions fell.
llm_translation: Rav Huna son of Yehuda said Rav Sheshet: One Mishnah teaches: Second tithe that does not have the value of a perutah that enters Jerusalem and exits. Why? Because it is redeemed, taken out, and eaten! When its walls collapse.

hebrew_text: וְנִפְרְקֵיהּ? הָאָמַר רָבָא: מְחִיצָה לֶאֱכוֹל דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, מְחִיצָה לִקְלוֹט דְּרַבָּנַן, וְכִי גְּזַרוּ רַבָּנַן – כִּי אִיתַנְהוּ לִמְחִיצוֹת. כִּי לֵיתַנְהוּ לִמְחִיצוֹת – לָא גְּזַרוּ רַבָּנַן. לָא פְּלוּג רַבָּנַן.
human_translation: And let him redeem doesn’t Rava say: a partition to eat by Torah law, partitions to gather by rabbinic law, and when the Sages issued a decree where there are partitions, where there are no partitions, the Sages did not issue a decree? The Sages did not distinguish
llm_translation: And it was resolved? This is what Rava said: A partition for eating is of biblical origin, a partition for absorbing is of rabbinic origin. And did the Rabbis decree? Because they established partitions. If they did not establish partitions - the Rabbis did not decree. The Rabbis do not disagree.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, מַאי אִירְיָא אֵין בּוֹ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה? אֲפִילּוּ יֵשׁ בּוֹ נָמֵי! לָא מִיבַּעְיָא קָאָמַר. לָא מִיבַּעְיָא יֵשׁ בּוֹ, דְּקָלְטָן לֵיהּ מְחִיצוֹת. אֲבָל אֵין בּוֹ, אֵימָא: לָא קְלַטוּ לֵיהּ מְחִיצוֹת, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: If so, why specifically does not have the value of one peruta ? even if it has is speaking It is not necessary. It is not necessary has that the partitions gather it but it does not have say the partitions do not gather it. he teaches us
llm_translation: If so, what is meant by "it does not contain a prutah"? Even if it contains a coin! He is not asking. He is not asking if it contains a coin, for he has already acquired partitions. But if it does not contain, say: they did not acquire partitions for it, this is what he is teaching us.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״אִם גָּאֹל יִגְאַל אִישׁ מִמַּעַשְׂרוֹ״, מִמַּעַשְׂרוֹ – וְלֹא כׇּל מַעַשְׂרוֹ. פְּרָט לְמַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה. אִיתְּמַר. רַב אַמֵּי אָמַר: אֵין בּוֹ. רַב אַסִּי אָמַר: אֵין בְּחוּמְשׁוֹ. רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: אֵין בּוֹ. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן לָקִישׁ אָמַר: אֵין בְּחוּמְשׁוֹ.
human_translation: The Sages taught “And if a man will redeem of his tithe, Of his tithe, but not all his tithe. to exclude second tithe that does not have the value of one peruta , It was stated Rav Ami says: does not have Rav Asi says: its one-fifth does not have Rabbi Yoḥanan says: does not have Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: Its one-fifth does not have
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "If he shall redeem, he shall redeem a man from his tithe," from his tithe - and not all of his tithe. This excludes the second tithe, which does not have an equivalent. It was stated: Rav Ammi said: It does not have. Rav Assi said: It does not have a fifth. Rabbi Yochanan said: It does not have. Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: It does not have a fifth.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ שָׁוֶה פְּרוּטָה – דַּיּוֹ שֶׁיֹּאמַר ״הוּא וְחוּמְשׁוֹ מְחוּלָּל עַל מָעוֹת רִאשׁוֹנוֹת״.
human_translation: raises an objection second-tithe that does not have the value of one peruta , sufficient that he will say: It and its one-fifth are desacralized upon the first coins
llm_translation: Challenger: Second tithe that does not have worth a prutah - enough that it should be said "it and its fifth are redeemed with the first coins."

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר ״אֵין בְּחוּמְשׁוֹ״ – הַיְינוּ דְּקָתָנֵי ״דַּיּוֹ״, דְּאַף עַל גַּב דִּבְדִידֵיהּ אִית בֵּיהּ, כֵּיוָן דִּבְחוּמְשֵׁיהּ לֵיכָּא – שַׁפִּיר. אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר ״אֵין בּוֹ״, מַאי ״דַּיּוֹ״? קַשְׁיָא.
human_translation: Granted, according to the one who says: not in its one-fifth, this that the teaches: It is sufficient, that even though in itself it has since not in its one-fifth well, But according to the one who says: does not have what It is sufficient? difficult
llm_translation: In truth, according to the one who says "there is no obligation to pay a fifth," – that is what it teaches "it is sufficient," for even though according to his own opinion there is a fifth, since there is no obligation to pay a fifth – it is fine. But according to the one who says "there is an obligation to pay a fifth," what is "it is sufficient"? It is difficult.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: חוּמְשָׁא מִלְּגָיו, אוֹ חוּמְשָׁא מִלְּבַר? אָמַר רָבִינָא, תָּא שְׁמַע: הַבְּעָלִים אוֹמְרִים בְּעֶשְׂרִים, וְכׇל אָדָם בְּעֶשְׂרִים – הַבְּעָלִים קוֹדְמִין מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמּוֹסִיפִין חוֹמֶשׁ. אָמַר אֶחָד: הֲרֵי עָלַי בְּעֶשְׂרִים וְאֶחָד –
human_translation: a dilemma was raised before one-fifth from within, or one-fifth from without, Ravina says: Come hear the owner says for twenty and any person for twenty the owners take precedence due to that they add one-fifth, one said: It is upon me for twenty-one
llm_translation: The question was asked: A fifth from his produce, or a fifth from his livestock? Ravina said, come and hear: The owners say in twenty, and every person in twenty - the owners take precedence because they add a fifth. One said: I am obligated in twenty-one -

hebrew_text: הַבְּעָלִים נוֹתְנִין עֶשְׂרִים וָשֵׁשׁ. עֶשְׂרִים וּשְׁנַיִם – הַבְּעָלִים נוֹתְנִין עֶשְׂרִים וָשֶׁבַע. בְּעֶשְׂרִים וְשָׁלֹשׁ – הַבְּעָלִים נוֹתְנִין עֶשְׂרִים וּשְׁמוֹנֶה. בְּעֶשְׂרִים וְאַרְבַּע – הַבְּעָלִים נוֹתְנִין עֶשְׂרִים וָתֵשַׁע.
human_translation: the owner gives twenty-six twenty-two the owner gives twenty-seven; twenty-three, the owner gives twenty-eight; twenty-four, the owner gives twenty-nine.
llm_translation: Owners give twenty-six. Twenty-two - owners give twenty-seven. At twenty-three - owners give twenty-eight. At twenty-four - owners give twenty-nine.

hebrew_text: עֶשְׂרִים וְחָמֵשׁ – הַבְּעָלִים נוֹתְנִין שְׁלֹשִׁים, לְפִי שֶׁאֵין מוֹסִיפִין חוֹמֶשׁ עַל עִילּוּי שֶׁל זֶה. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ חוּמְשָׁא מִלְּבַר. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: twenty-five the owner gives thirty, due to that does not add one-fifth on the raise of this Learn from it one-fifth from without, Learn from it
llm_translation: Twenty-five - the owners give thirty, because they do not add a fifth on the elevation of this. Learn from it a fifth from the verse. Learn from it.

hebrew_text: כְּתַנָּאֵי: ״וְיָסַף חֲמִשִׁתוֹ עָלָיו״, שֶׁיְּהֵא הוּא וְחוּמְשׁוֹ חֲמִשָּׁה, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יֹאשִׁיָּה. רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן אוֹמֵר: חֲמִישִׁיתוֹ חוּמְשׁוֹ שֶׁל קֶרֶן.
human_translation: parallel to tanna’im , “And shall add unto it one-fifth part thereof” that and its one-fifth will five the statement of Rabbi Yoshiya. Rabbi Yonatan says: Its one-fifth one-fifth of the principal;
llm_translation: Tannaim: "And he shall add a fifth of it," that he and his fifth should be five, the words of Rabbi Yoshiyah. Rabbi Yonatan says: His fifth is the fifth of the principal.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: חוֹמֶשׁ מְעַכֵּב, אוֹ אֵינוֹ מְעַכֵּב? אַרְבְּעָה בְּאַרְבְּעָה פָּרֵיק, וְאַכְּנַפְשֵׁיהּ מוֹסִיף חוֹמֶשׁ, אַלְמָא חוֹמֶשׁ לָא מְעַכֵּב. אוֹ דִּלְמָא אַרְבְּעָה בְּחַמְשָׁה פָּרֵיק, וְחוֹמֶשׁ מְעַכֵּב.
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before one-fifth prevent or does it not prevent four redeemed with four and add one-fifth upon himself? apparently, one-fifth does not prevent Or perhaps four is redeemed with five and one-fifth prevents
llm_translation: He asked them: Does a fifth impede or not impede? If one separates four from four and adds a fifth, it is clear that the fifth does not impede. Or perhaps if one separates four from five, the fifth does impede.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבִינָא, תָּא שְׁמַע: הַדְּמַאי – אֵין לוֹ חוֹמֶשׁ, וְאֵין לוֹ בִּיעוּר.
human_translation: Ravina said: Come hear doubtfully tithed produce [ demai ], there is no one-fifth and there is no eradication
llm_translation: Ravina said, come and hear: Demai - it does not have tithing, and it does not have removal.

hebrew_text: הָא קֶרֶן יֵשׁ לוֹ. מַאי טַעְמָא? קֶרֶן דִּמְעַכֵּב בִּדְאוֹרָיְיתָא – אִיתַהּ בִּדְרַבָּנַן, חוֹמֶשׁ דְּלָא מְעַכֵּב בִּדְאוֹרָיְיתָא – לֵיתַהּ בִּדְרַבָּנַן.
human_translation: But there is principal. What is the reason the principal, which prevents by Torah law, is in by rabbinic law. one-fifth, which does not prevent by Torah law, is not in by rabbinic law.
llm_translation: This is the case of a horn, it has. What is the reason? A horn that impedes in the Torah - if it is in the Rabbis' domain, one may use it; but if it does not impede in the Torah, one may not use it in the Rabbis' domain.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא כְּתַנָּאֵי: נָתַן אֶת הַקֶּרֶן, וְלֹא נָתַן אֶת הַחוֹמֶשׁ, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: יֹאכַל. רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ אוֹמֵר: לֹא יֹאכַל. אָמַר רַבִּי: נִרְאִין דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בַּשַּׁבָּת, וְדִבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בַּחוֹל.
human_translation: Let us say parallel to tanna’im , gave the principal but did not give the one-fifth, Rabbi Eliezer says: One may eat Rabbi Yehoshua says: One may not eat Rabbi said: The statement of Rabbi Eliezer appears with regard to Shabbat, and the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua with regard to the week.
llm_translation: Let us say like the Tannaim: If one gave the principal amount but did not give the fifth added by the Torah, Rabbi Eliezer says: he may eat. Rabbi Yehoshua says: he may not eat. Rabbi said: The words of Rabbi Eliezer appear concerning Shabbat, and the words of Rabbi Yehoshua concerning the weekday.

hebrew_text: מִדְּאָמַר נִרְאִין דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בַּשַּׁבָּת, מִכְּלָל דִּפְלִיגִי אֲפִילּוּ בְּחוֹל. מִדְּאָמַר נִרְאִין דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בַּחוֹל, מִכְּלָל דִּפְלִיגִי אֲפִילּוּ בְּשַׁבָּת.
human_translation: From that says: The statement of Rabbi Eliezer appears with regard to Shabbat, by inference they disagree even with regard to the week. from that says: The statement of Rabbi Yehoshua appears with regard to the week, by inference they disagree even with regard to Shabbat.
