human_translation: Until Jacob, there was no illness Jacob came and prayed for mercy, and illness was as it is stated: “And one said to Joseph: Behold, your father is sick” Until Elisha, one did not fall ill and heal, Elisha came and prayed for mercy and he was healed, as it is written: “Now Elisha fell ill with his illness from which he was to die” By inference, he fallen ill other illnesses
llm_translation: Jacob was not weak until Jacob came and was weak, as it is said: "And he said to Joseph, 'Behold, your father is sick.'" Until Elisha came, he was not weak and he prayed. Elisha came, prayed, as it is said: "And Elisha fell sick with the illness of which he was to die" - from the fact that he fell sick, it is an illness of the end.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: שְׁלֹשָׁה חֳלָאִין חָלָה אֱלִישָׁע – אֶחָד שֶׁדְּחָפוֹ לְגֵיחֲזִי בִּשְׁתֵּי יָדָיו, וְאֶחָד שֶׁגֵּירָה דּוּבִּין בַּתִּינוֹקוֹת, וְאֶחָד שֶׁמֵּת בּוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וֶאֱלִישָׁע חָלָה אֶת חׇלְיוֹ אֲשֶׁר יָמוּת בּוֹ״.
human_translation: The Sages taught: Elisha fell ill with three illnesses: One that he pushed Gehazi away with both hands, One that he incited bears against young children And one from which he died, as it is stated: “Now Elisha fell ill of his illness from which he was to die”
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: Three illnesses afflicted Elisha - one that seized Gehazi with both his hands, one that caused the children to mock him, and one that caused his death, as it is stated: "And Elisha fell sick of his sickness whereof he died."

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא עַד שֶׁלֹּא יַתְחִילוּ בַּמְּלָאכָה צֵא וֶאֱמוֹר לָהֶם עַל מְנָת שֶׁאֵין לָכֶם עָלַי אֶלָּא פַּת וְקִטְנִית כּוּ׳. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב יוֹסֵף לְרַב חִסְדָּא: פַּת קִטְנִית תְּנַן, אוֹ פַּת וְקִטְנִית תְּנַן? אֲמַר לֵיהּ הָאֱלֹהִים! צְרִיכָה וָיו כִּי מוּרְדְּיָא דְלִבְרוּת.
human_translation: Rather, before they begin in labor, go out and say to them: on the condition that you have from me only bread and legumes, Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Yosef, said to Rav Ḥisda: we learn: Bread of legumes [ pat kitnit ], or we learn: Bread and legumes [ pat vekitnit ]? said to him: By God! requires vav as an oar [ mordeya ] of cypress
llm_translation: Rather, until they do not begin work, go out and say to them, "On condition that you have nothing against me except a loaf and a small one." Rav Acha, son of Rav Yosef, said to Rav Chisda: "A small loaf we learned, or a loaf and a small one we learned?" He said to him, "By God! It requires 'vav' because of the rebellion of Livrut."

hebrew_text: רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ, הַכֹּל כְּמִנְהַג הַמְּדִינָה. הַכֹּל לְאֵתוֹיֵי מַאי? לְאֵתוֹיֵי הָא דִּתְנַן: הַשּׂוֹכֵר אֶת הַפּוֹעֵל וְאָמַר לוֹ כְּאֶחָד וְכִשְׁנַיִם מִבְּנֵי הָעִיר – נוֹתֵן לוֹ כַּפָּחוּת שֶׁבַּשְּׂכִירוּת, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ. וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: מְשַׁמְּנִין בֵּינֵיהֶם.
human_translation: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: did not need to state Everything is in accordance with the regional custom. Everything, to add what? to add that which we learned one who hires a laborer and said to him: as one or two of the residents of the city he gives him with the lowest wage the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua. The Rabbis say: One divides between
llm_translation: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: It is not necessary, everything follows the custom of the land. What is the purpose of this? To explain what we learned: One who hires a laborer and tells him, "Work for me as one or as two of the residents of the city," he pays him according to the lower rate of wages in the city, the words of Rabbi Yehoshua. And the Sages say: We assess between them.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ וְאֵלּוּ אוֹכְלִין מִן הַתּוֹרָה: הָעוֹשֶׂה בִּמְחוּבָּר לַקַּרְקַע בִּשְׁעַת גְּמַר מְלָאכָה, וּבְתָלוּשׁ מִן הַקַּרְקַע עַד שֶׁלֹּא נִגְמְרָה מְלַאכְתּוֹ, וּבְדָבָר שֶׁגִּידּוּלוֹ מִן הָאָרֶץ. וְאֵלּוּ שֶׁאֵין אוֹכְלִים: הָעוֹשֶׂה בִּמְחוּבָּר לַקַּרְקַע
human_translation: And these may eat by Torah law: who works with attached to the ground at the time of the completion of work, and with detached from the ground before the completion of its work, And with an item whose growth is from the land. And these may not eat: works with attached to the ground
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: And these are the ones who may eat from the produce of the Torah: One who performs a task connected to the ground at the completion of the work, and it is attached to the ground until his work is not yet completed, and in a matter that its growth is from the earth. And these are the ones who may not eat: One who performs a task connected to the ground.

hebrew_text: בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁאֵין גְּמַר מְלָאכָה, וּבְתָלוּשׁ מִן הַקַּרְקַע מֵאַחַר שֶׁנִּגְמְרָה מְלַאכְתּוֹ, וּבְדָבָר שֶׁאֵין גִּידּוּלוֹ מִן הָאָרֶץ.
human_translation: not at the time of the completion of work, and with detached from the ground after the completion of its work, and with an item whose growth is not from the land.
llm_translation: At the time when one has not completed work, and it is hanging from the ground after his work has been completed, and in a matter whose growth is not from the earth.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מְנָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי, דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּי תָבֹא בְּכֶרֶם רֵעֶךָ וְאָכַלְתָּ״. אַשְׁכְּחַן כֶּרֶם, כֹּל מִילֵּי מְנָא לַן?
human_translation: From where are these matters, As it is written: “When you come into your neighbor’s vineyard, then you may eat We find a vineyard; from where do we any type
llm_translation: Gemara: From where do we derive these matters, as it is written: "When you enter your neighbor's vineyard, then you may eat grapes to your fill." (Deuteronomy 23:25) If one finds a vineyard, are all matters derived for us?

hebrew_text: גָּמְרִינַן מִכֶּרֶם: מָה כֶּרֶם מְיוּחָד, דָּבָר שֶׁגִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע, וּבִשְׁעַת גְּמַר מְלָאכָה פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ – אַף כׇּל דָּבָר שֶׁגִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע, בִּשְׁעַת גְּמַר מְלָאכָה פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ.
human_translation: We derive from a vineyard: Just as a vineyard is unique an entity whose growth is from the ground, and the laborer eats it at the time of the completion of work, so too any entity whose growth is from the ground at the time of the completion of work, a laborer may eat it.
llm_translation: We have learned from a vineyard: What is a designated vineyard, a matter that its produce is of the ground, and at the time of completing work, one may perform labor or eat from it - so too, any matter that its produce is of the ground, at the time of completing work, one may perform labor or eat from it.

hebrew_text: מָה לְכֶרֶם – שֶׁכֵּן חַיָּיב בְּעוֹלֵלוֹת! גָּמְרִינַן מִקָּמָה. קָמָה גּוּפַהּ מְנָא לַן? דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּי תָבֹא בְּקָמַת רֵעֶךָ וְקָטַפְתָּ מְלִילוֹת בְּיָדֶךָ״.
human_translation: What about a vineyard? in that obligated in olelot , We derive from standing And from where do we standing itself? As it is written: “When you come into your neighbor’s standing grain, then you may pluck ears with your hand;
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "What is the law regarding a vineyard - that it is liable for damage caused by its produce! We have learned from its source. From where do we derive its source? As it is written: 'When you enter your neighbor's vineyard, then you may eat grapes as you desire, to your fill, but you shall not put any in your vessel.'"

hebrew_text: מָה לְקָמָה שֶׁכֵּן חַיֶּיבֶת בַּחַלָּה! וּמִמַּאי דְּהַאי קָמָה קָמָה דְּמִתְחַיֶּיבֶת בְּחַלָּה הִיא? דִּלְמָא כֹּל קָמָה קָאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא!
human_translation: What about standing in that obligated in ḥalla . And from where that this standing is standing whose obligated in ḥalla ? Perhaps the Merciful One is discussing any standing
llm_translation: What is the standing grain that it is liable to challah! And from what source is this standing grain that it stands and is liable to challah? Perhaps it is any standing grain that the Merciful One has said is liable to challah!

hebrew_text: אָתְיָא ״קָמָה״ ״קָמָה״, כְּתִיב הָכָא ״כִּי תָבֹא בְּקָמַת רֵעֶךָ״, וּכְתִיב הָתָם ״מֵהָחֵל חֶרְמֵשׁ בַּקָּמָה״. מָה הָתָם קָמָה דְּמִיחַיְּיבָא בְּחַלָּה, אַף הָכָא נָמֵי קָמָה דְּמִיחַיְּיבָא בְּחַלָּה.
human_translation: is derived “standing” “standing” It is written here: “When you come into your neighbor’s standing grain” and it is written there, from the time the sickle is first put to the standing grain” Just as there, standing who is obligated in ḥalla , so too here, standing whose is obligated in ḥalla .
llm_translation: It was taught: "Kamah" "Kamah," it is written here "when you come into your neighbor's standing grain," and it is written there "from the beginning of the sickle in the standing grain." Just as there, "kamah" refers to a quantity that incurs liability for challah, so too here, "kamah" refers to a quantity that incurs liability for challah.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא לְמִיפְרַךְ: מָה לְקָמָה שֶׁכֵּן חַיֶּיבֶת בְּחַלָּה! כֶּרֶם יוֹכִיחַ. מָה לְכֶרֶם שֶׁכֵּן חַיָּיב בְּעוֹלֵלוֹת! קָמָה תּוֹכִיחַ.
human_translation: can be refuted What about standing in that obligated in ḥalla . Let a vineyard prove What about a vineyard? in that obligated in olelot . Let standing prove
llm_translation: There is room to differentiate: what to a vineyard is so obligated in challah! A vineyard shall prove. What to a vineyard is so obligated in orphaned plants! A field shall prove.

hebrew_text: וְחָזַר הַדִּין: לֹא רְאִי זֶה כִּרְאִי זֶה. הַצַּד הַשָּׁוֶה שֶׁבָּהֶן – שֶׁכֵּן דָּבָר שֶׁגִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע, וּבִשְׁעַת גְּמַר מְלָאכָה פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ. אַף כׇּל דָּבָר שֶׁגִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע בִּשְׁעַת גְּמַר מְלָאכָה פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ.
human_translation: The inference has reverted The aspect of this is not like the aspect of that Their common denominator is that grows from the earth and at the time of the completion of work laborer may eat it. So too, any type that grows from the earth, at the time of the completion of work, a laborer may eat it.
llm_translation: The judgment returned: not seen this like seen this. The equal side in them - for so is the matter that is told of landowners, and at the time of completing work, one may labor or eat from it. Likewise, any matter that is told of landowners, at the time of completing work, one may labor or eat from it.

hebrew_text: מָה לְהַצַּד הַשָּׁוֶה שֶׁבָּהֶן, שֶׁכֵּן יֵשׁ בָּהֶן צַד מִזְבֵּחַ. וַאֲתָא נָמֵי זַיִת, דְּאִית בֵּיהּ צַד מִזְבֵּחַ!
human_translation: What about their common denominator? in that they have an aspect altar, An olive also be derived as it has an aspect altar,
llm_translation: What is similar to the side of the altar in them, that they have a side of the altar. And comes the statement of Zayit, for it has a side of the altar!

hebrew_text: וְזַיִת בְּמָה הַצַּד אָתֵי? הוּא גּוּפֵיהּ כֶּרֶם אִיקְּרִי, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיַּבְעֵר מִגָּדִישׁ וְעַד קָמָה וְעַד כֶּרֶם זָיִת״! אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: ״כֶּרֶם זַיִת״ – אִקְּרֵי, ״כֶּרֶם״ סְתָמָא – לָא אִקְּרֵי.
human_translation: And an olive derived from the common factor it itself is called a vineyard [ kerem ], as it is written: “And he burned up both the piles of produce and the standing grain, and also the olive yards [ kerem zayit ]” Rav Pappa said: it is called olive yard [ kerem zayit ], not called a plain vineyard.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And olive, in what does it come? Its body is like a vineyard, as it is written: 'And he cleared from the thornbush and up to the standing grain and up to the olive vineyard'! Rav Papa said: 'Olive vineyard' – it is called, 'vineyard' alone – it is not called."

hebrew_text: מִכׇּל מָקוֹם קַשְׁיָא! אֶלָּא אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: אָמַר קְרָא ״וְחֶרְמֵשׁ״ לְרַבּוֹת כׇּל בַּעֲלֵי חֶרְמֵשׁ.
human_translation: In any case, difficult, Rather, Shmuel said: The verse states “But a sickle” to include all that are with a sickle.
llm_translation: From every place difficult! Rather said Shmuel: said the verse "and a sword" to include all owners of a sword.

hebrew_text: וְהַאי ״חֶרְמֵשׁ״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ: בִּשְׁעַת חֶרְמֵשׁ – אֱכוֹל, שֶׁלֹּא בִּשְׁעַת חֶרְמֵשׁ – לָא תֵּיכוֹל!
human_translation: But this “sickle” is necessary At the time of the sickle, you may eat. when it is not the time of the sickle, you may not eat.
llm_translation: And this "cheremesh" requires it: at the time of cheremesh - eat, not at the time of cheremesh - do not eat!

hebrew_text: הָהוּא מִ״וְּאֶל כֶּלְיְךָ לֹא תִתֵּן״ נָפְקָא. תִּינַח דְּבַר חֶרְמֵשׁ, דְּלָאו בַּר חֶרְמֵשׁ מְנָא לַן?
human_translation: That is derived from “But you may not put any in your vessel” works out well that requires a sickle from where do we that does not require a sickle
llm_translation: That one from "וְּאֶל כֶּלְיְךָ לֹא תִתֵּן" went out. Let the matter of Cheremesh be placed, for is he not from the sons of Cheremesh with us?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: אָמַר קְרָא ״קָמָה״ לְרַבּוֹת כׇּל בַּעֲלֵי קֹמָה. וְהָא אָמְרַתְּ: ״קָמָה״, קָמָה דְּמִיחַיְּיבָא בְּחַלָּה!
human_translation: Rather, Rabbi Yitzḥak said The verse states: “Standing [ kama ]” to include any standing But didn’t you say standing standing whose obligated in ḥalla ,
llm_translation: Rather, Rabbi Yitzchak said: The verse said "kamah" to include all those who are standing. But didn't you say: "kamah" - it is the standing that obligates in challah!

hebrew_text: הָנֵי מִילֵּי מִקַּמֵּי דְּנֵיתֵי ״חֶרְמֵשׁ״, הַשְׁתָּא דְּאָתֵי ״חֶרְמֵשׁ״ – אִיתְרַבִּי לֵיהּ כֹּל דְּבַר חֶרְמֵשׁ, וְאַף עַל גַּב דְּלָא מִיחַיַּיב בְּחַלָּה. ״קָמָה״ לְמָה לִי – לְרַבּוֹת כׇּל בַּעֲלֵי קֹמָה.
human_translation: That matter before we derived “sickle.” Now that was derived from “sickle,” any type a sickle is included, and even though is not obligated in ḥalla . why do I “standing”? to include any standing
llm_translation: These are the matters from before "cheremesh," now that "cheremesh" has come - everything is considered cheremesh, even though it does not render one liable to chalah. "Kamah" - why do I need it? To include all those who have a koma.

hebrew_text: וְהַשְׁתָּא דְּנָפְקָא לַן מֵחֶרְמֵשׁ וּמִקָּמָה ״כִּי תָבֹא בְּכֶרֶם רֵעֶךָ״ לְמָה לִי?
human_translation: And now that have derived from “sickle” and from “standing,” why do I “When you come into your neighbor’s vineyard,
llm_translation: At this time that we have emerged from the study hall and from its place, "When you enter your neighbor's vineyard," why do I need it?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא, לְהִלְכוֹתָיו. כִּדְתַנְיָא: ״כִּי תָבֹא״, נֶאֱמַר כָּאן בִּיאָה, וְנֶאֱמַר לְהַלָּן ״לֹא תָבוֹא עָלָיו הַשֶּׁמֶשׁ״, מָה לְהַלָּן בְּפוֹעֵל הַכָּתוּב מְדַבֵּר, אַף כָּאן בְּפוֹעֵל הַכָּתוּב מְדַבֵּר.
human_translation: Rava said: for its halakhot , as it is taught “when you come [ tavo ]” Coming [ bia ] is stated here, and coming is also stated there: and the sun shall not go down [ tavo ] upon it” Just as there, the verse is speaking of a laborer, so too here, the verse is speaking of a laborer,
llm_translation: Rava said, to his actions. As it was taught: "When she comes," it is stated here regarding coming, and it is stated there "the sun shall not come upon him," just as there the Scripture is speaking in an active sense, so too here the Scripture is speaking in an active sense.

hebrew_text: ״בְּכֶרֶם רֵעֶךָ״, וְלֹא בְּכֶרֶם נׇכְרִי. הָנִיחָא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר גֶּזֶל נׇכְרִי אָסוּר, הַיְינוּ דְּאִיצְטְרִיךְ קְרָא לְמִישְׁרֵי פּוֹעֵל. אֶלָּא לְמַאן דְּאָמַר גֶּזֶל נׇכְרִי מוּתָּר – הַשְׁתָּא גְּזֵילָה מוּתָּר, פּוֹעֵל מִיבַּעְיָא?!
human_translation: “in your neighbor’s vineyard” but not in the vineyard of a gentile, This works out well according to the one who says robbery a gentile is prohibited; this is why it was necessary for the verse to permit a laborer But according to the one who says robbery a gentile is permitted, now robbery is permitted, is necessary a laborer
llm_translation: "In the vineyard of your fellow," and not in the vineyard of a foreigner. This supports the one who says that theft from a foreigner is prohibited, which is why a verse is needed for the rectification of the worker. But according to the one who says that theft from a foreigner is permitted – now, if theft is permitted, why would the worker be necessary?

hebrew_text: מוֹקֵים לַהּ: ״בְּכֶרֶם רֵעֶךָ״ – וְלֹא שֶׁל הֶקְדֵּשׁ. ״וְאָכַלְתָּ״ – וְלֹא מוֹצֵץ. ״עֲנָבִים״ וְלֹא עֲנָבִים וְדָבָר אַחֵר.
human_translation: interprets “in your neighbor’s vineyard” but may not of consecrated “then you may eat” and may not suck “grapes” and not grapes and something else,
llm_translation: Established for it: "In the vineyard of your friend" - and not of consecrated property. "And you shall eat" - and not suck. "Grapes" and not grapes, and another matter.

hebrew_text: ״כְּנַפְשְׁךָ״ – כְּנֶפֶשׁ שֶׁל בַּעַל הַבַּיִת כָּךְ נַפְשׁוֹ שֶׁל פּוֹעֵל. מָה נַפְשְׁךָ אוֹכֵל וּפָטוּר, אַף נַפְשׁוֹ שֶׁל פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל וּפָטוּר.
human_translation: kenafshekha the owner himself, so is you, the laborer himself: Just as nafshekha , may eat and exempt so too, the laborer himself may eat exempt
llm_translation: "Like your soul" - just as the soul of the homeowner, so too the soul of the laborer. Just as your soul eats and is exempt, so too the soul of the laborer eats and is exempt.

hebrew_text: ״שׇׂבְעֶךָ״, וְלֹא אֲכִילָה גַּסָּה. ״וְאַל כֶּלְיְךָ לֹא תִתֵּן״, בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁאַתָּה נוֹתֵן לְכֶלְיוֹ שֶׁל בַּעַל הַבַּיִת – אַתָּה אוֹכֵל, וּבְשָׁעָה שֶׁאִי אַתָּה נוֹתֵן לְכֶלְיוֹ שֶׁל בַּעַל הַבַּיִת – אִי אַתָּה אוֹכֵל.
human_translation: you have enough” but may not excessive eating. “but you may not put any in your vessel” at a time when you put in the owner’s vessels, you may eat, but at a time when you are not putting in the owner’s vessels, you may not eat.
llm_translation: "Your fullness," and not excessive eating. "And your oil flask you shall not put," at the time when you are putting into the utensil of the homeowner - you may eat, and at the time when you are not putting into the utensil of the homeowner - you may not eat.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יַנַּאי: אֵין הַטֶּבֶל מִתְחַיֵּיב בְּמַעֲשֵׂר
human_translation: Rabbi Yannai says: untithed produce is not obligated in tithing
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Yannai: The tevel is not obligated in tithing.

hebrew_text: עַד שֶׁיִּרְאֶה פְּנֵי הַבַּיִת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״בִּעַרְתִּי הַקֹּדֶשׁ מִן הַבַּיִת״.
human_translation: until it sees the front of the house as it is stated “I have removed the consecrated from the house”
llm_translation: Until he sees the face of the house, as it is stated: "I will remove the holy from the house."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ חָצֵר קוֹבַעַת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְאָכְלוּ בִשְׁעָרֶיךָ וְשָׂבֵעוּ״.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even courtyard determines as it is stated and they shall eat in your gates and be satisfied”
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: Even a courtyard establishes ownership, as it is stated: "And they shall eat in your gates and be satisfied."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן נָמֵי, הָא כְּתִיב ״מִן הַבַּיִת״! אָמַר לָךְ: חָצֵר – דֻּמְיָא דְּבַיִת: מָה בַּיִת הַמִּשְׁתַּמֵּר – אַף חָצֵר הַמִּשְׁתַּמֶּרֶת.
human_translation: But Rabbi Yoḥanan also, isn’t it written: “From the house”? He said to you a courtyard is similar to a house, Just as a house a secured so too, the courtyard secured.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan Nami said: Is it not written "from the house"? I say to you: Courtyard - similar to a house: Just as a house that is maintained, so too a courtyard that is maintained.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יַנַּאי נָמֵי, הָכְתִיב ״בִּשְׁעָרֶיךָ״! הָהוּא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ דִּמְעַיֵּיל לֵיהּ דֶּרֶךְ שַׁעַר, לְאַפּוֹקֵי דֶּרֶךְ גַּגּוֹת וְקַרְפֵּיפוֹת דְּלָא.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yannai also, isn’t it written: “In your gates”? That is necessary that when one brings through the gate, to the exclusion of through rooftops and enclosures, which not
llm_translation: Rabbi Yannai said, it is written "in your gates"! That one wants to make for him a path of a gate, to go out by way of roofs and balconies that are not.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב חֲנִינָא חוֹזָאָה: ״כְּנַפְשְׁךָ״ – כָּךְ נַפְשׁוֹ שֶׁל פּוֹעֵל, מָה נַפְשְׁךָ אוֹכֵל וּפָטוּר, אַף נַפְשׁוֹ שֶׁל פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל וּפָטוּר.
human_translation: Rav Ḥanina Ḥoza’a raises an objection kenafshekha so is the laborer himself: Just as nafshekha , may eat and exempt so too, the laborer himself may eat exempt
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: Rav Chanina Chavza'ah raised an objection: "Like your soul" - just as your soul is exempt, what is your soul? It eats and is exempt, so too, the soul of the laborer eats and is exempt.

hebrew_text: הָא לוֹקֵחַ חַיָּיב, מַאי לָאו בַּשָּׂדֶה?
human_translation: but one who buys obligated What, is it not in the field,
llm_translation: This one who acquires is liable, what is the reason that it is not in the field?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: הָכָא בִּתְאֵנָה הָעוֹמֶדֶת בְּגִינָּה וְנוֹפָהּ נוֹטֶה לְחָצֵר עָסְקִינַן, וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר לְבַיִת – לְבַיִת.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: Here, we are dealing with a fig tree that is standing in a garden and its leaves are leaning into a courtyard, or, according to the one who says into the house, into the house.
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: Here, with regard to a fig tree standing in a garden and its branch leaning towards the courtyard, we are dealing, and according to the one who says "to the house - to the house."

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי בַּעַל הַבַּיִת נָמֵי נִיחַיַּיב! בַּעַל הַבַּיִת עֵינָיו בִּתְאֵנָתוֹ, וְלוֹקֵחַ עֵינָיו בְּמִקָּחוֹ.
human_translation: If so, the homeowner should also be obligated The homeowner’s eyes are on his fig tree, But the buyer’s eyes are on his purchase,
llm_translation: So it is, the Ba'al HaBayit is indeed liable! The Ba'al HaBayit's eyes are on his figs, yet he takes his eyes off to make a purchase.

hebrew_text: וְלוֹקֵחַ מִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא מִי מִחַיַּיב? וְהָתַנְיָא: מִפְּנֵי מָה חָרְבוּ חֲנוּיוֹת שֶׁל בֵּית הִינוֹ שָׁלֹשׁ שָׁנִים קוֹדֶם יְרוּשָׁלַיִם – מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהֶעֱמִידוּ דִּבְרֵיהֶם עַל דִּבְרֵי תוֹרָה. שֶׁהָיוּ אוֹמְרִין:
human_translation: And is a buyer obligated by Torah law But isn’t it taught For what reason were the shops of Beit Hino, destroyed three years before Jerusalem because they based their practices on matters of Torah, that they would say
llm_translation: And one who takes from the Torah, who is liable? And it was taught: For what reason were the courtyards of the Hasmonean house destroyed three years before Jerusalem? Because they established their words over the words of the Torah. For they used to say:

hebrew_text: ״עַשֵּׂר תְּעַשֵּׂר וְאָכַלְתָּ״ – וְלֹא מוֹכֵר. ״תְּבוּאַת זַרְעֶךָ״ – וְלֹא לוֹקֵחַ. אֶלָּא מִדְּרַבָּנַן, וּקְרָא אַסְמַכְתָּא בְּעָלְמָא.
human_translation: “you shall tithe…and you shall eat” but not the one who sells “the produce of your planting” but not the one who buys Rather, by rabbinic law, and the verse is a mere support
llm_translation: "Tithe, you shall surely tithe, and you shall eat" - and not sell. "The produce of your seed" - and not buy. Rather, this is a Rabbinic decree, and the verse is merely a support in general.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא ״כְּנַפְשְׁךָ״ לְמַאי אֲתָא? לְכִדְתַנְיָא: ״כְּנַפְשְׁךָ״, מָה נַפְשְׁךָ אִם חָסַמְתָּ – פָּטוּר, אַף פּוֹעֵל אִם חָסַמְתָּ – פָּטוּר.
human_translation: Rather, what does kenafshekha come to that which is taught in Kenafshekha Just as your own person, if you muzzled exempt so too a laborer, if you muzzled exempt
llm_translation: Rather, "like your soul" for what does it come? As it was taught: "like your soul," just as your soul, if you have neglected – you are exempt, so too a worker, if you have neglected – you are exempt.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב מָר זוּטְרָא: אֵיזֶהוּ גּוֹרְנָן לְמַעַשְׂרוֹת? בַּקִּישּׁוּאִים וּבַדִּלּוּעִים מִשֶּׁיְּפַקֵּסוּ. וְאָמַר רַבִּי אַסִּי: מִשֶּׁיִּנָּטֵל פֵּיקֶס שֶׁלָּהֶן. מַאי לָאו מִשֶּׁיְּפַקֵּסוּ – אֲפִילּוּ בַּשָּׂדֶה!
human_translation: Mar Zutra raises an objection what is their granary, subject to tithes? With regard to cucumbers and gourds, from when they lose their blossom; and Rabbi Asi said: from when their blossom [ pikas ] is removed. What, is it not from when they lose their blossom, even in the field?
llm_translation: The Master Zutra raises an objection: What is considered a threshing floor for tithes? In the vineyards and in the olive presses from when they are designated. And Rabbi Assi said: From when their produce is removed. Why not from when they are designated? Even in the field!

hebrew_text: לֹא מִשֶּׁיְּפַקְּסוּ בַּבַּיִת. אִי הָכִי, ״מִשֶּׁיְּפַקֵּסוּ״ ״עַד שֶׁיְּפַקֵּסוּ״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ!
human_translation: No, From when they lose their blossom in the house If so, From when they lose their blossom, should have Until they lose their blossom.
llm_translation: Not from when they check in the house. If so, "when they check in" or "until they check in" is required!

hebrew_text: אִי תְּנָא עַד שֶׁיְּפַקֵּסוּ – הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: עַד דְּגָמַר לְפִיקּוּסַיְיהוּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן: מִשֶּׁיְּפַקְּסוּ, מִכִּי (אַתְחוֹלֵי) [מַתְחֵיל] פִּיקּוּסַיְיהוּ.
human_translation: Had taught: Until they lose their blossom, I would say until their loss of blossom is complete, From when they lose their blossom, teaches us from when they begin to lose their blossom.
llm_translation: If you want, until they appraise - I would say: until he completes their appraisal, it implies to us: from when they appraise, from when they begin their appraisal.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב מָר זוּטְרָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב נַחְמָן: גּוֹרְנוֹ לְמַעֲשֵׂר לְחַיֵּיב עָלָיו מִשּׁוּם טֶבֶל מִשֶּׁתִּגָּמֵר מְלַאכְתָּן. וְאֵיזֶהוּ גְּמַר מְלַאכְתָּן – מְלֶאכֶת הַכְנָסָתָן. מַאי לָאו הַכְנָסָתָן אֲפִילּוּ בַּשָּׂדֶה!
human_translation: Mar Zutra, son of Rav Naḥman, raises an objection its granary for tithes, rendering one liable for untithed produce, from when its work is completed. And what is the completion of its work? the work of its being brought in. What, is it not its being brought into even in the field?
llm_translation: The Master Zutra, son of Rav Nachman, raises an objection: "A threshing floor designated for tithing - one is obligated regarding it due to the completion of their work. And what is considered the completion of their work? The work of their gathering." What is the reason that it is not considered their gathering even in the field!

hebrew_text: לָא, הַכְנָסָתָן לַבַּיִת – זֶה הוּא גְּמַר מְלַאכְתָּן. וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: כִּי קָאָמַר רַבִּי יַנַּאי בְּזֵיתִים וַעֲנָבִים, דְּלָאו בְּנֵי גוֹרֶן נִינְהוּ. אֲבָל חִטִּין וּשְׂעוֹרִין – ״גּוֹרֶן״ בְּהֶדְיָא כְּתִיב בֵּיהּ.
human_translation: No, its being brought into the house is completion of its work. And if you wish, say When Rabbi Yannai say to olives or grapes, which are not of a granary, But wheat or barley, a granary is explicitly written with regard to them
llm_translation: Not entering their house - this is completing their work. And if you will say: When Rabbi Yannai spoke about olives and grapes, he was not referring to the sons of the threshing floor. But wheat and barley - "threshing floor" is explicitly written regarding them.

hebrew_text: אַשְׁכְּחַן אָדָם בִּמְחוּבָּר וְשׁוֹר בְּתָלוּשׁ. אָדָם בְּתָלוּשׁ מְנָלַן?
human_translation: We found a person from attached and an ox from detached From where do we a person, from detached
llm_translation: We find a man in a state of connection and an ox in a state of detachment. How do we know that a man in a state of detachment is liable?

hebrew_text: קַל וָחוֹמֶר מִשּׁוֹר: וּמָה שׁוֹר שֶׁאֵינוֹ אוֹכֵל בִּמְחוּבָּר – אוֹכֵל בְּתָלוּשׁ, אָדָם שֶׁאוֹכֵל בִּמְחוּבָּר אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁאוֹכֵל בְּתָלוּשׁ? מָה לְשׁוֹר שֶׁכֵּן אַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה עַל חֲסִימָתוֹ, תֹּאמַר בְּאָדָם שֶׁאִי אַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה עַל חֲסִימָתוֹ!
human_translation: an a fortiori from an ox. And if an ox, not eat from attached eat from detached a person, who may eat from attached is it not right that he may eat from detached What about an ox? in that you are commanded concerning its muzzling. you say to a person, as you are not commanded with regard to his muzzling?
llm_translation: Light and heavy from an ox: And just as an ox that does not eat in a tied manner - eats in a loose manner, is it not logical that a person who eats in a tied manner is not judged as one who eats in a loose manner? Just as for an ox, for which you are commanded regarding its muzzle, you would say the same for a person for whom you are not commanded regarding his muzzle!

hebrew_text: וִיהֵא אָדָם מְצֻוֶּוה עַל חֲסִימָתוֹ מִקַּל וָחוֹמֶר מִשּׁוֹר: וּמָה שׁוֹר שֶׁאִי אַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה לְהַחְיוֹתוֹ, אַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה עַל חֲסִימָתוֹ. אָדָם שֶׁאַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה לְהַחְיוֹתוֹ – אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁאַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה עַל חֲסִימָתוֹ?!
human_translation: But let be commanded concerning a person’s, muzzling, from an a fortiori from an ox: And if an ox, which you are not commanded to sustain, you are commanded concerning its muzzling, person, whom you are commanded to sustain is it not right that you are commanded concerning his muzzling?
llm_translation: And a person is commanded regarding the muzzling of his animal from a fortiori reasoning from an ox: And just as for an ox, for which you are commanded to keep it alive, you are commanded regarding its muzzling. Is it not the case that for a person, for whom you are commanded to keep alive, is it not logical that you are commanded regarding its muzzling?!

hebrew_text: אָמַר קְרָא ״כְּנַפְשְׁךָ״, כְּנַפְשׁוֹ שֶׁל פּוֹעֵל: מָה נַפְשׁוֹ אִם חֲסַמְתּוֹ פָּטוּר – אַף פּוֹעֵל אִם חֲסַמְתּוֹ פָּטוּר.
human_translation: the verse states: “ Kenafshekha ,” so is the person of the laborer. just as himself, if you muzzled exempt so too a laborer, if you muzzled exempt
llm_translation: The verse said, "like your soul," like the soul of the worker: just as his soul, if you have exempted him, so too the worker, if you have exempted him.

hebrew_text: וְאֶלָּא, אָדָם בְּתָלוּשׁ מְנָלַן? אָמַר קְרָא ״קָמָה״ ״קָמָה״ – שְׁתֵּי פְּעָמִים, אִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לְאָדָם בִּמְחוּבָּר, תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לְאָדָם בְּתָלוּשׁ.
human_translation: Rather, from where do we a person from detached The verse states “standing,” “standing” twice: If not matter of a person from attached apply it matter of a person from detached
llm_translation: And rather, is man suspended, wherefrom do we derive this? The verse says "arise" "arise" - twice. If it is not a matter for a person when connected, make it a matter for a person when suspended.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אַמֵּי אָמַר: אָדָם בְּתָלוּשׁ לָא צְרִיךְ קְרָא. כְּתִיב: ״כִּי תָבֹא בְּכֶרֶם רֵעֶךָ״ – מִי לָא עָסְקִינַן שֶׁשְּׂכָרוֹ לְכַתֵּף, וְאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא לֵיכוֹל.
human_translation: Rabbi Ami stated A verse is not required a person from detached it is written: “When you come into your neighbor’s vineyard, Are we not dealing which hired to transport and the Merciful One states he may eat?
llm_translation: Rabbi Ammi said: A person who is hanging does not require a verse. It is written: "When you enter your neighbor's vineyard" - are we not dealing with a case where his reward is on his shoulder, and the Merciful One said he may eat?

hebrew_text: שׁוֹר בִּמְחוּבָּר מְנָלַן? קַל וָחֹמֶר מֵאָדָם: וּמָה אָדָם שֶׁאֵינוֹ אוֹכֵל בְּתָלוּשׁ – אוֹכֵל בִּמְחוּבָּר, שׁוֹר שֶׁאוֹכֵל בְּתָלוּשׁ – אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁאוֹכֵל בִּמְחוּבָּר? מָה לְאָדָם – שֶׁכֵּן אַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה לְהַחְיוֹתוֹ, תֹּאמַר בְּשׁוֹר שֶׁאִי אַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה לְהַחְיוֹתוֹ!
human_translation: From where do we an ox from attached an a fortiori from a person. And if a person, who may not eat from detached may eat from attached an ox, which eat from detached is it not right that it eat from attached What about a person? in that you are commanded to sustain him. you say of an ox, when you are not commanded to sustain it?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: A bull in a pen, from where do we derive it? Light and heavy from a person: And just as a person who does not eat while suspended - eats when in a pen, a bull that eats while suspended - is it not logical that it should eat when in a pen? Just as for a person - since you are commanded to sustain him, you would say the same for a bull that you are not commanded to sustain him!

hebrew_text: וִיהֵא שׁוֹר מְצֻוֶּוה לְהַחְיוֹתוֹ, מִקַּל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה אָדָם שֶׁאִי אַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה עַל חֲסִימָתוֹ – אַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה לְהַחְיוֹתוֹ, שׁוֹר שֶׁאַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה עַל חֲסִימָתוֹ – אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁאַתָּה מְצֻוֶּוה לְהַחְיוֹתוֹ?!
human_translation: But let one be commanded to sustain an ox, by an a fortiori And if, a person, where you are not commanded concerning his muzzling, you are commanded to sustain him, an ox, where you are commanded concerning its muzzling, is it not right that you are commanded to sustain it?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And a commanded ox to keep it alive, from a fortiori reasoning: And just as for a person, that you are commanded regarding his lost property - you are commanded to keep him alive, for an ox that you are commanded regarding its lost property - is it not logical that you are commanded to keep it alive?!

hebrew_text: אָמַר קְרָא: ״וְחֵי אָחִיךָ עִמָּךְ״, אָחִיךָ וְלֹא שׁוֹר. וְאֶלָּא, שׁוֹר בִּמְחוּבָּר מְנָלַן? אָמַר קְרָא: ״רֵעֶךָ״ ״רֵעֶךָ״ שְׁתֵּי פְּעָמִים, אִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לְאָדָם בִּמְחוּבָּר – תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לְשׁוֹר בִּמְחוּבָּר.
human_translation: the verse states: “And your brother shall live with you” your brother, but not an ox. Rather, from where do we an ox from attached The verse states “your neighbor,” “your neighbor” twice If is not matter of a person from attached apply it matter of an ox, from attached
llm_translation: The verse says: "And let your brother live with you," your brother and not an ox. But is an ox connected to you? The verse says: "Your neighbor," "Your neighbor" twice, if it is not fitting for a person to be connected to you, make it fitting for an ox to be connected to you.

hebrew_text: רָבִינָא אָמַר: לָא אָדָם בְּתָלוּשׁ וְלֹא שׁוֹר בִּמְחוּבָּר צְרִיכִי קְרָאֵי, דִּכְתִיב: ״לֹא תַחְסֹם שׁוֹר בְּדִישׁוֹ״.
human_translation: Ravina said: Verses are not necessary either a person from detached or an ox from attached as it is written: “You shall not muzzle an ox in its threshing”
llm_translation: Ravina said: "Not a person hanging and not an ox tied need Scriptural verses, as it is written: 'You shall not muzzle an ox while it is threshing.'"

hebrew_text: מִכְּדֵי כֹּל מִילֵּי אִיתַנְהוּ בַּחֲסִימָה, דְּיָלְפִינַן ״שׁוֹר״ ״שׁוֹר״ מִשַּׁבָּת. אִם כֵּן, לִכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא: ״לֹא תָּדוּשׁ בַּחֲסִימָה״, שׁוֹר דִּכְתַב רַחֲמָנָא לְמָה לִי?
human_translation: Now, All matters, are in muzzling, as we derive “an ox” “an ox” with regard to Shabbat. If so, let the Merciful One write You shall not thresh while muzzling; why do I need “ox” that the Merciful One writes?
llm_translation: From all words they included in the vinegar, that we differentiate "ox" "ox" from Sabbath. If so, to write the Merciful One: "Do not thresh in the vinegar," why do I need an ox that the Merciful One wrote?

hebrew_text: לְאַקּוֹשֵׁי חוֹסֵם לְנֶחְסָם וְנֶחְסָם לְחוֹסֵם. מַה חוֹסֵם אוֹכֵל בִּמְחוּבָּר – אַף נֶחְסָם אוֹכֵל בִּמְחוּבָּר. וּמַה נֶחְסָם אוֹכֵל בְּתָלוּשׁ – אַף חוֹסֵם אוֹכֵל בְּתָלוּשׁ.
human_translation: to juxtapose muzzles to the muzzled and the muzzled to the one who muzzles: Just as the one who muzzles, eat from attached so too the muzzled may eat from attached And just as the muzzled may eat from detached so too the one who muzzles may eat from detached
llm_translation: To those who tie, it is forbidden to untie, and to those who untie, it is forbidden to tie. Just as one who ties may eat from a mixture, so too one who unties may eat from a mixture. And just as one who unties may eat from a hanging mixture, so too one who ties may eat from a hanging mixture.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״דַּיִשׁ״, מָה דַּיִשׁ מְיוּחָד – דָּבָר שֶׁגִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע, וּבִשְׁעַת גְּמַר מְלָאכָה, וּפוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ – אַף כֹּל שֶׁגִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ. יָצָא הַחוֹלֵב וְהַמְחַבֵּץ וְהַמְגַבֵּן, שֶׁאֵין גִּידּוּלֵי קַרְקַע וְאֵין פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ.
human_translation: The Sages taught threshing. Just as threshing is unique that an item grown from the ground, and at the time of the completion of work, and a laborer may eat it, so too any that is grown from the ground, a laborer may eat it. exclude one who milks one who makes butter and one who makes cheese as are not grown from the ground, and a laborer may not eat them.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: "Dish," what is a unique dish - something that is attached to the ground, and at the time of completing the work, and a worker or animal eats from it - so too, anything attached to the ground, a worker or animal eats from it. Exempt are the milk curdler, the tanner, and the dyer, for they are not attached to the ground and a worker or animal does not eat from them.

hebrew_text: לְמָה לִי? מִ״כִּי תָבֹא בְּכֶרֶם רֵעֶךָ״ נָפְקָא. אִיצְטְרִיךְ: סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא, הוֹאִיל וּכְתִיב ״קָמָה״, לְרַבּוֹת כׇּל בַּעֲלֵי קֹמָה, לְרַבּוֹת נָמֵי מִידֵּי דְּלָאו גִּדּוּלֵי קַרְקַע נִינְהוּ, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: Why do I derived from “When you come into your neighbor’s vineyard” was necessary it might enter your mind to say since writes: “Standing” to include all items that stand, also to include items that are not grown from the ground. teaches us
llm_translation: "Why do I need it?" "When you enter your neighbor's vineyard" is derived. It is necessary: I would say, since it is written "arises," to include all those of elevated stature, to include also those who are not owners of land, they are considered as if they are. This is what he teaches us.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא אִידַּךְ: ״דַּיִשׁ״ – מָה דַּיִשׁ מְיוּחָד, דָּבָר שֶׁבִּשְׁעַת גְּמַר מְלָאכָה פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ – אַף כֹּל שֶׁהוּא בִּשְׁעַת גְּמַר מְלָאכָה פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ. יָצָא הַמְנַכֵּשׁ בְּשׁוּמִים וּבִבְצָלִים, הוֹאִיל וְאֵין גְּמַר מְלָאכָה – אֵין פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בָּהֶם.
human_translation: It is taught another Threshing, just as threshing is unique an item that is at the time of the completion of work a laborer may eat it, so too any that is at the time of the completion of work, a laborer may eat it. exclude one who weeds garlic and onions, since it is not the completion of work, a laborer may not eat from them.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: It was taught in another Baraita: "Dish" - just as a dish is designated, something that at the time of completing the work, one may perform labor or eat with it - so too, anything that is at the time of completing the work, one may perform labor or eat with it. One who traps an animal with garlic or with onions, since there is no completion of the work - one may not perform labor or eat with them.

hebrew_text: לְמָה לִי? מִ״וְאֶל כֶּלְיְךָ לֹא תִתֵּן״ נָפְקָא! לָא צְרִיכָא, אַף עַל גַּב דְּקָא מְשַׁלֵּיף קַטִּינֵי מִבֵּינֵי אַלִּימֵי.
human_translation: Why do I derived from: “But you shall not put any in your vessel” No, necessary Even though he plucks the small ones from between the thick ones,
llm_translation: "Why do I need it? 'From a foreigner you may exact it, but your hand shall release what is yours' - it is derived! It is not necessary, even though he is extracting small coins from among the mighty."

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא אִידַּךְ: ״דַּיִשׁ״, מָה דַּיִשׁ מְיוּחָד, דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא נִגְמְרָה מְלַאכְתּוֹ לְמַעֲשֵׂר פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ – אַף כׇּל שֶׁלֹּא נִגְמְרָה מְלַאכְתּוֹ לְמַעֲשֵׂר פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ. יָצָא הַבּוֹדֵל בִּתְמָרִים וּבִגְרוֹגְרוֹת, הוֹאִיל וְנִגְמְרָה מְלַאכְתּוֹ לְמַעֲשֵׂר – אֵין פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ.
human_translation: It is taught another Threshing, just as threshing is unique an item whose work is not completed for tithes, a laborer may eat it, so too any whose work is not completed for tithes, a laborer may eat it. exclude one who separates dates and dried figs, since its work is completed for tithes a laborer may not eat from it.
llm_translation: It was taught in another Baraita: "Dish," just as a dish is designated, an item whose work has not been completed, one may perform labor or eat from it – so too, any item whose work has not been completed, one may perform labor or eat from it. If one separates dates and dried figs, since their work has been completed for tithing – one may not perform labor or eat from them.

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא: הַבּוֹדֵל בִּתְמָרִים וּבִגְרוֹגְרוֹת פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ! אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: כִּי תַּנְיָא הָהִיא – בְּתוּחְלָנֵי.
human_translation: But isn’t it taught one who separates dates and dried figs, laborer may eat from it? Rav Pappa said: When that is taught, to unripe dates,
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it was taught: One who separates dates and nuts, may perform labor or eat it! Rav Papa said: For it was taught in the language of Tuchlanai. English translation:

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא אִידַּךְ: ״דַּיִשׁ״, מָה דַּיִשׁ מְיוּחָד, דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא נִגְמְרָה מְלַאכְתּוֹ לְחַלָּה וּפוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ – אַף כׇּל דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא נִגְמְרָה מְלַאכְתּוֹ לְחַלָּה פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ. יָצָא הַלָּשׁ וְהַמְקַטֵּף וְהָאוֹפֶה שֶׁנִּגְמְרָה מְלַאכְתּוֹ לְחַלָּה, דְּאֵין פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ. וַהֲלֹא נִגְמְרָה מְלַאכְתּוֹ לְמַעֲשֵׂר!
human_translation: It is taught another Threshing, just as threshing is unique an item whose work is not completed for ḥalla , and a laborer may eat it, so too any whose work is not completed for ḥalla , a laborer may eat it. exclude one who kneads and one who smooths and one who bakes, as its work is completed for ḥalla , a laborer may not eat from it. But hasn’t its work been completed for tithes
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: "Dish," what is a unique dish? Something whose work has not been completed to its detriment, and a worker or consumer benefits from it - so too, anything whose work has not been completed to its detriment, a worker or consumer benefits from it. The kneader, the reaper, and the baker, whose work has been completed to its detriment, as a worker or consumer does not benefit from it. But has not his work been completed for tithing!

hebrew_text: לָא קַשְׁיָא: בְּחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ עָסְקִינַן, דְּלֵיכָּא מַעֲשֵׂר. אִי הָכִי, חַלָּה נָמֵי לֵיכָּא! אֶלָּא לְעוֹלָם בָּאָרֶץ, וְלָא קַשְׁיָא: בְּשֶׁבַע שֶׁכִּיבְּשׁוּ וּבְשֶׁבַע שֶׁחִילְּקוּ, דְּאָמַר מָר: שֶׁבַע שֶׁכִּיבְּשׁוּ וְשֶׁבַע שֶׁחִילְּקוּ נִתְחַיְּיבוּ בְּחַלָּה וְלֹא נִתְחַיְּיבוּ בְּמַעֲשֵׂר.
human_translation: not difficult, we are dealing with outside of Eretz where there is no tithes. If so, ḥalla also not Rather, actually with regard to Eretz and not difficult, to seven which they conquered and to the seven which they divided As the Master said: seven which conquered and seven which they divided they were obligated in ḥalla but they were not obligated in of tithes.
llm_translation: Not difficult: In the outskirts of the land we are dealing, as there is no tithe. If so, there is also no obligation for challah! Rather, indeed in the land, and it is not difficult: in seven years that they dried up and in seven years that they were divided, as the Master said: in seven years that they dried up and in seven years that they were divided, they are obligated in challah and not obligated in tithe.

hebrew_text: מִידֵּי מַעֲשֵׂר קָא גָרֵים? גְּמַר מְלָאכָה קָא גָרֵים!
human_translation: Is tithes factor the completion of the work is factor,
llm_translation: From the hands of tithes they are dwelling? They are dwelling from the completion of work!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבִינָא: כְּרוֹךְ וּתְנִי. ״דַּיִשׁ״, מָה דַּיִשׁ מְיוּחָד – דָּבָר שֶׁלֹּא נִגְמַר מְלַאכְתּוֹ לְמַעֲשֵׂר וּלְחַלָּה וּפוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ, אַף כׇּל שֶׁלֹּא נִגְמַר מְלַאכְתּוֹ לְמַעֲשֵׂר וּלְחַלָּה פּוֹעֵל אוֹכֵל בּוֹ.
human_translation: Rather, Ravina said: combine and teach threshing, just as threshing is unique an item whose work is not completed for tithe, and for ḥalla , a laborer may eat it, so too any whose work is not completed for tithe or for ḥalla , a laborer may eat it.
llm_translation: Rather, Ravina said: "Tie it and teach. 'Dish,' just as a dish is designated - something whose work has not been completed for tithing and taking challah, and a worker or animal can eat from it, so too, anything whose work has not been completed for tithing and taking challah, a worker or animal can eat from it."

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: פּוֹעֵל, מַהוּ שֶׁיְּהַבְהֵב בָּאוּר וְיֹאכַל, מִי הָוֵי כַּעֲנָבִים וְדָבָר אַחֵר אוֹ לָא? תָּא שְׁמַע: רַשַּׁאי בַּעַל הַבַּיִת לְהַשְׁקוֹת פּוֹעֲלִים יַיִן כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יֹאכְלוּ עֲנָבִים הַרְבֵּה, רַשָּׁאִין פּוֹעֲלִין לְטַבֵּל פִּיתָּם בְּצִיר כְּדֵי שֶׁיֹּאכְלוּ עֲנָבִים הַרְבֵּה!
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before a laborer, what is that he may singe in fire, and eat whether is like grapes and something else, or not? Come hear A homeowner is permitted to give laborers wine to drink, so that they will not eat many grapes laborers are permitted to dip their bread in brine, so that they will eat many grapes.
llm_translation: He asked them: A worker, what if he kindles a fire in the light and eats, is it considered like grapes or not? Come and hear: The owner of the house is permitted to give workers wine to drink so that they do not eat many grapes, and workers are permitted to dip their bread in vinegar so that they may eat many grapes!

hebrew_text: לְאַכְשׁוֹרֵי גַּבְרָא לָא קָמִיבַּעְיָא לַן, כִּי קָמִיבַּעְיָא לַן לְאַכְשׁוֹרֵי פֵּירָא, מַאי? תָּא שְׁמַע: פּוֹעֲלִין אוֹכְלִין עֲנָבִים בְּרָאשֵׁי אוּמָּנִיּוֹת שֶׁלָּהֶם, וּבִלְבַד שֶׁלֹּא יְהַבְהֲבוּ בָּאוּר!
human_translation: We did not raise difficulty with regard to the fitness of the man When was raised to us, to the fitness of the produce What, Come hear Laborers may eat grapes at the end of their rows provided that they do not singe in fire.
llm_translation: To the merchants of a man, not he stood for us, when he stood for us to the merchants of a wild donkey, what? Come and hear: Workers eat grapes at the beginning of their craftsmanship, only they should not light a fire!

hebrew_text: הָתָם מִשּׁוּם בִּיטּוּל מְלָאכָה, כִּי קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לַן, הֵיכָא דְּאִיכָּא אִשְׁתּוֹ וּבָנָיו, מַאי?
human_translation: there due to neglect labor, When the dilemma is raised to us, to when has his wife and children What
llm_translation: There, because of the nullification of work, when it is necessary for us, in a place where there is a wife and children, what is the law?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: לֹא יְהַבְהֵב בָּאוּר וְיֹאכַל, וְלֹא יִכְמוֹר בַּאֲדָמָה וְיֹאכַל, וְלֹא יַפְרִיךְ עַל גַּבֵּי הַסֶּלַע וְיֹאכַל, אֲבָל מְפָרֵיךְ עַל יָד עַל יָד וְאוֹכֵל. הָתָם מִשּׁוּם בִּיטּוּל מְלָאכָה. הָכִי נָמֵי מִסְתַּבְּרָא, דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ מִשּׁוּם מַתּוֹקֵי פֵּירָא – סֶלַע מַאי מַתּוֹקֵי פֵּירָא אִיכָּא? אִי אֶפְשָׁר דְּלָא מְמַתֵּיק פּוּרְתָּא.
human_translation: Come hear may not singe in fire and eat, and he may not heat in the ground and eat, and he may not break on rocks and eat, but he may break little by little and eat. There due to neglect labor. So too, it is reasonable As, if it enters your mind due to sweetening of the produce, what sweetening of the produce is there a rock? impossible that would not be sweetened a little.
llm_translation: Come and hear: One may not kindle a flame from a lamp and eat, nor may one heap up soil and eat, nor may one crumble bread on the surface of a rock and eat, but one may crumble bread hand to hand and eat. There it is prohibited due to the prohibition of performing labor. It is thus reasoned: If it enters your mind to permit eating because of the sweetness of the fruit – what sweetness of fruit is there in a rock? It is impossible that it sweetens the bread.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: פּוֹעֲלִין שֶׁהָיוּ עוֹדְרִים בִּתְאֵנִים וְגוֹדְרִים בִּתְמָרִים וּבוֹצְרִים בַּעֲנָבִים וּמוֹסְקִין בְּזֵיתִים – הֲרֵי אֵלּוּ אוֹכְלִים, וּפְטוּרִים, שֶׁהַתּוֹרָה זִיכְּתָה לָהֶם. בְּפִיתָּם לֹא יֹאכְלוּ, אֶלָּא אִם כֵּן נָטְלוּ רְשׁוּת מִבַּעַל הַבַּיִת. וְלֹא יִסְפּוֹת בַּמֶּלַח וְיֹאכַל!
human_translation: Come hear laborers who were plucking figs, or plucking dates, or harvesting grapes, or harvesting olives, they may eat and they are exempt as the Torah entitled them they may not eat with their bread unless they received permission from the homeowner. one may not dip [ lo yispot ] in salt and eat.
llm_translation: Come and hear: Workers who were still gathering figs, and cutting dates, and harvesting grapes, and pressing olives - these may eat, and are exempt, for the Torah has designated them. They may not eat from their own bread unless they have received permission from the owner of the house. And they may not dip in salt and eat!

hebrew_text: מֶלַח וַדַּאי כַּעֲנָבִים וְדָבָר אַחֵר דָּמֵי.
human_translation: Salt is certainly considered like grapes and something else,
llm_translation: Salt and indeed like grapes and another matter blood.

hebrew_text: וְלֹא יִסְפּוֹת בַּמֶּלַח וְיֹאכַל. וּרְמִינְהוּ: הַשּׂוֹכֵר אֶת הַפּוֹעֵל לְעַדֵּר וּלְקַשְׁקֵשׁ תַּחַת הַזֵּיתִים – הֲרֵי זֶה לֹא יֹאכַל, שְׂכָרוֹ לִבְצוֹר שְׂכָרוֹ לִמְסוֹק שְׂכָרוֹ לְלַקֵּט – הֲרֵי זֶה אוֹכֵל וּפָטוּר, שֶׁהַתּוֹרָה זִיכְּתָה לָהֶן. קָצַץ אַחַת וְאַחַת – יֹאכַל, שְׁתַּיִם שְׁתַּיִם – לֹא יֹאכַל, וְסוֹפֵת בַּמֶּלַח וְיֹאכַל.
human_translation: And he may not dip in salt and eat. And raises a contradiction one who hires a laborer to till and dig a circle under olives, this one may not eat he hired him to harvest or hired him to harvest hired him to gather this one may eat and he is exempt as the Torah entitled he stipulated one by one, he may eat two by two he may not eat And he may dip in salt and eat.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And he shall not diminish in the salt and eat." And they raised a dilemma: One who hires a laborer to gather and to prune beneath the olive trees - this one may not eat, his wage is for harvesting, his wage is for pruning, his wage is for gathering - this one may eat and be exempt, for the Torah has acquitted them. If he cuts one by one - he may eat, two by two - he may not eat, and he finishes with salt and eats.

hebrew_text: אַהֵיָיא? אִילֵּימָא אַסֵּיפָא – כֵּיוָן דְּקָצַץ, כֹּל הֵיכִי דְּבָעֵי לֵיכוֹל, אֶלָּא לָאו אַרֵישָׁא!
human_translation: To which If we say to the latter clause, Since stipulated in any manner he wishes, he may eat Rather, is it not to the first clause
llm_translation: אַהֵיָיא? - Ahaiya? אִילֵּימָא אַסֵּיפָא – Ileima, Asseifa - כֵּיוָן דְּקָצַץ, כֹּל הֵיכִי דְּבָעֵי לֵיכוֹל, אֶלָּא לָאו אַרֵישָׁא! - Since he cut, in every way he wants to eat, but not the head!

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: לָא קַשְׁיָא. כָּאן – בָּאָרֶץ, כָּאן – בְּחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ. בָּאָרֶץ קָבְעָא סְפִיתָא, בְּחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ לָא קְבַעָא סְפֵיתָא. אָמַר רָבָא: מִי אִיכָּא מִידֵּי דְּבָאָרֶץ קְבַעָא סְפֵיתָא מִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, וּבְחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ לֹא קִבְעָא סְפֵיתָא, וּמוּתָּר לְכַתְּחִילָּה?!
human_translation: Abaye said: not difficult, here in Eretz there outside of Eretz In Eretz dipping establishes Outside of Eretz dipping does not establish Rava said: Is there any that in Eretz dipping establishes by Torah law, and outside Eretz dipping does not establish and it is permitted ab initio ?
llm_translation: Abaye said: It is not difficult. Here - in the land, here - outside the land. In the land, the measure is fixed, outside the land the measure is not fixed. Rava said: Is it possible that regarding the land, the measure is fixed from the Torah, and outside the land the measure is not fixed, and it is permitted to begin with?!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: בֵּין בָּאָרֶץ בֵּין בְּחוּצָה לָאָרֶץ, חֲדָא לָא – קִבְעָא סְפֵיתָא, תַּרְתֵּי – קְבַעָא סְפֵיתָא. קָצַץ: בֵּין סָפַת וּבֵין לֹא סָפַת, אַחַת אַחַת – אוֹכֵל, שְׁתַּיִם שְׁתַּיִם – לֹא יֹאכַל. לֹא קָצַץ וְלֹא סָפַת – אוֹכֵל שְׁתַּיִם שְׁתַּיִם, סָפַת: אַחַת אַחַת – אוֹכֵל, שְׁתַּיִם שְׁתַּיִם – לֹא יֹאכַל, וְאַף עַל גַּב דְּנָטַל רְשׁוּת מִבַּעַל הַבַּיִת, דְּאִיטְּבִיל לְהוּ לְמַעֲשֵׂר וְקָבְעָא סְפִיתָא.
human_translation: Rather, Rava stated Whether in Eretz outside of Eretz one dipping does not establish two, dipping does establish he stipulated whether he dipped or did not dip he may eat one by one, he may not eat two by two. he did not stipulate and did not dip may eat two by two. dips may eat one by one, he may not eat two by two, even though he received permission from the homeowner. that they have been rendered untithed produce with regard to tithes, dipping established
llm_translation: Rava said: Whether in the domain or outside the domain, if one cut off a single stalk, it is considered a fixed measure; if two, it is considered an established measure. If one cuts, whether it is a stalk or not a stalk, he may eat each one separately; if two, he may not eat them. If he neither cut nor uprooted, he may eat two at a time. If he uprooted, he may eat each one separately; if two, he may not eat them. Even though he took permission from the homeowner, as he intended to tithe and establish a measure.

hebrew_text: וְתַרְתֵּי דְּקָבְעָא סְפִיתָא מְנָא לַן? אָמַר רַב מַתְנָא, דְּאָמַר קְרָא: ״כִּי קִבְּצָם כֶּעָמִיר גֹּרְנָה״.
human_translation: And from where do we that two dipping establishes Rav Mattana said as the verse states: “For He has gathered them as the sheaves to the threshing-floor”
llm_translation: "And two of a kab of fine flour, how much is it for us? Rav Matna said, as the verse states: 'For when they will be gathered like sheaves in the threshing floor.'"

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: פָּרוֹת הַמְרַכְּסוֹת בִּתְבוּאָה,
human_translation: The Sages taught: cows that tread on produce
llm_translation: The Sages taught: Fruits that are mixed in produce,

hebrew_text: וְהַדָּשׁוֹת בִּתְרוּמָה וּמַעֲשֵׂר, אֵינוֹ עוֹבֵר מִשּׁוּם ״בַּל תַּחְסוֹם״, אֲבָל מִפְּנֵי מַרְאִית הָעַיִן – מֵבִיא בּוּל מֵאוֹתוֹ הַמִּין וְתוֹלֶה לָהּ בַּטְּרַסְקָלִין שֶׁבְּפִיהָ. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחַאי אוֹמֵר: מֵבִיא כַּרְשִׁינִים וְתוֹלֶה לָהּ, שֶׁהַכַּרְשִׁינִים יָפוֹת לָהּ מִן הַכֹּל.
human_translation: or that thresh teruma and tithe, he does not violate Do not muzzle, but due to the appearance of bring a piece of that species and hang it in the basket [ bateraskalin ] that is by mouth. Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: may bring vetches and hang it, as vetches are better for it than anything.
llm_translation: The lentils in terumah and ma'aser, does not transgress due to "do not seal," but because of the appearance of the eye - one brings bul from the same species and suspends it in her mouth. Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai says: one brings peas and suspends it for her, for peas are the most beautiful of all.

hebrew_text: וּרְמִינְהִי: פָּרוֹת הַמְרַכְּסוֹת בִּתְבוּאָה – אֵינוֹ עוֹבֵר מִשּׁוּם ״בַּל תַּחְסוֹם״. וְהַדָּשׁוֹת בִּתְרוּמָה וּמַעֲשֵׂר – עוֹבֵר מִשּׁוּם ״בַּל תַּחְסוֹם״. וְנׇכְרִי הַדָּשׁ בְּפָרָתוֹ שֶׁל יִשְׂרָאֵל – אֵינוֹ עוֹבֵר מִשּׁוּם ״בַּל תַּחְסוֹם״. וְיִשְׂרָאֵל הַדָּשׁ בְּפָרָתוֹ שֶׁל נׇכְרִי – עוֹבֵר מִשּׁוּם ״בַּל תַּחְסוֹם״. קַשְׁיָא תְּרוּמָה אַתְּרוּמָה, קַשְׁיָא מַעֲשֵׂר אַמַּעֲשֵׂר!
human_translation: And raises a contradiction cows that tread on produce, one does not violate Do not muzzle, but those which thresh teruma and tithes, he does violate Do not muzzle. And a gentile who threshes with the cow of a Jew, he does not violate Do not muzzle, but a Jew who threshes with the cow of a gentile does violate Do not muzzle, a difficulty teruma and teruma a difficulty tithe and tithe
llm_translation: And ask: Cattle that are tied up for produce - does not violate the prohibition of "Do not muzzle an ox while it is threshing." And threshing animals with tithes and offerings - does violate the prohibition of "Do not muzzle an ox while it is threshing." And a non-Jew who threshes with the cow of an Israelite - does not violate the prohibition of "Do not muzzle an ox while it is threshing." And an Israelite who threshes with the cow of a non-Jew - does violate the prohibition of "Do not muzzle an ox while it is threshing." Difficulty: tithe is tithe, difficulty: tithe is tithe!

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא תְּרוּמָה אַתְּרוּמָה לָא קַשְׁיָא – כָּאן בִּתְרוּמָה, כָּאן בְּגִידּוּלֵי תְרוּמָה. אֶלָּא מַעֲשֵׂר אַמַּעֲשֵׂר קַשְׁיָא!
human_translation: Granted, teruma and teruma not difficult, here, with regard to teruma , there, with regard to growths of teruma , But tithe and tithe difficult.
llm_translation: In peace, terumah you shall separate - terumah is not difficult here in terumah, here in the growths of terumah. Rather, tithing is difficult!

hebrew_text: וְכִי תֵּימָא מַעֲשֵׂר אַמַּעֲשֵׂר נָמֵי לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן – בְּמַעֲשֵׂר, כָּאן – בְּגִידּוּלֵי מַעֲשֵׂר. בִּשְׁלָמָא גִּידּוּלֵי תְרוּמָה – תְּרוּמָה! אֶלָּא גִּידּוּלֵי מַעֲשֵׂר – חוּלִּין נִינְהוּ. דִּתְנַן: גִּידּוּלֵי טֶבֶל וְגִידּוּלֵי מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי – חוּלִּין!
human_translation: And if you would say tithe and tithe also not difficult, here, with regard to tithe, there, with regard to growths of tithe, granted, growths of teruma teruma but growths of tithe are non-sacred As we learned growths of untithed produce and growths of second tithe non-sacred.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And if you say, "Tithe of a tithe is not difficult," here - regarding tithe, here - regarding the growth of the tithe. Granted, the growth of terumah - it is terumah! Rather, the growth of the tithe - they are common. As we learned: The growth of second tithe and the growth of the second tithe - they are common! English translation:

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא בְּמַעֲשֵׂר רִאשׁוֹן, הָא בְּמַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי. וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: הָא וְהָא בְּמַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי, וְלָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא רַבִּי מֵאִיר, הָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: Rather, not difficult. this with regard to first tithe, that with regard to second tithe, And if you wish, say this and that with regard to second tithe, and not difficult, this Rabbi Meir, that Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: Rather, it is not difficult: this in regards to the first tithe, this in regards to the second tithe. And if you wish, say: this and this in regards to the second tithe, and it is not difficult: this is Rabbi Meir, this is Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: הָא רַבִּי מֵאִיר, דְּאָמַר: מַעֲשֵׂר מָמוֹן גָּבוֹהַּ הוּא, הָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה דְּאָמַר: מַעֲשֵׂר שֵׁנִי מָמוֹן הֶדְיוֹט הוּא.
human_translation: This Rabbi Meir, who says that tithe is property Most High, that Rabbi Yehuda, who says that second tithe is non-sacred property.
llm_translation: The text reads as follows: "Here, Rabbi Meir, who said: Tithe is high-quality money. Here, Rabbi Yehuda, who said: Second tithe is common money."

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָּמֵי? כְּגוֹן שֶׁהִקְדִּימוֹ בְּשִׁבֳּלִין.
human_translation: What are the circumstances where preceded when on the stalks.
llm_translation: "How is it similar? For example, that they prioritized him in Shebilin."

hebrew_text: וּלְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה? וְהָא בָּעֵי חוֹמָה! כְּגוֹן שֶׁדָּשׁ לִפְנִים מֵחוֹמַת בֵּית פָּאגֵי.
human_translation: And according to Rabbi Yehuda, But required wall. where he threshed inside the wall of Beit Pagei,
llm_translation: And for Rabbi Yehuda? But it requires a wall! For example, if one threshed inside the boundary of the house of Pagai.

hebrew_text: אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: לָא קַשְׁיָא. כָּאן – בְּמַעֲשֵׂר וַדַּאי, כָּאן – בְּמַעֲשֵׂר דְּמַאי. הַשְׁתָּא דְּאָתֵית לְהָכִי, תְּרוּמָה אַתְּרוּמָה נָמֵי לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן – בִּתְרוּמַת וַדַּאי, כָּאן – בִּתְרוּמַת דְּמַאי.
human_translation: If you wish, say not difficult; here, with regard to definite tithe, there, with regard to doubtfully tithed produce [ demai ], Now that you have arrived at this teruma and teruma also not difficult, here, with regard to definite teruma , there, with regard to teruma of demai .
llm_translation: If you ask, say: it is not difficult. Here - regarding tithe definitely, here - regarding tithe of what. Now that you have come to this, terumah after terumah is not difficult: here - regarding terumah definitely, here - regarding terumah of what.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא מַעֲשֵׂר דְּמַאי אִיכָּא, אֶלָּא תְּרוּמַת דְּמַאי מִי אִיכָּא? וְהָתַנְיָא: אַף הוּא בִּיטֵּל אֶת הַוִּידּוּי וְגָזַר עַל הַדְּמַאי – לְפִי שֶׁשָּׁלַח בְּכֹל גְּבוּל יִשְׂרָאֵל וְרָאָה שֶׁלֹּא הָיוּ מַפְרִישִׁין אֶלָּא תְּרוּמָה גְּדוֹלָה בִּלְבָד!
human_translation: Granted, demai of tithe, there is But demai of teruma , is there But isn’t it taught He, also annulled the declaration and he decreed that demai because he sent throughout all the borders of Eretz Yisrael and saw that they would separate only the great teruma alone,
llm_translation: In truth, what is the tithe of Demai? Rather, is there a separation of Demai? And it was taught: He also annulled the declaration and decreed concerning Demai - because he sent to all the borders of Israel and saw that they were separating only a large terumah!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן – בִּתְרוּמַת מַעֲשֵׂר וַדַּאי, כָּאן – בִּתְרוּמַת מַעֲשֵׂר דְּמַאי.
human_translation: Rather, not difficult; here, with regard to definite teruma of the tithe, there, with regard to teruma of the tithe from demai .
llm_translation: Rather, it is not difficult: here - regarding the tithe of produce, for sure; here - regarding the tithe of produce of what.

hebrew_text: בְּעוֹ מִינֵּיהּ מֵרַב שֵׁשֶׁת: הָיְתָה אוֹכֶלֶת וּמַתְרֶזֶת, מַהוּ? מִשּׁוּם דִּמְעַלֵּי לַהּ הוּא, וְהָא לָא מְעַלֵּי לַהּ? אוֹ דִלְמָא דְּחָזְיָא וּמִצְטַעֲרָא, וְהָא חָזְיָא וּמִצְטַעֲרָא?
human_translation: raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet: was eating and was excreting diarrhea [ matrezet ], what is because is good for it, and this is not good for it, Or perhaps that it sees and suffers and this one sees and suffers
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Be'o mineih mei Rav Sheshet: haytah okhelet u'matretzet, mah? mishum di'ma'alei la, ve'ha la ma'alei la? o dilma dechazyah u'mitzta'ara, ve'ha chazyah u'mitzta'ara?" English translation: "They asked Rav Sheshet: If she was eating and vomiting, what is the ruling? Is it because she is causing herself to become ill, and this is not considered causing herself to become ill? Or perhaps because she sees and becomes distressed, and this one sees and becomes distressed?"

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לְהוּ רַב שֵׁשֶׁת: תְּנֵיתוּהָ, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחַי אוֹמֵר: מֵבִיא כַּרְשִׁינִים וְתוֹלֶה לָהּ, שֶׁהַכַּרְשִׁינִים יָפוֹת לָהּ מִן הַכֹּל. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ מִשּׁוּם דִּמְעַלֵּי לַהּ הוּא. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: Rav Sheshet said to them: You learned Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: bring vetches and hang it, as vetches are better for it than anything. learn from because is good for it. Learn from
llm_translation: He said to them, Rav Sheshet: You have taught it, Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai says: One brings cress and hangs it for her, for cress is the most beautiful of all. Learn from this that it is a transgression for her. Learn from this.

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: מַהוּ שֶׁיֹּאמַר אָדָם לְנׇכְרִי ״חֲסוֹם פָּרָתִי וְדוּשׁ בָּהּ״? מִי אָמְרִינַן: כִּי אָמְרִינַן אֲמִירָה לְנׇכְרִי שְׁבוּת, הָנֵי מִילֵּי לְעִנְיַן שַׁבָּת – דְּאִיסּוּר סְקִילָה, אֲבָל חֲסִימָה, דְּאִיסּוּר לָאו – לָא, אוֹ דִלְמָא לָא שְׁנָא?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before What is that a person can say to a gentile: Muzzle my cow and thresh with it? Do we say when we state speaking to a gentile a rabbinic decree, this matter only to Shabbat, when a prohibition stoning, but muzzling, which prohibition, not or perhaps is no difference
llm_translation: The question was asked: What should a person say to a non-Jew, "Seal my wine and press it"? Do we say: When we say to a non-Jew a statement of prohibition, those words are regarding the matter of Shabbat - which involves a punishment of stoning, but regarding sealing, which does not involve a prohibition of stoning - no, or perhaps it is not different?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: נׇכְרִי הַדָּשׁ בְּפָרָתוֹ שֶׁל יִשְׂרָאֵל – אֵינוֹ עוֹבֵר מִשּׁוּם ״בַּל תַּחְסוֹם״. מִעְבָּר הוּא דְּלָא עָבַר, הָא אִיסּוּרָא אִיכָּא. בְּדִין הוּא דְּאִיסּוּרָא נָמֵי לֵיכָּא, וְאַיְּידֵי דִּתְנָא סֵיפָא דְּיִשְׂרָאֵל הַדָּשׁ בְּפָרָתוֹ שֶׁל נׇכְרִי עוֹבֵר, תְּנָא רֵישָׁא: אֵינוֹ עוֹבֵר.
human_translation: Come hear A gentile who threshes with the cow of a Jew does not violate Do not muzzle. It is a transgression that he does not transgress, but there is a prohibition by right that there is no prohibition either, but since taught the latter clause that a Jew who threshes with the cow of a gentile does violate he taught the first clause He does not violate
llm_translation: Come and hear: A non-Jew who threshes with the ox of an Israelite - he does not transgress the prohibition of "Do not muzzle an ox while it is threshing." He transgresses because he did not transgress, for there is a prohibition involved. It is a valid judgment that there is a prohibition, and since the latter clause teaches that an Israelite who threshes with the ox of a non-Jew transgresses, the first clause teaches: he does not transgress.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע דִּשְׁלַחוּ לֵיהּ לַאֲבוּהּ דִּשְׁמוּאֵל: הָלֵין תּוֹרֵי
human_translation: Come hear, as they sent to Shmuel’s father these oxen
llm_translation: Come and hear that they sent to his father-in-law of Shmuel: "Lain Torah."

hebrew_text: דְּגָנְבִין אַרְמָאֵי וּמְגַנְּחִין יָתְהוֹן, מַהוּ? שְׁלַח לְהוּ: הַעֲרָמָה אִתְעֲבִיד בְּהוּ, אַעֲרִימוּ עֲלַיְיהוּ וְיִזְדַּבְּנוּן.
human_translation: which gentiles steal and castrate. What is sent to him: They used artifice; artifice with them and make them sell it
llm_translation: Theft Arameans and deceivers they, what? Send to them: deceit do with them, deceive upon them and they will be deceived.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: בְּנֵי מַעְרְבָא סָבְרִי לַהּ כְּרַבִּי חִידְקָא, דְּאָמַר: בְּנֵי נֹחַ מְצֻוִּוין עַל הַסֵּירוּס, וְקָא עָבְרִי מִשּׁוּם ״וְלִפְנֵי עִוֵּר לֹא תִתֵּן מִכְשֹׁל״.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: the inhabitants of the West, hold in accordance with Rabbi Ḥideka, who says: The descendants of Noah are commanded with regard to castration. And transgress of: “Nor put a stumbling block before the blind”
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: The people of Ma'arva hold like Rabbi Ḥidka, who said: The descendants of Noah were commanded concerning the prohibition of castration, and it is transgressed due to the verse, "And before the blind do not place a stumbling block."

hebrew_text: סְבַר רָבָא לְמֵימַר יִמָּכְרוּ לִשְׁחִיטָה. אָמַר לוֹ אַבָּיֵי דַּיָּין שֶׁקָּנַסְתָּ עֲלֵיהֶם מְכִירָה.
human_translation: Rava thought to say they sell for slaughter, Abaye said to him: enough for them that you penalized them sell
llm_translation: Rava thought to say, "They should be sold for slaughter." Abaye said to him, "A judge who coerces them into selling."

hebrew_text: פְּשִׁיטָא: בְּנוֹ גָּדוֹל – כִּי אַחֵר דָּמֵי. בְּנוֹ קָטָן מַאי? רַב אַחַי אָסַר, וְרַב אָשֵׁי שָׁרֵי. מָרִימָר וּמָר זוּטְרָא, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ הָנְהוּ תְּרֵי חֲסִידֵי, מְחַלְּפִי אַהֲדָדֵי.
human_translation: obvious to his adult son, is considered like another his minor son, what Rav Aḥai prohibited and Rav Ashi permitted Mareimar and Mar Zutra, and some say a certain pair of pious men, would exchange with each other.
llm_translation: The Gemara: It is obvious: with a grown son - because of the blood. What about with a young son? Rav Achai prohibited, and Rav Ashe permitted. Marimar and Mar Zutra, and some say it was two pious individuals, they would exchange with each other.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: הוֹשִׁיב לָהּ קוֹץ בְּפִיהָ, מַהוּ? הוֹשִׁיב לָהּ?! חֲסִימָה מְעַלַּיְיתָא הִיא! אֶלָּא יָשַׁב לָהּ קוֹץ בְּפִיהָ, מַהוּ?
human_translation: Rami bar Ḥama raises a dilemma: placed a thorn in the mouth what is he placed in its is proper muzzling. Rather, a thorn settled in its mouth what is
llm_translation: Ba'ei Ramei bar Ḥama asked: He placed a thorn in her mouth, what is the ruling? He placed it in her mouth?! It is a form of witchcraft! Rather, if he sat a thorn in her mouth, what is the ruling?

hebrew_text: הִרְבִּיץ לָהּ אֲרִי מִבַּחוּץ, מַהוּ? הִרְבִּיץ לָהּ?! חֲסִימָה מְעַלַּיְיתָא הִיא! אֶלָּא רָבַץ לָהּ אֲרִי מִבַּחוּץ, מַהוּ? הֶעֱמִיד בְּנָהּ מִבַּחוּץ, מַהוּ? הָיְתָה צְמֵאָה לְמַיִם, מַהוּ? פָּרַס לָהּ קַטְבֻלְיָא עַל גַּבֵּי דִּישָׁה, מַהוּ?
human_translation: one made a lion crouch over it from outside, what is he made crouch over it, is proper muzzling. Rather, a lion was crouching over it what is if he placed its young on the outside, what is was thirsty for water, what is he spread a leather blanket [ katavliya ] for it over threshing, what is
llm_translation: He spread out for her a lion from outside, what? He spread out for her?! It is a dangerous act! Rather, he placed for her a lion from outside, what? He stood her son from outside, what? She was thirsty for water, what? He spread out a pitcher of water for her on a pile of lentils, what?

hebrew_text: פְּשׁוֹט מִיהָא חֲדָא, דְּתַנְיָא: רַשַּׁאי בַּעַל פָּרָה לְהַרְעִיב פָּרָתוֹ כְּדֵי שֶׁתֹּאכַל מִן הַדִּישָׁה הַרְבֵּה, וְרַשַּׁאי בַּעַל הַבַּיִת לְהַתִּיר פְּקִיעַ עָמִיר לִפְנֵי הַבְּהֵמָה כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא תֹּאכַל מִן הַדִּישָׁה הַרְבֵּה!
human_translation: Resolve at least one as it is taught The owner of a cow is permitted to starve his cow so that it will eat plenty of the threshing, and a homeowner is permitted to untie a bundle of straw before an animal so that it will not eat plenty of the threshing.
llm_translation: Simply, one, as it was taught: It is permitted for the owner of an ox to starve his ox in order for it to eat much from the threshing floor, and it is permitted for the owner of the house to permit the animal to break through a stack of sheaves in front of it so that it does not eat much from the threshing floor!

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי הָתָם דְּקָא אָכְלָה. אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: רַשַּׁאי בַּעַל הַבַּיִת לְהַתִּיר פְּקִיעַ עָמִיר לִפְנֵי בְּהֵמָה מֵעִיקָּרָא כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא תֹּאכַל הַרְבֵּה מִן הַדִּישָׁה.
human_translation: there it is different, as it eat If you wish, say A homeowner is permitted to untie a bundle of straw before an animal at the outset, so that it will not eat plenty of the threshing.
llm_translation: The difference there is that she ate. If you wish, say: Is the homeowner permitted to untie a bundle of sheaves in front of an animal initially so that it does not eat a lot from the threshing floor.

hebrew_text: בְּעָא מִינֵּיהּ רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן מֵרַבִּי סִימַאי: חֲסָמָהּ מִבַּחוּץ, מַהוּ? ״שׁוֹר בְּדִישׁוֹ״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא, וְהָא לָאו בְּדִישׁוֹ הוּא, אוֹ דִלְמָא לֹא תָּדוּשׁ בַּחֲסִימָה אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא?
human_translation: Rabbi Yonatan raised a dilemma before Rabbi Simai: one muzzled from the outside, what is the Merciful One states: “An ox in its threshing” and this is not in its threshing, Or perhaps the Merciful One states may not thresh while muzzled.
llm_translation: Requested of him Rabbi Yonatan from Rabbi Simai: She sealed it from the outside, what? "An ox in its threshing" said the Merciful One, but this is not in its threshing, or perhaps the Merciful One said not to thresh with the seal?

hebrew_text: אָמַר לוֹ: מִבֵּית אָבִיךָ אַתָּה לָמֵד: ״יַיִן וְשֵׁכָר אַל תֵּשְׁתְּ אַתָּה וּבָנֶיךָ אִתָּךְ בְּבֹאֲכֶם״. בְּבוֹאֲכֶם הוּא דְּאָסוּר, הָא מִישְׁתָּא וּמֵיעַל שְׁרֵי.
human_translation: said to him: You learn from your father’s house, “Drink no wine nor strong drink, you nor your sons with you, when you come into it is when you come into that it is prohibited, to drink and enter is permitted?
llm_translation: He said to him: From the house of your father you have learned: "Wine and strong drink do not drink, you and your sons with you, when you enter." When they enter, it is prohibited, but after they have entered, it is permitted and it is no longer considered drinking.

hebrew_text: ״וּלְהַבְדִּיל בֵּין הַקֹּדֶשׁ וּבֵין הַחֹל״ אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא. אֶלָּא, מָה הָתָם: בִּשְׁעַת בִּיאָה לֹא תְּהֵא שִׁכְרוּת, הָכָא נָמֵי: בִּשְׁעַת דִּישָׁה לֹא תְּהֵא חֲסִימָה.
human_translation: the Merciful One states: “That you may make a difference between the sacred and the non-sacred” Rather, just as there, at the time of entry there must be no drunkenness, here too at the time of threshing there must be no muzzling.
llm_translation: "To separate between the holy and the mundane," the Merciful One said. Rather, just as there: at the time of plowing there should not be drunkenness, so too here: at the time of threshing there should not be negligence."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַחוֹסֵם אֶת הַפָּרָה וְהַמְזַוֵּוג בְּכִלְאַיִם – פָּטוּר, וְאֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה אֶלָּא דָּשׁ וּמַנְהִיג בִּלְבָד.
human_translation: The Sages taught: one who muzzles a cow and one who plows with diverse kinds together, exempt, as only threshes and who leads are flogged.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: One who seals the cow and mates it with two different animals - is exempt, and he is only liable for damages and fines.

hebrew_text: אִיתְּמַר: חֲסָמָהּ בְּקוֹל וְהִנְהִיגָהּ בְּקוֹל? רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: חַיָּיב, רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר: פָּטוּר. רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: חַיָּיב, עֲקִימַת פִּיו הָוְיָא מַעֲשֶׂה. רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר: פָּטוּר, קָלָא לָא הָוֵי מַעֲשֶׂה.
human_translation: It was stated one muzzled with voice, and he led by voice, Rabbi Yoḥanan says liable; Reish Lakish says exempt. Rabbi Yoḥanan says liable, the twisting of one’s mouth is an action, Reish Lakish says exempt, voice is not an action.
llm_translation: It was stated: If she silenced her with a voice and led her with a voice? Rabbi Yochanan said: Guilty. Resh Lakish said: Exempt. Rabbi Yochanan said: Guilty, for the closing of his mouth is considered an action. Resh Lakish said: Exempt, for mere voice is not considered an action.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן לְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ:
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Reish Lakish:
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan raised an objection to Reish Lakish:

hebrew_text: לֹא שֶׁאָדָם רַשַּׁאי לְהָמִיר, אֶלָּא שֶׁאִם הֵמִיר – מוּמָר, וְסוֹפֵג אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָא מַנִּי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, דְּאָמַר: לָאו שֶׁאֵין בּוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה לוֹקִין עָלָיו.
human_translation: not that it is permitted for a person to effect substitution; rather that if one substituted the substitution takes effect. and incurs the forty said to him: whose is this It is Rabbi Yehuda, who says one is flogged for a prohibition that does not involve an action.
llm_translation: Not that a person is permitted to exchange, rather if he exchanged - he is designated, and he completes the forty. He said to him: This is the teaching of Rabbi Yehuda, who said: "If it does not have a deed, lashes are not administered upon it."

hebrew_text: וּמִי מָצֵית מוֹקְמַתְּ לַהּ כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה? וְהָא קָתָנֵי רֵישָׁא: הַכֹּל מְמִירִין, אֶחָד הָאֲנָשִׁים וְאֶחָד הַנָּשִׁים, וְהָוֵינַן בָּהּ: ״הַכֹּל״ לְאֵתוֹיֵי מַאי? לְאֵתוֹיֵי יוֹרֵשׁ, וּדְלָא כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה,
human_translation: But can you establish in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda? it teaches the first clause: Everyone substitutes both men and women. And we discussed Everyone, to add what? to add an heir, And not in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And who found a basis for her like Rabbi Yehuda? And it teaches in the beginning: All can change, whether men or women, and we are in it: "All" - to include what? To include an heir, and not like Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: דְּאִי כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, הָאָמַר: יוֹרֵשׁ אֵינוֹ מֵמִיר, יוֹרֵשׁ אֵינוֹ סוֹמֵךְ! הַאי תַּנָּא סָבַר לַהּ כְּווֹתֵיהּ בַּחֲדָא, וּפָלֵיג עֲלֵיהּ בַּחֲדָא.
human_translation: As, if in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, doesn’t he say an heir cannot effect substitution, an heir cannot place this tanna holds in accordance with with regard to one and disagrees with him with regard to one
llm_translation: Like Rabbi Yehuda, who said: "An heir does not effect a change, an heir does not rely on it!" This Tanna holds in accordance with his reasoning in one aspect, and disagrees with him in another aspect.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הַחוֹסֵם אֶת הַפָּרָה וְדָשׁ בָּהּ – לוֹקֶה, וּמְשַׁלֵּם אַרְבָּעָה קַבִּין לְפָרָה וּשְׁלֹשָׁה קַבִּין לַחֲמוֹר. וְהָא אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה וָמֵת, וְאֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה וּמְשַׁלֵּם. אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: הָא מַנִּי – רַבִּי מֵאִיר הִיא, דְּאָמַר: לוֹקֶה וּמְשַׁלֵּם.
human_translation: The Sages taught: One who muzzles a cow and threshes with it is flogged, and he must pay four kav for a cow, and three kav for a donkey. But isn’t is not flogged and death, and he is not flogged and pay? Abaye said: whose is this It is Rabbi Meir, who says flogged and pay.
llm_translation: The sages taught: One who seals a cow and threshes with it - is liable, and must pay four kav for the cow and three kav for the donkey. If he is not liable and dies, he is not liable to pay. Abaye said: This is the opinion of Rabbi Meir, who said: he is liable and must pay.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: ״אֶתְנַן״ אָסְרָה תּוֹרָה, וַאֲפִילּוּ בָּא עַל אִמּוֹ.
human_translation: Rava said Torah prohibits payment and even engaged in intercourse with his own mother,
llm_translation: Rava said: "Etnan" the Torah prohibited, even if he came upon his mother.

hebrew_text: רַב פָּפָּא אָמַר: מִשְּׁעַת מְשִׁיכָה אִיחַיַּיב לֵהּ בִּמְזוֹנוֹתֶיהָ, וּמִילְקָא לָא לָקֵי עַד שְׁעַת חֲסִימָה.
human_translation: Rav Pappa stated From the time of pulling he was rendered obligated to its sustenance but for flogging, he is not flogged until the time of muzzling.
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: From the time of drawing the dowry, he is obligated to provide for her sustenance, but the milk does not take effect until the time of weaning.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: הָנֵי מִילֵּי בְּעוֹ מִינַּאי דְּבֵי רַב פָּפָּא בַּר אַבָּא, וּפְשַׁטִי לְהוּ לְאִיסּוּרָא – חֲדָא כְּהִלְכְתָא, וַחֲדָא דְּלָאו כְּהִלְכְתָא.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said: These matters, were raised as a dilemma to me the house Rav Pappa bar Abba, and I resolved for them that a prohibition One in accordance with the halakha , and one not in accordance with the halakha .
llm_translation: Rav Papa said: Those words are from the heretical sect of the house of Rav Papa bar Abba, and I will explain to them as follows - one is in accordance with the halakha, and one is not in accordance with the halakha.

hebrew_text: בְּעוֹ מִינַּאי: מַהוּ לָלוּשׁ אֶת הָעִיסָּה בְּחָלָב? וּפְשַׁטִי לְהוּ לְאִיסּוּרָא כְּהִלְכְתָא, דְּתַנְיָא: אֵין לָשִׁין אֶת הָעִיסָּה בְּחָלָב, וְאִם לָשׁ – כׇּל הַפַּת כּוּלָּהּ אֲסוּרָה, מִפְּנֵי הֶרְגֵּל עֲבֵירָה. כַּיּוֹצֵא בוֹ: אֵין טָשִׁין אֶת הַתַּנּוּר בְּאַלְיָה, וְאִם טָשׁ – כׇּל הַפַּת כּוּלָּהּ אֲסוּרָה, עַד שֶׁיַּסִּיק אֶת הַתַּנּוּר.
human_translation: They raised dilemma before me: What is of kneading dough with milk? And I resolved for them that a prohibition, in accordance with the halakha . As it is taught One may not knead dough with milk, and if he kneaded the entire loaf is forbidden, because accustomed to sin. Similarly, one may not smear over an oven with tail, and if he did smear the entire loaf is forbidden, until he heats the oven
llm_translation: Inquiry: What is the ruling regarding kneading dough with milk? And I will explain it according to the law, as it is taught: One may not knead dough with milk, and if one does so - all the bread is entirely forbidden, due to the habit of transgression. Similar to this: One may not smear the oven with fat, and if one does so - all the bread is entirely forbidden, until one heats the oven.

hebrew_text: וְאִידָּךְ בְּעוֹ מִינַּאי: מַהוּ לְהַכְנִיס מִין וְשֶׁאֵינוֹ מִינוֹ לַדִּיר? וּפְשַׁטִי לְהוּ לְאִיסּוּרָא דְּלָאו כְּהִלְכְתָא.
human_translation: And the other question they asked of me What is bringing in of different species into pen? And I resolved for them that a prohibition, not in accordance with the halakha .
llm_translation: And the other opinion is regarding a different matter: What is the law regarding bringing in a species that is not its own kind into a dwelling? And I would explain it to mean regarding prohibition, not according to the law.
